algorithms.bodyText: >1. 63.--No. 2 .--All rights reserved. MARCH-APRIL, 1957 R.OSEATE x BARE-EYED COCKATOO HYBRID By Karol Lukaszewigz (Director of the Zoo, Wroclaw, Poland) The female Bare-eyed Cockatoo possessed by the Wroclaw Zoo as quite an old bird when, in 1948, it returned from a temporary )st-war exile to our bird house. Its very clamorous call, uttered pecially frequently in the evening hours, and heard far away in the irk, made me suspect that it was a female. For a time it shared ie same aviary and company of a Greater Sulphur-crested Cockatoo, en lived with many other parrots, but was much dreaded by them 'cause of its pugnacious character. Finally, it associated itself with red Macaw until, in 1953, the Zoo came into possession of a Roseate ockatoo, whose most outstanding quality consisted in a remarkable repertoire " of some fifty Polish words. The two cockatoos became excellent friends from the very moment ey saw each other and as the Bare-eyed at the same time stopped ving its evening concerts of cries, I thought it proper to give this mewhat unusual couple an opportunity to nest. A trunk of an old rn tree, 5 feet high with a diameter of some 12 inches, was placed one corner of the aviary. A circular hole measuring 4 inches was ade in the front of the bark-covered trunk and below this an oblong ;sure invited the birds to work it with their beaks so as to enlarge ie shallow cavity inside the trunk. Both cockatoos took great interest . working at the trunk. Day after day the Roseate male left the hole of the ground near the trunk covered with chips and splinters, worked so hard. Gradually the hole inside the trunk became rger and larger and the birds managed to transform the narrow isure into a wide entrance to their nest situated a little below the iginal circular opening. By the beginning of 1955 it was evident that the friendship of the /o cockatoos was of the most serious nature. The best proof of it as an egg laid on the last day of March. The Roseate male and e Bare-eyed female were sitting and incubating most assiduously on
algorithms.sectionHeader: 42 KAROL LUKASZEWICZ-ROSEATE X BARE-EYED COCKATOO HYBRID
algorithms.bodyText: their nest and in the intervals did not stop working at the trunk, After twenty-one days of incubation the keeper found, on the morning of 18th May, that a young bird had hatched and was lying dead or the sand on the ground of the aviary. A conspicuous feature of the young was a well-developed bare area around the eyes. Six months later, in December, 1955, the cockatoos mated again several times during a week. Eggs, two in number, pure white and the size of a larger pigeon egg, were laid on 6th and 8th January. Incubation began once, the male relieving the female every three hours by day and night, and lasted for thirty-two days. The young ones hatched on 8th February and lived for twelve days. Their rate of growth showed itself to be very good. At the time of death they were covered with conspicuous quills. The explanation of this mishap is not easy. Obviously the parents fed the young birds well and we found no reason to interfere by taking them out of the nest. The birds were absolutely unmolested and the keeper did not even dare to enter the cage because of the agressiveness of both adult birds. The post-mortem examination of the two young ones, which were normally developed and weighed respectively 88.5 gr. and 118.0 gr, did not reveal any pathological changes. The stomach and the intestines, however, were copiously filled with sand, which wa< probably brought with the food. The floor of the aviary was therefore scrupulously cleared of sand and only a small box containing some gravel was left in the aviary for the parents. Almost immediately after the death of the young ones the parent: mated again and eggs were laid on 10th, 12th, and 17th March. The laying of the last egg was somewhat belated and for three days the female (the Bare-eyed) was evidently feeling sick ; it could not keep perched normally across the branches but laid along them with it eyes shut and shivering, often with cowered wings--a typical picture of what in German is called the Legenot. Two eggs disappeared ir an unaccountable way leaving no trace. Finally, on 5th April, 1956 a young one hatched and was reared successfully up to the age 0: twenty-one days, when suddenly the parents stopped feeding it. Thi: was noticed too late and the young one died from under-nourishment On 21 st and 25th May, 1956, again three eggs were laid. Thf incubation was regular and lasted from twenty-five to thirty days The first young cockatoo hatched on 15th May and from the beginning was obviously a stronger bird. The two others did not thrive anc died a few days after hatching, on 18th and 20th May. The surviv'd was left with the parents for ten days, during which it was regularl) fed by them. On 26th May, however, as the parents were observec to be neglecting their duties, the old cockatoos were moved to ar aviary some distance away and the young hybrid confided to th< care of a keeper, Mrs. Teresa Ungert.
To face p. 43 Mrs. TERESA UnGERT, FEEDING THE LAST COCKATOO HYBRID, JULY, 1956.
algorithms.sectionHeader: KAROL LUKASZEWICZ-ROSEATE X BARE-EYED COCKATOO HYBRID 43
algorithms.bodyText: The bird was fed by the keeper from her mouth every two hours etween 7 * 3 * a * m * and 6.30 p.m. For the first three days it was given pap of hard-boiled yolk and toast in this way ; then chopped and rushed sunflower seed and fresh strawberry juice were added. Gradually this diet was amplified by cake, pulped mashed apple, oiled rice with strawberry juice, pumpkin seed, lemon and red urrant juice, fresh cherries, and tomatoes. The young cockatoo grew fast and fledged normally, the quills ppearing first on the wings and the crest after the eighth day. After month the feathers developed to such an extent as to show the Dlours. The general colouring was that of the father : dove-grey hove, dirty rosy-yellow on cheeks and underparts, with pure white rimaries. The bare area round the eye, characteristic of the mother 7 . gymnopis), was well developed but instead of the blue tinge of . gymnopis it was a pronounced yellow colour. From the age of four r eeks the young hybrid began to utter peeping sounds, when six weeks Id it began to preen its plumage. Unfortunately, on 13th August, fter a short period of sickness the young cockatoo died of pneumonia, robably contracted during a stay of a few minutes outside the ouse, when having its photograph taken. The experiment of artificially rearing a cockatoo hybrid, despite le final negative result, has thus proved successful. The hybrid lived fty-nine days and it is probable that, in spite of an undoubtedly elicate constitution it might have been brought to complete maturity, he anatomical examination, however, showed that the skeleton of le young bird was rather weak, and therefore in future attempts reater attention must be paid to the supply of mineral components. The interbreeding of C. roseicapilla and C. gymnopis seems to indicate jiat the two species are more closely related to each other than has een assumed in the past.
algorithms.address: 44 c. AF ENEHJELM-THE BREEDING OF THE LITTLE OWL
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF THE LITTLE OWL
algorithms.bodyText: (.Athene noctua) By C. af Enehjelm (Helsingfors, Finland) In 1951 I got two specimens of the Little Owl from Germany. The birds were exactly similar in size so I had no idea as to the sex. In winter they were kept in a well-lighted indoor aviary about 10x4 feet and 8 feet high. They spent the summer in a compartment in our cages for small birds of prey. This compartment is 20 X 5 feet and 8 feet high with an adjoining open-fronted shelter 5X5 feet. The upper part is boarded about 3 feet downwards from the roof, giving the birds an undisturbed and well protected shelter. In the climate of Finland we are simply forced to take most birds--even our native ones-- inside for the winter, among other reasons, in order to prevent the soft food and meat from freezing as hard as a stone. The keeping ol birds and mammals in a climate like our's presents problems unknown to avicultural and zoological colleagues living in milder latitudes. We cannot release the birds into the outdoor aviaries too early in the spring, as experience has shown that, even if kept in only slightly warmed rooms, the birds are rather delicate if put outside in the early spring, even though the same specimens may stand quite low temperatures in late autumn without any ill effects. In 1952 and 1953 the Little Owls made no attempt to nest, but early in April, 1954, two white eggs were laid on the floor of the flight. On 2nd April, 1955, an egg was found on the floor of the flight. Without very high hopes I constructed a nest of brick on the floor of the flight and covered it with a piece of plywood kept in position with a brick. Inside I made a nest of some hay and put the newly-laid egg in the nest. Contrary to my expectations the nest was accepted and four more eggs laid in it. As far as I could see incubation started about 8th April On 6th May I observed some egg-shells in front of the nest and or removing the plywood cover saw some white, downy youngsters under the female. I was not able to find out whether all the eggs had hatched as I did not want to disturb the birds unnecessarily. Observation oi the birds was not easy as one of the parents, obviously the female, immediately disappeared into the nest when the room was entered. The old birds were not shy in a hysterical way, but were always on the watch for every movement ; they had obviously been caught wher full grown. When I looked into the nest a fortnight later I saw that al the eggs had hatched and the youngsters were obviously thriving well As far as I could see they were all the same size and I am under tht impression that incubation had started as soon as the eggs were laid 01 possibly at least most of them. On 6th June I saw three youngster. 1 popping round on the floor when I entered the room, but they al immediately disappeared into the nest. I entered the flight anc
algorithms.sectionHeader: C. AF ENEHJELM-THE BREEDING OF THE LITTLE OWL 45
algorithms.bodyText: emoved the cover of the nest and all five youngsters came out and vent running round the aviary, trying to fly without success. About a veek later, however, they were all sitting on their perches, 6-7 feet tigh, but for several days they rushed down to the nest whenever the 00m was entered. After yet another week they remained on their >erches or flew from perch to perch and I removed the nest. The amily was then moved to the outside flight, the young having first >een ringed with aluminium parrakeet rings. They are all thriving r ery well. When they left the nest the young were similar in colour to heir parents and are now quite indistinguishable, so I am glad I ringed hem in good time. As to food, the owls have mainly been fed on white mice, rats, and ;olden hamsters, very occasionally also with chickens, crows (the two ast named being cut into suitable pieces), and Budgerigar runners. r resh ants' eggs were scattered over the food. We breed a lot of lamsters as food for our small owls and birds of prey and they obviously eem to prefer them to other rodents. In my experience Little Owls are onsiderably easier to keep than many other small species, for instance, Tengmalm's and Passerine Owls. With exactly the same treatment the fengmalm's Owls are difficult to maintain for any length of time. They seem to thrive quite well for some time but suddenly sit on the ground and are usually dead within a day or two. I have never seen the Little Owls bathing, even if suitable facilities at least in my opinion) are always at their disposal. But they seem to njoy sitting outside in the rain and getting their feathers wet. As a summary : it seems that the eggs are laid at intervals of one lay and that incubation starts when the last or second last egg is laid, ncubation obviously lasts about four weeks. The youngsters leave the test (in captivity, at least) when about a month old and can fly quite veil a week later. After the nestling down there does not seem to be my intermediate colour in their first plumage, but the young immediately attain the colour of the old birds, a fact I have also >bserved when breeding Eagle-Owls. I regret that my observations are not more exact, but as this is the irst time I have bred this species I would not take any risks as I was mxious to get a complete success with the birds. Additional note .--In the winter 1955-56 I unfortunately lost the old len and one youngster and no attempts to breed were made by the emaining five birds in the spring of 1956.
algorithms.address: 46 J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS
algorithms.bodyText: By J. R. van Oosten (San Marino, California, U.S.A.) My adventures with birds started when I was born, but it took me until my fifteenth birthday to realize that fact. My father had always kept a large cage of African finches in the house and these always used to fascinate me. In 1941 we moved to California and, once settled here, he built an aviary which housed common finches and parrakeets. Right after the war years we built another aviary, smaller, which would enable us to house our finches separately. Then in 1948 I came across a copy of Aviculture and with that my adventures really began. In the issue was an article written by Mr. A. H. Isenberg on the breeding of some Alcippes. I promptly wrote him regarding softbills and where it might be possible to obtain some. His answer put me in contact with another grand gentleman, Mr. Ray Thomas, whom I met and had a chance first-hand to see my first softbills. Through both these men I learned how to keep and take care of these beautiful gems. I owe a great deal to them, for had it not been for their advice and assistance I might never have become interested in birds. In the early months of 1949, while driving back to Los Angeles, I stopped at a pet shop and purchased my first pair of softbills for the sum of 25 dollars--a pair of White-cheeked Bulbuls. Since that time one might say that I have become a " bird-nut ", for my love for birds grows more with each passing day and at present being only twenty-two I can look forward to many enjoyable years with birds. Besides the two above aviaries we now have three large ones for the various size softbills--large, medium, and small. The large-size aviary houses Toucans, Magpies, Jays, etc., and is planted with various bushes and small trees and includes an orange tree. It is 18 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 12 feet high with an added shelter on the outside, enclosed except for two windows and the front. The aviary for medium-sized softbills is 36 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 10 feet high with an adjoining shelter 21 feet long, 9 feet wide, and 7 feet high. The shelter is divided into two parts so that food may be placed in two separate places in order to eliminate fights. This aviary contains Jay-Thrushes, Jays, Thrushes, Barbets, Sibias, Starlings, Troupials, etc., and is likewise planted with bushes, small trees, and one orange tree. The last one is our " glass house " aviary for the small birds such as Tanagers, Sugar Birds, Redstarts, Bulbuls, etc. The house is 24 feet long, 12 feet wide, and 8 feet high with an adjoining flight 15 feet long, 12 feet wide, and 9 feet high. Both the house and the flight are planted with small bushes, vines, grasses, and a few small trees. Also in this aviary we built a two-tiered running waterfall which the birds seem to enjoy greatly as it draws many insects and bacteria. All the perches and swings in the three aviaries are dead
J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS

ree branches, which I feel helps to simulate natural surroundings as v r ell as making the aviary look more artistic. To-day one does not read very much about softbills so I decided to ^rite an article for the Magazine, giving some of my experiences dth the birds in my collection. It is further hoped that this may spur m other collectors of softbills to write on their birds as they may have witnessed things which would be of interest to other enthusiasts. The most outstanding event in my collection thus far was my Drtunate success in raising two hybrid Mynahs this year. Housed in he " glass house " were a beautiful pair of Grey-headed Mynahs vhich have been here for three years. While away at college the ten was lost and the cause of death not determined. In the same nclosure were also two pairs and an extra hen Pagoda Mynah which rave been here for six years. Early this year the male Grey-headed hose the odd female Pagoda as his mate. I had hopes that the two night breed and sure enough they did two months later. As both these >irds are well known to aviculture I see no reason for going into letails of their respective descriptions. It might be worth mentioning, lowever, that the females of both species are easy to sex. I have bund that the females are all a shade lighter than the males, and his is especially noticeable if the birds are in the sun or upon close nspection of three or more birds. The pair settled down and by April had chosen a redwood stained )arrakeet nest-box as their nesting site. The only materials used in )uilding were twigs and a few feathers. The material was slanted rom the opening down to the back with the eggs being laid in one :orner. As I was unable to be home all the time no accurate record vas kept. However, four eggs were laid and four young hatched by he middle of June. One youngster disappeared after four days and [ suspect that the male Scarlet Cock-of-the-Rock was responsible, ^oon after, four days later, another baby was found dead in the nest. The two remaining are now fully feathered and not dependent upon heir parents. The youngsters were fed my formula egg-food mixture, soaked ;urrants, all sorts of fruit--apple, grapes, tomato, pear, banana-- nilk sop, canned dog food, and Mockingbird food. The only live ood which was used was live fruit-flies which I propagate within the iviary by filling half-way a 5-lb. lard can with fruit rinds. I find that :here is no odour and hundreds of live flies, which all the birds love, ire produced. Both youngsters show very little colour beyond grey. The wings, oack, rump, and tail are a deep powder grey. Head, neck, chest, oelly, and vent are a very light powder grey, in which they resemble their father. The bill, feet, and eyes are also the same as their father's. There seem to be some black feathers coming on the crest of the

J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS head, as in the Pagoda, but only the next moult will show for sure Beyond this they show none of the colour or other characteristics 0 their mother. Their size is between the two, but this may change when they reach maturity. Needless to say, sexing is not yet possible although one seems a little brighter than the other. They have ai present all the antics of their father as they are always chirupping and running around in a never-ending search for bugs. I will write furthei on these two birds after they pass their first moult. Another unique nesting took place in the " glass house " by a pair of Pope Cardinals which each year for the last four years have main- tained two nests at the same time. Both birds have been seer entering the nests and at times neither one was seen, and upon my entering the " glass house " each would come out of a nest. They nested twice each year, during the spring and summer, and as yei have never reared a young one. This is due to the lack of mealworms , which are only fed during the winter months. They have never been observed catching or eating fruit-flies so this no doubt is where the trouble comes in. Unfortunately, I am not home so am unable tc feed the live food required ; however, I feel that both broods could be reared if the live food were supplied. There are always four eggs in each nest and four youngsters hatch. About two years ago my male White-cheeked Bulbul died of old age. The pair had been very devoted to each other, but as soon as the male was gone the hen promptly killed my female White-eared Bulbul and mated with the male. They had one nest each year, but the youngsters just vanished into thin air. They built the nests in a canary-type outside cage-nest. The nest was covered with palm leaves on the sides and the top, leaving the front open. The nests were constructed of dried grasses, twigs, and feathers, and lined with string and cotton. Two eggs were always laid and the hen sat close at all times ; she was fed by the male. This year no nest was built as the hen is rather old and cannot fly very well although she is in perfect condition. The White-eared male is a most devoted husband and sits with her most of the day and preens her feathers. He also hawks fruit-flies which he feeds her, as he seems to know that she is unable to fly very well. In the summer of 1954 while sitting in the aviary taking notes, all of a sudden I found the cause of the disappearing Bulbul youngsters. Hovering outside the nest like a Humming Bird the Scarlet Cock-of-the- Rock reached in with his beak and took one of the young. He then flew to a perch where he struck it a few times and then swallowed it whole. Needless to say, the babies were not more than a few days old. Had I not seen it then and again on other occasions I would never have believed it. The guilty party was believed to be a male Orange-headed Ground Thrush. Because of lack of space I was unable
J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS

) remove the bird and was therefore unable to raise any young, 'hese young could have proved to be a very interesting hybrid but nfortunately I shall never know. Also within this aviary are housed a pair of Button Quail, and fter two nests, young all reared, the babies began to disappear. feel certain that the same bird is responsible ; however, he never others the White-eyes or Yuhinas which sleep near him at night. 4 rs. Erlanger some years ago had babies from Cocks-of-the-Rock nd she fed them baby mice. It is very possible that breeding these wely birds might be achieved by feeding some of the larger live )od, such as baby mice and rats. Another attempted nesting took place this summer but met with lilure. The pair consisted of a male Orange-headed Ground Thrush nd a female White-throated Ground Thrush, both birds had been nported from India in 1950. Up till two years ago I only suspected he sex, but I could not be sure. The female Orange-headed had to e placed in the medium-sized softbill aviary for fear that the male /ould kill her. However, the White-throated was left in as he took o notice of her. The male was much deeper in colour than the female nd was heard singing on a few occasions. This year there was no oubt that they were a pair as one egg was laid and sat on for five ays before it was broken. During this time the male was never more lan 5 feet away from the nest and any bird coming too close was at once hased off. I have found these birds to be very nervous and no doubt his caused the failure because if anyone came to the aviary the imale would leave the nest. The nest was built 4 feet off the ground 1 the right-hand front corner of the aviary in a small, but thick, pruce tree. The tree was right behind the waterfall and could not e seen from outside the aviary even though the nest was 2 feet from he wire. The nest itself reminded one strongly of a dove's nest, lthough it had a sort of a mud plaster holding the bottom together. Jpon closer inspection I noticed that twigs had been laid between wo branches, then some twigs placed in the opposite direction and overed with mud. The nest was roughly lined with grass and a few iaves. No further attempt was made by these birds, although both /ere seen carrying twigs on several occasions. I have found that both these birds are very friendly towards other irds. At present there is an English Robin in with them and they ake no notice of him. Also a pair of White-capped Redstarts had >een kept in the same cage and not once had the Ground Thrushes een seen chasing them or even paying them any heed. This also olds true for a female Rainbow Bunting that always seems to get he fruit-fly just at the moment the Orange-headed is reaching for it. dso at one time a Shama Thrush had been in the same aviary with he same good results. One day by accident my father turned loose
algorithms.sectionHeader: 50 KENNETH A. WYATT-BREEDING LOVEBIRDS IN CALIFORNIA
algorithms.bodyText: a male Kashmir Blue Thrush and the Ground Thrushes wasted n time in trying to get a hold of him and do him in. He was take out before any harm could come of it. Next number I will relate an almost successful attempt by a pair " Black-chinned Yuhinas to rear some young, and of some of the othf birds which are housed in my collection. I will tell how my birc have been fed, which I feel has attributed to some of my very goo fortune. And last I will give descriptions of some birds which ha\ been imported from South America but about which I can find n mention in books or the back issues of this Magazine.
algorithms.table: [To be continued) * * * BREEDING LOVEBIRDS IN CALIFORNIA By Kenneth A. Wyatt (Torrance, California, U.S.A.) Having read in your Magazine of the difficulty in raising lovebin in England, I would like to write about the very good luck I have ha
algorithms.bodyText: in breeding them. In December, 1955, I finished an aviary 20 feet Ion. 10 feet high, and 8 feet wide. By March, 1956, I had acquired foi pairs of Peach-faced, two pairs of Masked, and three pairs of Fischer' and put them all into this one big aviary. With plenty of nest-box' I had very little, if any, fighting, and have not bred a hybrid in tl aviary. On 1st September, 1956, I took the boxes down for a thre< month rest, and at that date had reared forty-one lovebirds, twent' four Peach-faced, four blue Masked, seven Masked, and six Fischer' I got a little impatient and put the nest-boxes in early, and to-da (6th January, 1957) I have seven baby Fischer's flying along wit two blue Masked the Fischer's reared with their own. In the ne I have three Masked, three blue Masked, and two Peach-faced tv> weeks old. Also two nests of Peach-faced, five eggs in each box, a fertile, due to hatch any day, also one other pair of blue Maske due to hatch in about a week. The only trouble I have had is whe the young come out of the nest the Peach-faced like to bite tl youngsters' feet causing them much trouble but not injuring them. The winter here in southern California has been very mild, mar days being in the 8o's and nights in the 50's, with only about tv rainy days in December and January so far. In this wonderful clima the raising of these lovebirds is not rare or out of the ordinary, f< many of my friends have done as well and some better, and I tal none of the credit. The birds just love it here and will fill one
algorithms.sectionHeader: DAVID M. WEST-BREEDING HYBRID BROWN'S X YELLOW ROSELLAS 5 1
algorithms.bodyText: iary if one just gives them a little care. Other than millet and nflower seed I give them soaked bread, pyracantha berries, corn l the cob, apple, grass seeds of all kinds, and lots of lettuce and indelion.

By David M. West (Montebello, Calif., U.S.A.) Last year one of the more interesting breeding successes was the aring of four young hybrid Brown's x Yellow Rosella {P. flaveolus). Last fall I finally despaired of obtaining proper mates for the male rown's and the female Yellow Rosella, so it was decided to put the vo birds together and attempt to produce some hybrids. From the iry first minute of introduction the two birds agreed, despite the Terence in size between the smaller Brown's Rosella and the larger male Yellow Rosella. Formerly, when paired to a female Brown's, Le cock was quite given to driving his mate about, but he did not intinue this practice with the Yellow Rosella hen. Apparently sr greater size impressed him, and he made his advances to her ith the greatest of care. During March the pair were frequently seen feeding and the )ck Brown's displayed to his mate almost every morning. Two large sst-boxes were put up about the middle of March and the pair were ten seen visiting the boxes after this. By April it was apparent that le hen was most seriously interested in the smaller of the two boxes, ad much of the sawdust and wood chips were being ejected by her. 1 late April the pair were observed mating, and shortly after that le hen disappeared into the box. No investigation was made during incubation ; as the hen would [ways tumble back into the box upon seeing anyone approaching, he first opportunity to investigate the contents of the nest-box was a 16th May, when the temperature was well over ioo degrees and le hen was off the box. The nest was observed to contain four nice oungsters that were probably just five or six days old, and very bsely intertwined. During the period the young were in the box both parents fed lem, and the male was frequently observed to enter the box to do is fair share. The usual grains, fruit, and extras in the form of greens r ere given and both parents spent large amounts of time caring for the rowing family. The first two youngsters left the nest when about five weeks old.
algorithms.sectionHeader: SYDNEY PORTER-THE STORY OF A CROSSOPTILON
algorithms.bodyText: They were excellent fliers and very steady. The second two youngsters left the nest two days later, and they too were steady and quite tame. Before the second two left the nest the mother had laid again, and is now incubating. As this cross has not, apparently, been achieved before, a short description of the youngsters may be of interest. They are best described as almost completely resembling their mother--being quite identical in coloration with her save for the fact that they have pale orange under tail-coverts where the true Yellow Rosella has pale yellow under tail-coverts. There are also a few pale orange feathers on their breasts--but otherwise they are closely akin to young Yellow Rosellas. This similarity to the mother is rather surprising, for I had rather thought that they would resemble a combination of the two parents which are quite different from each other. Still, crosses between the widely different Pennant's X Barnard's result in young that are so nearly pure Barnard's in appearance that only an expert would be able to tell the difference. Eventually I anticipate breeding the young male hybrids back to their Yellow Rosella mother, and see if the resultant young are not good enough to try and re-establish the Yellow Rosella in my collec- tion for new imports are out of the question, and the Yellow Rosella is very scarce in the U.S.A.
algorithms.figure: * * * THE STORY OF A BLUE CROSSOPTILON By Sydney Porter (Derby, England) " Emma " should not have been at all ! " He " and his sister were
algorithms.bodyText: a kind of baksheesh, as my own life has become after being saved by the drug " Cortisone ". Towards the end of a very long illness, my kind friend Fred Logan (who came to my rescue when the person who was looking after my collection suddenly disappeared, with the result of the loss of nearly half the birds) set a quantity of pheasant eggs. These all duly hatched, were reared, and most of them given to friends. However, there were five eggs left over, we did not know of what species they were or how old. Mr. Logan went to a good deal of trouble, as it was then late in the season to get a broody bantam. At that time I was well enough to do a few chores connected with the birds and one was to see after the bantam hen. The chicks from the first lot of eggs were now quite large. From their earliest chickenhood, with the aid of the gardener, we moved their pens to fresh ground every day . . . but, Oh ! . . . the damage the young Crossoptilons did to my nice smooth lawns ! In fact they have not recovered yet.
algorithms.sectionHeader: SYDNEY PORTER-THE STORY OF A CROSSOPTILON
algorithms.bodyText: Crossoptilons, being mainly root feeders, dig for their living, and row those chicks dug ! At the end of each day there were dozens of loles in the sward into each of which one could put a tennis ball. Every evening the bantam was taken off the eggs, but she was in >uch a state of broodiness that she used to rush back on to them as soon is she was lifted off. To stop this the grille in front of the coop was placed back until she had finished feeding. One day the housekeeper came to say that there was a long-distance :all on the telephone. Now the aviaries are at the bottom end of a small Drchard and quite a distance from the house. By the time I had heard most of the " birdy " gossip from London the hen and the eggs had been clean forgotten. Next day, about 6 p.m., the hen was seen sitting disconsolately before the grille and the eggs stone cold after twenty- four hours' exposure on a rather cold day and night. Not wanting anyone to realize what a fool I had been, I decided to let the hen sit out the allotted span and then throw the eggs away, saying they must have been stale and had not germinated. Ten days after the normal incubation period I thought it would be better to smash one of the eggs to see if they really were bad. The egg was flung with much force on to the hard gravel, but nothing happened. The process was then repeated with much more vigour, this time the shell cracked and blood poured out and a faint cheeping was heard ; on picking up the damaged egg a tiny beak was seen apparently gasping its last. Believing in the old adage " while there's life there's hope ", the much-damaged egg was put back under the hen. The next day the shell had disappeared and running about at lightning speed was a beautiful little Crossoptilon chick. I believe the Chinese name " Manchee " means the bird that can run faster than a horse. I can guarantee that no one on foot could ever be able to overtake one of these birds. The next day another little chick was seen, but alas, just as the grille was being lowered between the coop and the run it shot out from under the hen into the run, the grille fell on the bird's neck and after a few convulsive struggles the tiny body flopped over, became limp, and appeared to breathe its last. Being in a hurry I left the body until later in the day, but when I came to the birds again it wasn't there and the next day two very lively chicks were seen running about the pen. 1 hey flourished exceedingly, until they were too big for the run and were then put with their older brothers and sisters, who chivvied them around with their mock fights and kept them from the food dishes. The two poor twins started to grow listless and mope, they became dejected and ill so, having nowhere to put them, I set them free in the orchard. At first they hung about the birdroom, looking for scraps of food and odd mealworms which managed to get out of the breeding box. In the course of time they grew much better, due to feeding on
algorithms.sectionHeader: SYDNEY PORTER-THE STORY OF A CROSSOPTILON
algorithms.bodyText: all manner of things, grass in particular, and, to my sorrow, rare bult species which they dug out of the rockeries. Gradually the menu was extended to include all manner of things, raspberries, alpine straw- berries (Frais du bois ), insects ; they played havoc with the lettuce bee in the kitchen garden, and all the time they dug everywhere, but meal- worms proved the factor which rendered them tamer than domestic poultry. Used properly, mealworms will tame almost any bird. The larger of the two we called " Emma ", in remembrance of a female given to me many years ago by Mr. Delacour, a bird of great character However, " Emma " turned out to be a male and his mate a female The latter was always shyer than her brother, in fact when first let oul she was very wild and, indeed, I often thought she would fly away, in fact she once did, but we got her back again. It is useless to pinior these birds when chicks, for besides their swiftness they are remarkable for their jumping propensities, they can easily leap on to a 8 or 9 ft fence or shed. And it's next to impossible to catch a Crossoptilon when once thoroughly frightened unless it is cornered, and it is never wise to handle them, for no bird loses its feathers so quickly. When one oj these birds has lost its confidence in humans only complete incarcera- tion will keep it from flying or running away. For a long time after the male became so tame the female stayed in the background. " Emma " always thought of me as another Cros- soptilon and, in the manner of his species, he talked to me all the time I was around. A better scientific name for the species would be C. garrulax ! All the time these birds are together they hold long con- versations with each other. Beebe mentions this in his study of the birds in their native state. In time I learned quite a bit of their language and what a rather loud, snake-like hiss, which is very seldom heard in captivity, means, which is " I am not annoyed but I don't like what you are doing ". The pair would go every day to their parents' aviary and spend many hours conversing with them. " Emma " seems to have a great aversion to the glass vessels which are used for the nectar- feeding birds, these he will take up when they are being collected or being washed and will deliberately break them one by one. Why he does this I can never make out. He would jump on to my knee if I was sitting down and let me handle any part of him, but he usually hissed when I touched his tail, though he did not move away. The tail of the Blue Crossoptilon is remarkable in that it is composed of twenty-four feathers, which is more than that of most other birds except the Bulwer's Pheasant. The central feathers are from 18 to 24 inches long and the ends curve downwards, the webs are very disintegrated and are like long fine hairs and in old birds are 8 to 1 o inches long and when used in the plumage trade are known as " glycerined ostrich feathers ". The outer tail feathers are normal, the lower half being white and the end half being iridescent
algorithms.sectionHeader: SYDNEY PORTER-THE STORY OF A GROSSOPTILON 55
algorithms.bodyText: teel-blue. The outer and middle tail feathers gradually integrate one vith another, in a manner difficult to explain. One unfortunate thing about the Crossoptilons is that they are very )rone to feather biting, not of their own plumage but that of their nates. As they usually roost together, head to tail, they indulge in a dnd of feather-biting competition, which soon renders their nether egions a very unsightly mess. I keep the hen separate from the cock, except during the breeding season, this seems to be the only way of ceeping their plumage perfect. On the whole the birds are very good tempered, except with other pecies of pheasants, which they will immediately start to kill. Even if me catches the victim in time the aggressors will continue their ittacks by jumping up and pecking it when one is carrying it out of the iviary. With all other species I have found them perfectly safe, though hey will not stand any interference from any bird. One pair share an iviary with a pair of Choughs and when these were first placed with he Crossoptilons they commenced, in the usual crow-like way, to ;ease and play jokes on their companions ; they very soon put the Choughs in their place and woe betide them if they ever try any tricks :hese days. Strange to say, these two species are also companions in the high and remote regions which is their native habitat, at from 10,000 to 16,000 feet. Amongst themselves they are very peaceful, except when yDung they indulge in a great deal of mock fighting, perhaps more so than any other pheasant, but when they have got rid of their youthful inhibitions no bird could be less aggressive ; in a wild state they are highly gregarious. Feather biting is even worse in the Brown species and one rarely sees one of these birds whose feathers are not completely ruined by this unfortunate habit. Of course, if one has a big enough estate the best thing is to have them loose, like domestic fowls ; they will stay around the house, but are apt on occasions to wander, though if left alone they always come back, but the sight of so strange a bird as a Crossoptilon is sure to cause a hue and cry and the poor bird is so chivvied and chased by both humans and dogs that it loses its sense of direction as in the end it is chased further and further away from its home. Another thing, with keeping the birds at liberty they are certainly not a gardener's friend and, leaving rare bulbs, etc., aside, they are apt to think that one's kitchen garden produce is grown solely for them and, in the end, one has to resort to the local greengrocer for one's vegetables. If one does not mind all this, one will have delightfully tame and intelligent pets which are also feather perfect, and a feather perfect and tame Crossoptilon is a very beautiful creature. It seems a pity that these extremely interesting birds, which look like meeting with extinction in the near future (in fact, the Brown species
algorithms.sectionHeader: SYDNEY PORTER-THE STORY OF A CROSSOPTILON
algorithms.bodyText: is thought to have become almost extinct through killing and deforesta- tion in its native haunts on the mountains of Shansi and Chihli, ir North-western China) are not more widely kept and bred, for no birds are easier to rear than these. One wonders what will happen to the genus Crossoptilon now that Tibet, Szechuan, Yunnan, Shansi, Kokonor, and Kansu, the home of these birds, have been " liberated ", as the Communists call their occupation, from the domination o Buddhism, a gentle and enlightened religion which teaches the sanctity of all life. One wonders too, what will happen to the other splendid pheasants, of which we know so little, which inhabit those lofty regions, the Chinese and Sclater's Monal's (I consider mysell very lucky to have seen living specimens of the former, one of the mosl magnificent of pheasants, when in China in 1936, being one of the very few Europeans to have done so. These birds were later shipped tc Europe but died en route), the Tragopans, the Koklass, and the uniquely coloured Blood Pheasants (of which it seems less than ten individuals have ever reached Europe and of which thirteen sub-species are known), not to mention various other species. After reading the late Hachisuka's recently published book on the extinct birds of the Mascarene Islands, in which we read " nc other part of the world . . . contained such an extraordinary avi- fauna . . . and nowhere was the destruction more rapid or complete ' one contemplates on the question, if Buddhists had discovered these fair islands would we not have with us to-day all those many and fantastic forms of avian life, which were so swiftly swept to oblivion after the discovery and occupation by the Portuguese, Dutch, French, and English, and which for untold aeons of time had known no enemies until so-called Christian Man came on the scene. Forty-seven species were exterminated, including a huge 6 ft. high, white and red water-hen, the giant black Ground Parrots and, amongst others, the very Dodo itself. There may have been other species, we shall nevei know, for all we have to tell us of those exterminated are an odd stuffed specimen or two, a few bones and skeletons, notes in ancient manu- scripts, or mention in some aged tomes on travel written by those whe visited those far distant isles, the reading of which leaves the bird- loving ornithologist sick at heart at the sadistic ways of mankind. Sad to say, the same story is being enacted all over the world to-day, ir spite of the endeavours of those who try to preserve our great heritage. To get back to Crossoptilons, when in California a few years age I saw hybrids between the White and Blue species. In shape they were exactly like the Blue, which is different to that of the White. These birds were most beautiful and attractive, being of a pale lavender blue. I do not know if any of them are left as I understand that Mr. Gibson, on whose ranch I saw them, has disposed of all his vast collection ol birds. As mentioned before, it is not known if the Brown Crossoptilor
algorithms.sectionHeader: SYDNEY PORTER-THE STORY OF A CROSSOPTILON
algorithms.bodyText: till exists in its natural habitat, which was the western mountain anges of Shansi and Chilli, in China, most parts of which have become Tactically desert regions with the continual deforestation and absequent erosion. It seems to have been introduced into Europe early a hundred years ago and since then few wild specimens have cached us. The breed is therefore very inbred, which accounts for the yw fertility of the eggs. To save this bird it seems that it will be ecessary to cross it with the Blue to ensure fresh and stronger blood nd then breed back again to the pure Brown. Though a free breeder Ten it first arrived here, it is becoming very much rarer in captivity wing to the cause mentioned above and everything should be done ) save the species while there is yet time. As to the White Crossoptilons, very few Europeans have ever seen rese in their native haunts, as they live in probably the most inaccessible nd remote parts of the world and which, no doubt, will always remain ) owing to the difficulty of any transport ever reaching there. Their abitat is in the high Eastern Himalayas, in that part of the world Tere Tibet, Burma, and China meet. We are told they range from 0,000 to 16,000 feet and upwards. The existence of these birds has een perpetuated by the influence of the kindly Buddhist monks, whose imastries are situated in those lofty and distant regions. I was )rtunate enough to see some of these wonderful birds whilst in California, where a few were sent in 1936. Unfortunately they are not rolific like their congenitors and very few are bred. These lovely irds are snow-white, their immaculate plumage being set off by the :arlet face and legs and the brilliant, iridescent, purple-blue tail athers. The story of how the first Blue Crossoptilons were procured 1 1929 and of how they were first carried in baskets by coolies, then on le backs of donkeys, and finally by river boat during a journey of ver six months' duration from Kansu, in the far interior of China, weral thousand miles to Shanghai, is told by Herr Hampe and uoted by Mr. Jean Delacour in his fine book The Pheasants of the World , nd makes fascinating reading.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 5 $ EDWARD J. BOOSEY-BLUE RINGNEGK PARRAKEETS BLUE RINGNECK PARRAKEETS AND A " PIED 55 RINGNECK
algorithms.bodyText: By Edward J. Boosey (Keston, Kent, England) I thought the accompanying photograph of the brood of five young Blue Ringneck Parrakeets bred here at the Keston Foreign Bird Farm during the 1956 season might be of interest. They are the progeny of the late Duke of Bedford's famous original breeding pair of these birds, which came to Keston on his death and have since reared ten young ones in all--one in 1954 j four in 1955 > amd five in 195E Incidentally, their latest brood is, in my experience, just one more than Ringnecks generally produce--their broods usually consisting of threes and fours. When one takes into consideration the fact that they had already reared numerous young ones at Woburn before they came to us, it will be seen that, in sharp and refreshing contrast to most rare and beautiful colour " sports " they are a truly wonderful breeding pair, even judged by normal standards. Nor is this the only respect in which they are remarkable, for the attitude of the sexes one to the other is in their case reversed. Usually, of course, with Ringnecks, it is the hen who " wears the trousers " and is often very snappy and short-tempered with the cock, except when she is actually in breeding condition. With these two, however, the position is exactly the opposite, the cock being at all times the master and lunging at his wife should she attempt to sit too close to him, and I have even seen him do this during the breeding season, though a few moments before he had been feeding her as she put her head out of the nest-box. It may be remembered that the late Duke referred to him as a bird of funny and uncertain temper and thought he might eventually need careful watching with his newly fledged family, although I must say I have always found him entirely exemplary in this respect and a model parent in every way. Altogether he adopts a typically mid-Victorian attitude towards his wife, but in extenuation it must be said that the number of their offspring is comparatively quite up to mid-Victorian standards, too ! I only wish the accompanying photograph could be in colour, and for those who may never have seen a Blue Ringneck I would add that they are extremely beautiful birds of a soft yet rich shade of powder blue which, in the cock, is particularly vivid on the crown and fore- head and which makes a lovely colour contrast to the coral red oi the bill. While on the subject of Ringnecks, I think a short account of a very unusual and colourful Ringneck " sport " we have might be 0: interest, as it is the only one of its kind I have ever seen. It wa^ discovered in one of the London bird shops by our General Manager

S. T. JOHNSTONE-195^ BREEDING SEASON AT THE WILDFOWL TRUST 59 vlr. Cummings, and I would call it a pied Ringneck, as its appearance 3 somewhat reminiscent of a green and yellow pied or harlequin ludgerigar. It is not an easy bird to describe but I hope the following may give, my way, a rough idea of its general appearance. It is a cock and is in :very other respect a normal green, except for the large areas of bright r ellow in its plumage and the fact that the two central tail feathers are >articularly blue, being only faintly tinged with green, while the outer >nes are mainly yellow. The usual black and pink neck-rings are >resent, as is the area of bluish-mauve at the back of the head, but on he head itself there is some yellow in the region of the forehead. The nantle and the flight feathers are pure bright yellow, while the upper >reast is yellow of a rather paler shade merging into green on the lower >reast and belly. It is a great pity that, with the Ringneck family, the breeding of olour varieties is such a very long-winded process, but I suppose the ventual hopes from this bird would be that, about a decade hence, t might be the ancestor of evenly marked pieds and normal-eyed ellows--as opposed to pink-eyed lutinos. I only wish the present state >f the world was stable enough to allow one to hope that such long- erm projects had a reasonable prospect of eventual fruition. Unlike in the days of my youth--planning ahead seems, nowadays, he essence of folly--nevertheless, I cheerfully go on doing it !
algorithms.equation: * * * THE 1956 BREEDING SEASON AT THE WILDFOWL TRUST
algorithms.bodyText: By S. T. Johnstone (Slimbridge, Glos., England) During the past spring and summer the weather can, with justifica- ion, be blamed for considerable losses amongst our young birds. Continuous rain and cold in June and July caused havoc, particularly vith the ducklings. One recalls two heart breaking weeks in June when >ver a hundred babies were lost from chilling and allied troubles. Nevertheless, it was a pleasant surprise when figures were assessed at he end of the season to find that we had had our best breeding season n the ten years that the Trust has been established. The figures are is follows :--* No. of species No. of kinds No. of No. of No. of breeding. reared. cygnets. goslings, ducklings. Total. 86 67 5 171 326 502 Me have had our most successful season with the Hawaiian Geese, hxty-two eggs were laid, of which twenty-two were fertile. Of the
algorithms.footnote: 6o S. T. JOHNSTONE-1 956 BREEDING SEASON AT THE WILDFOWL TRUST .
algorithms.bodyText: sixteen that hatched fifteen were reared, and a further three wen reared from a pair under the care of Mr. Terry Jones, at Leckford. Cuban Whistling Duck ( Dendrocygna arborea), Wandering Whistling Duck ( Dendrocygna arcuata arcuata), Magpie Goose ( Anseranas semi- palmata ), Bewick's Swan (Cygnus columbianus bewickii), Lesser Scauj (.Aythya affinis), Comb Duck ( Sarkidiornis melanotos) and the Soutl American Comb Duck ( Sarkidiornis melanotos carunclatus) , Commor Golden-eye ( Buecephala clangula clangula ), Goosander (Mergus merganser merganser ), were reared for the first time at Slimbridge, indeed, the Iasi seven kinds, we believe, for the first time in England. Some notes on the Bewick's swans have already been given. Of th( rest, by far the most interesting is the breeding of the Magpie Goose We have in our collection a pair imported from Sydney in 1949 and ar old female which has been in this country since pre-war days. They an kept in our Wood pen along with a pair of Black Swans, Whistling Ducks, and Muscovys. There is a 4 ft. privet hedge bounding th< pen on one side and it was in this that in 1955 a male was found to b< making the rudiments of a nest. The activity was soon abandonee and when a similar occurrence took place this year we were not unduh elated. However, some days later the old female joined the male ir building a second nest on the ground, some two or three yards from th< original site, composed of twigs, straw, and nettles, very like that of i swan in design. In the course of the next four weeks a further fiv" nests were built in the nettles at the back of the pen and during th* last week the female was seen to be getting very heavy. On 15th Augus she was sitting on the latest nest. When approached she emitted < high-pitched scream and the male came striding to her assistance. Botl birds stood on the nest with tails in the air, heads lowered, and wing outspread and one could see the first roundish white egg had been laid During the next twelve days a further seven eggs were laid. They hac roughish shells and were dead white in colour. The average size beim 73 X 56 mm. and weight 115-3 gm. As the eggs were laid they wen replaced by dummies and when the clutch was completed two rea eggs were left in the nest for a few days after incubation commenced It was found that both birds shared in the sitting and that the egg were never left. The two eggs were removed and added to those tha had been placed under the broody bantam. For the rest of the incuba tion period, when the broodies were being fed and exercised, the egg were kept warm by use of a spare bantam. An incubation period c around thirty-five days was expected and it was with some surpris 1 that we found the first egg chipped after twenty-seven days. Fiv goslings hatched on the 28th day, the other three eggs being infertile The downy young are striking little things, quite unlike those of an' other of the Anatidae. The head and neck are a cinnamon red reminiscent of the male Red-crested Pochard. The body is a dar

S. T. JOHNSTONE- 1 956 BREEDING SEASON AT THE WILDFOWL TRUST 6 I rey above, with an absence of barring, and the under parts a pale rey. The bill, yellow in colour, is large and powerful, the nail being articularly prominent, and the lores are bare. The toes are very large 1 proportion to the rest of the gosling and the yellow tarsus is very :urdy. These babies were very aggressive to each other and had great ecking matches as soon as they were able to stand. The diet con- sted of soaked biscuit-meal with a 25 per cent protein content, lentiful supplies of duckweek, chopped plantain, grass, and lettuce, "hey were given quantities of fresh-water shrimps and these they pre- 'rred to all else. When food was given to them they would emit a high- itched sibilant call, similar to that of passerine nestlings at the pproach of the parent bird. Feathering commenced at twenty-five ays and at the same time the bill began to turn black. The down was )st completely at six weeks and the adolescent plumage was a black ead and neck, mantle, and upper parts, except for a white rump, ath the under parts and breast shaded from pale grey to white. The yes do not as yet give the impression of being so far round on to the ontal aspect of the head as in the parent birds and one is not conscious f their use of binocular vision as in the adults. The forehead is not yet are and the characteristic bump not yet developed. A South American Comb Duck bred at New Grounds in 1955 ut lost its brood within two days. In 1956 three South American Comb )uck and one of the Old World race nested. In each case the eggs r ere laid in little grape barrels that had been sited some two or three :et above the ground in willow trees. The incubation period was lirty-one days for both forms. The creamy white eggs had a thin, liny shell and the average size for twenty-five specimens was 7x37 mm. and average weight 44 gm. The ducklings are obviously near relations of the Muscovy as igards shape and dual colouring of the tarsus. The downy pattern as cap, back of the neck, and upper parts of the body brown, the ings and body being barred with yellow. There was a brown eye- ripe and the throat, breast, and under parts were yellow. The first hatching did not thrive at all and showed little inclination ) feed. They soon succumbed in the cold, wet weather. The use of ifra-red lamps had a very favourable effect on subsequent broods, he ducklings showed great interest in life, ate well and, apart from one r two weaklings, grew rapidly.
algorithms.sectionHeader: GERNER PETERSEN-BREEDING THE SENEGAL PARROT BREEDING THE SENEGAL PARROT
algorithms.bodyText: (.Poicephalus senegalus) By Gerner Petersen (Glostrup, Denmark) (Reprinted, by kind permission, from Stuekultur , March and April nos., 1956. Translated by Paul Hansen.) In December, 1951, I bought two Senegal Parrots, which later turned out to be two cocks ; one died in September, 1953, but the following day I was lucky enough to be able to buy a female. When I placed it with the cock they immediately showed great interest, and were very pleased with each other. In the summer of 1954 the pair was placed in an outside aviary with a nest-box, which seemed to interest them but, apparently on account of too much disturbance from the other birds in the aviary, they did not show any signs of breeding. In spring, 1955, we tried again, this time indoors (in my bedroom, which faces north), in a parrot cage measuring 44 cm. by 44 cm. with a height of 60 cm., and with a nest-box measuring 25 cm. by 25 cm. and 35 cm. in height placed outside on the cage, which was put against a warm chimney. On the 17th March the first egg appeared and, with a day between each, in all four were laid ; one of them, however, was destroyed. On the 15th April the first sounds of young were heard from the nest-box, and examination showed two youngsters, but one died on the 20th April and the other on the 27th. In the summer of 1955 I tried again in the garden aviary, also without any results on account of disturbances. In October, 1955, the birds again were placed indoors in the parrot cage with the nest- box on the outside. The birds were mating and were apparently in very fine condition. The first egg was laid on the 2nd January, 1956, and three in all appeared. During the whole period of incubation both the parents spent the time in the nest, only one at the time coming out for feeding. The 27th January sounds were heard from two youngsters ; one of them, however, died on the 2nd February, though the other was thriving very well. As soon as the hen left the nest, which at first she only did in order to relieve herself, the youngster kept up a continual noise until she came back. During the first four weeks the cock was feeding both the young and the hen. The young had quite white down. As rearing food I used sprouted seed in a mixture of sunflower seed, hemp, canary, white and golden millet, and dry seed in the same mixture ; in addition, plenty of millet and apples. In the bottom of the nest-box w peat-moss. s prays, hard-boiled egg, placed 3 cm. of damp
algorithms.table: Avic. Mag. 1957. Copyright ] Senegal Parrots and Young in Cage. [Mortensen m Copyright ] [Mortensen Young Senegal Parrot. To face p. 62
algorithms.bodyText: When the youngster was five weeks old the feathers started to grow, first on the head, afterwards on the wings and the tail, and lastly on the body. The eyes were very dark, but at approximately ten weeks the yellow rings started to show very faintly, but at the time of writing (April, 1956) are not yet very colourful. The first feathers were very dull in colour, but when the young left the nest, at nine weeks old, it was fully feathered and the colours most beautiful and clear like the colours of the parents. Before it left the nest the parents had been calling for it for some time, enticing it to take the great step out in the world, but it never went further than looking out of the nest-hole, and here it was fed. It was very early in the morning on the 30th March when it finally came out ; at first it was very unsteady on the feet, but the unsteadiness very soon left it altogether. Gradually the hen seemed less and less interested in the young, leaving the cock to do all the feeding, at which he was very good. Since ten weeks old it has been feeding for itself, occasionally still begging a little from the cock. The youngster, which is a little bigger than its parents, with a comparatively smaller head and beak, looks very promising, is sound and in fine condition, and starts every day with a good bath in the bird-bath attached to the cage. I have had it in my hand a couple of times ; it is very quiet and does not try to bite.
algorithms.table: * * * BREEDING THE CRIMSON-WINGED PARRAKEET IN CALIFORNIA IN 1956 By David M. West (Montebello, California, U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: This lovely Australian psittacine has never been too easy to breed here in California. The result is that they have always been scarce, and the breeding records not too numerous. In recent years the San Diego Zoo has had several successful breedings, but in private collections the only recent result that comes to mind is that of G. Rayson Brown's 1955 success with two young reared. My own two pairs have had a four-year record of every possible vagary. They have laid every year, but sometimes they refused to incubate, other times have laid from the perch, smashed the eggs, deserted them, etc. It was, therefore, without much optimism that I greeted the current breeding season. This season (1956) both pairs appear to have turned over a new leaf. To be sure both males continued driving and heckling their mates, but every now and again they would stop long enough to feed them ! The hens, apparently anxious to justify their long non-

productive sojourn in the collection, responded by beginning actual nesting operations six weeks earlier than in any former year. By 2nd March both hens had disappeared from sight, and sat very steadily until 24th March when young could be plainly heard. As the nest-boxes were placed very high, and a small ladder would have been needed to make an inspection, none was made. The usual grandfather-clock nest was used, the bottom being filled with wood chips and sawdust. From the time the youngsters hatched until they emerged from the nest, some five weeks later, the parents were perfect in every way and gave me no worry whatsoever. Large amounts of food were consumed, and during the first few weeks I was regularly carrying in three bucket- fuls of poa annua to each pair daily. In addition, each pair were fed canned corn that had been washed and rinsed in clear water before being given to the parents. Of this they were terribly fond, and each pair ate a small can of it daily. Both males fed their respective hens assiduously, and after about two weeks the hens began to spend longer periods away from the young. The males were only very rarely seen actually to enter the box, and then rather hesitantly. The first youngster appeared on about the thirty-fifth day and looked smaller and duller than the mother. The others followed within a few days, and were active and good flyers from the first. Some of the youngsters have more red on the wing than others, but this is apparently not a good or valid indication of sex. One of the adult hens has much more red on the wing than the other hen. The male parents have proved to be very tolerant of their off- spring, and have not driven them about. This is in contrast to some other species, as the Red-rump for example, which will sometimes attack the youngsters if a second nest is planned. The aviary of the first pair was 18 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 9 feet high. The second pair were in an aviary about 24 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 9 feet high. Both nest-boxes were hung under shelters, and were filled with rough wood chips. In addition to the usual dry seed mixture, seed was thrown on the dirt floors to sprout, and soft food such as soaked bread, oats, etc., was also provided. Naturally, large amounts of greens were provided, and fruit, such as orange, apple, and fresh corn on the cob also provided, and relished. I am very pleased to report this success, because Crimson-wings are a little difficult to rear, and it has given me a great deal of pleasure to be fortunate enough to rear some this year after four years of negative results. The first pair reared two, and the second pair reared two more. Both pairs nested a second time--but one pair deserted their nest during a heat wave in May. The other pair successfully reared two more--thus making a total of six reared for the year.
algorithms.sectionHeader: HYLTON BLYTHE-A FEEDING METHOD FOR BREEDING FINCHES 65 A. FEEDING METHOD FOR BREEDING FINCHES
algorithms.bodyText: By Hylton Blythe (Thorpe Bay, Essex, England) For some years I have realized that breeding pairs of finches, both British and foreign need more nutrition than is available in hard seed. If necessary proteins and vitamins are absent in the spring diet the eggs will be too poor in quality to sustain life until the chicks can be fed by the parent birds, resulting in " dead in shell Then, if the regurgitated food is lacking in essentials, chicks will fade out after a few days. In addition to the usual seeds and greenfood a soft food seems to be the answer and after several years of unscientific experiments starting from bread-and-milk, I evolved a food last year which proved very successful. This formula aims to provide a food which is hygenic and consistent in quality and supplies high-class protein and the necessary vitamins A..D.B. Bread rusk is used as being pure and free from mould and consistent in quality. It is obtainable from the butchers quite cheaply. Here is the formula :--
algorithms.footnote: 1 lb. Bread Rusk. 2 oz. Skimmed Milk Powder. 1 oz. Wheat Germ (Bemax). 1 oz. Bran. 1 oz. Peanut Oil. 1 oz. God Liver Oil. The C.L.O. is mixed with the peanut oil and added to the rusk, well stirred in, and the other ingredients added. If feeding Softbills add 1 oz. powdered yeast and 2 oz. of good fish meal. Keep in an airtight
algorithms.bodyText: :in and make sufficient for a week or two. Avoid strong smelling oil, hr it will be decomposed and useless, if not actually unhealthy. This mixture only needs to be moistened with water and allowed to stand for a few minutes before crumbling. In hot weather add more water. Through the years several friends have tried out my experimental batches and this latest mixture was successfully used with British and oreign finches. I also found that newly imported foreign finches greatly benefited by this mixture, feeding in small quantities frequently :o prevent fouling and re-infection where there are large numbers of
I am sure this food is on the right lines and pass on this information 0 breeders. I shall be pleased to have observations and suggestions or further improvement.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE NATIONAL SHOW 1957 THE NATIONAL SHOW 1957
algorithms.bodyText: The 46 classes allocated to foreign birds at the National Show this year were the same number as at the 1956 event. With tht exception of the class " For all seedeaters larger than a Java Sparrow " which had no entry, the classes were well filled, and the total entn was about 600. Apart from the fact that there were a number of very rare exhibits some being shown for the first time in this country, the average quality of all the birds staged was extremely high. The majority of the placing for seed-eaters were made by Mrs. E. M. Schenck and Mr. W. A Upson, as were those in the classes for Starlings, Mynahs, Toucans and Quails. Mr. J. J. Yealland and myself placed the rest of the soft bills, also the seed-eater classes for Weavers, Whydahs, Gouldians Australian, etc., finches, and other seed-eaters not larger than a Jaw Sparrow. Mr. Claude M. Payne made the awards in the sections fo parrot-like, abnormal coloured foreign, and hybrids with one or botl parents foreign. Mr. R. C. J. Sawyer, with exhibits shown in his usual immaculat style, won the Ezra Memorial Cup, National Rosette, and Award c Merit for best foreign bird, Duke of Bedford Trophy and Nationa Rosettes for best large seed-eater and best insectivorous bird Mr. G. M. Baker winning the National Rosette for best lovebird. " Cage Birds," with Mr. G. E. Weston as Show Manager an< Mr. F. W. Batchelor as Show Organizer, together with their man helpers, must be complimented on their excellent organization of s great and important an event as this Exhibition of Cage Birds. A very fine pair of Gold-breasts belonging to Mrs. P. Henderso won a large class (25 entries) for Red-eared, Orange-cheeked, an Golden-breasted Waxbills, etc., followed by C. W. Smith s an G. E. Whitmore's Fire-finches in 2nd and 3rd places. St. Helenas and Lavenders were 1st and 2nd for H. Mitchell i the next class of 18 entries, followed by Mrs. K. M. Scamell s Cordor bleus and G. E. Whitmore's Lavenders. The class for Silverbills, Combassous, Grey Java Sparrows, an Singing Finches was won by A. H. Hayes's Silverbills, followed b V. J. Price's Green Singing Finches and L. Whitmore's very good pair of Red-headed Gouldians were the winners, followed by Gouldians belonging to G. Deans and [* R- Jagger. A class containing Violet-eared, Sydney Waxbills, Melbas, etc., was headed by Mr. and Mrs. Fiveash's Violet-eared cock shown in lovely :ondition and very steady, closely followed by G. E. Whitmore's lovely pair of Violet-ears which were not looking their best. 3rd and ph, H. Mitchell's Melbas and Violet-eared, both good exhibits. The Cardinals and Grosbeaks class was won by G. E. Whitmore with an Evening Grosbeak in perfect condition, followed by W. Rolph's very nice pair of Chinese Hawfinches in 2nd place. I believe this to be the first time this species has been exhibited for competition. The class for all other seed-eaters not larger than a Java Sparrow, with 25 entries, was won by W. Dyson's very fine pair of Peter's Twinspot Waxbills, the hen being one of the best coloured I have seen, closely followed for 2nd place by G. E. Whitmore's Green Twinspots, H. Sawyer's pair of Twelve-wired shown in perfect condition, except that the cock had only 6 wires showing, the same owner also gaining 3rd place with a very nice Regent Bower-bird in very good feather. Second place went to G. E. Whitmore's magnificent Red Bird of Paradise which

algorithms.equation: ! * * * LONDON ZOO NOTES By J- J- Yealland
algorithms.bodyText: A pair of Cormorants collected on Lambay Island during 1947, :sted in January on the " cliff" in the Southern Aviary. Two eggs sre laid and one chick, now about ten days old, has been seen. The Cereopsis Geese that reared two goslings last year nested in ecember, but none of the five fertile eggs was hatched. Another utch of two is now being incubated. Birds new to the Collection are a pair of Chinese Crossbills (Loxia rvirostra albiventris) and a pair of Yellow-bellied Titmice (Parus nuslulus) presented by Dr. K. C. Searle. The Crossbills much semble the Common Crossbill--a little smaller, perhaps, but not, the present plumage, appreciably whiter on the underparts. The itmice are one of the smallest and prettiest species with their glossy ack, white, yellow and greenish-grey plumage. Mr. G. Newmark has sent a gift of a second Malachite-shouldered ruitsucker or Leaf-bird, a Crested Mynah, and a Malaysian Black- iped Oriole. Miss R. Ezra has presented two Golden Pheasants id Messrs. Brooke Bond and Co. a Sulphur-breasted Toucan. Monsieur Delacour's very interesting note on the diet of the umming Birds kept in Brazil by Dr. Beraut and Mr. Ruschi brings * mind the case of a female Sun Gem that has recently died after dng here for i |years. Without knowing the age of the bird at the me of its arrival and the expectation of life of these very small umming Birds in the wild state, it would be impossible to judge

whether this is a good record or not. This particular bird was alwa hovering round the bottles containing fruit-fly pupae and catchir the flies as they came out and I doubt whether it would have live so long had it not been for the amount of flies that it ate. If on spiders could be bred as easily as fruit-flies !

Barclay-Smith. Members of the Club : Miss J. Barnes, P. C. Bath, Hylton Blyth A. W. Bolton, Miss K. Bonner, Mrs. V. M. Bourne, Captain A. 1 Clarence, W. D. Cummings, M. F. Draper, W. T. I Maxwell, F. Mosford, G. S. Mottershead, S. Murray, Sir Crawfoi McCullagh, Bart., K. A. Norris, C. M. Payne, A. A. Prestwic, J. H. Reay, D. M. Reid-Henry, D. H. S. Risdon, S. Sanderso R. C. J. Sawyer, J. L. Sears, D. Seth-Smith, A. E. Sibley, H. J Snazle, A. C. Soanes, E. O. Squire, Newton Steel, E. N. T. Van, H. Wilmot, J. J. Yealland. Guest of the Club : Professor Jacques Berlioz. Guests : J. Bailey, Mrs. D. Barker, D. B. Barker, Mrs. P. C. Bat, A. R. Bull, T. Crewes, S. A. Croucher, Mrs. S. A. Croucher, Mrs. M. Draper, V. Faulkner, Miss H. Frampton, D. C. Garratt, Lord Gerar, Mrs. F. Grant, Mrs. F. B. Lake, E. C. Lewis, A. R. Lockie, Mrs. A. 1 Lockie, F. W. Luck, G. T. Lynch, J. D. Macdonald, Dr. E. Ma- donald, A. A. MacLaren, Miss E. E. Monnell, Mrs. S. Murra, Mrs. C. M. Payne, Captain R. S. de Q. Quincey, Mrs. J. H. Rea, Miss Roberts, Mrs. D. Seth-Smith, Mrs. E. N. T. Vane, Mrs. I Wilmot, Miss F. Wood. Members of the Club, 57 ; guests, 34 ; total, 91. The Chairman extended a hearty welcome to Mr. J. D. Macdonal, a Principal Scientific Officer of the British Museum (Natural History Many members had reason to be grateful to Mr. Macdonald, Head :
algorithms.bodyText: he Bird Room, and his staff for the ready help and courtesy which vas always shown to them when they had occasion to examine skins n the Museum collection. She was glad to have the opportunity of hanking Mr. Macdonald and of expressing the great pleasure it was o have him and Mrs. Macdonald as guests of the Club. Professor Jacques Berlioz, of the Museum National d'Histoire vlaturelle, was then introduced. Professor Berlioz, the recognized vrorld authority on Humming Birds, had come over from Paris pecially to address the Club. Professor Berlioz gave an absorbingly interesting life history of arious species, and briefly described the best means of keeping them a captivity. A full account will appear in the next number of the vlagazine. At the close the Professor received a great ovation. Question ime was unfortunately marred by a dance band in an adjoining oom. The next meeting of the Club is on Wednesday, 8th May. Arthur A. Prestwich, Hon. Secretary.

Mrs. A Morgan successfully bred a Jendaya Conure in 19^ In 1955 the parents did not nest, but last year three good young or left the nest on 26th August.
O. Hirthe, one of the oldest parrot breeders in Denmark, has br the Severe Macaw. At a recent Copenhagen bird show he exhibit the parents with their three young ones.

Jerome O. Wilson, Metairie, Louisiana, reports : "I have t very good fortune of having a breeding pair of Queen of Bavari Conures. The female has laid and hatched three eggs. The you birds are now (1st February) thirteen weeks old."

Folmer Prip, Copenhagen, writes : " Last year I only bred Pennant's, 4 Stanley, 3 Splendids, 2 Bourkes, and 2 Turquoisin A pair of Pale-headed Rosellas laid 17 eggs in 26 days. I took 10 the eggs away, but the hen did not sit on the rest, as she started moult. None of my other birds even made an attempt to nest."

algorithms.bodyText: Paul E. Schneider, San Gabriel, California, records the breeding fof his Roseate Cockatoos. Four eggs were laid and all hatched ; me young one died after about ten days. The other three left the iest on 12th, 14th, and 16th May. The parents then went to nest a second time ; three eggs, two hatched ; one young one died after a lew days, but the survivor left the nest on 9th August. All four young were successfully reared.

Breeding results, 1956. Dr. J. Dalborg-Johansen, Odense, Lineolated Parrakeet. Major V. Dilwyn Jones, five Black-headed Conures, one died when a few months old ; one Jendaya Conure that died during the bad weather at Christmas ; ten Cockatiels ; three Ring-necks ; and a number of Masked and Fischer's Lovebirds. Kenneth Greenway, eleven Redrumps from two pairs ; twenty-one Fischer's from two pairs, and fourteen Masked Lovebirds from three pairs. R. G. Kirkham, Peach-faced Lovebird, many, " I'll soon be up to my knees in them ! " Charles Lucas, Burwood, Victoria, two Princess of Wales's, three Turquoisines, and half a dozen Bourkes. J. P. Newell, Athlone, Eire, a nest of four grey Java Sparrows reared. J. FI. Reay, two Rock Pebblers left the nest, one was, unfortunately, lost after it had been self-supporting for some weeks--its loss was due to a severe storm, the other turned out to be a female ; one male Many-coloured ; two pairs of Bourkes reared nine good young ones. Brian I urner, Virginian Cardinal, two young left the nest prematurely ; one died and the survivor was caged with its parents ; an attempt to hand-feed failed. Carleton F. Smith, San Gabriel, California, two Bleeding- heart Pigeons. San Francisco Zoo, two Stanley Cranes, the first Cranes to be hatched there.

L. Raymaekers, Brussels, 1956 results. A pair of Crimson-wings hatched two young which were given to a pair of Queen Alexandra's with two young of their own. One Crimson-winged died a couple of days later, but the other was successfully reared along with the two Queen Alexandra's. The hen Crimson-winged laid a second clutch of three eggs ; the single young hatched was reared by its parents. Many-coloured abandoned five eggs after fifteen days. They were given to a pair of Bourkes ; one was hatched and reared in company with three young Bourkes. Splendid, two females reared. Bourkes,
