algorithms.bodyText: Turquoisine, one male reared. Queen Alexandra's, two reared witi the young Crimson-winged, two reared in a second nest ; a secon pair reared one. Pennant's, four hatched, three reared. Yellow bellied, a nest of six reared, two males and four females. Golder mantled Rosella, reared six in the first nest and five of seven hatche in a second. Lutino Ring-necked, two reared. King, four eggs laid on floor of the shelter, incubated but all infertile. A. A. P.
algorithms.sectionHeader: REVIEWS BIRDS OF SAURASHTRA, INDIA. ByR. S. Dharmakumarsinhj
algorithms.bodyText: F.Z.S., M.B.O.U. Published by R. S. Dharmakumarsinhji at D; Bahar, Bhavnagar, Saurashtra, India. 1955. Price -#5 1 8 j . 6d. The author is a well-known ornithologist who first started his interes in birds while at his preparatory school in England. This book is th result of more than fifteen years' study of the birds of Saurashtra, th country lying on the west coast of India between the smaller projectioi of Kutch and the straight line of the Gujerat coast. The author state that most of Saurashtra is hilly, but that there is every variety of terrain including desolate salt plains, flat land growing wheat and millel open grass, and wooded hills. He adds that many of the birds found ii Saurashtra are also found in Kutch, Gujerat, and South Rajasthan so these areas have also been covered in the book and a special supple ment has been added of notes on birds so far not recorded in Saurashtr. but found in Kutch and Gujerat. The first chapter is devoted to sections on migration, local migra tions, the study of migration, migration routes, how birds travel, cok as a factor affecting migratory birds, rain as affecting migration am breeding, and sudden influxes of birds. The author says that nowhen does rain play such an important part in local movements of birds as ii India and refers to the hordes of birds he has seen appearing at th time of the monsoon, which not only brings birds with it, but acts as; breeding stimulus. Also in the first chapter are sections on brigh plumage and bird song, how to study birds in the field and, finally bird areas in Saurashtra. The author considers the Gir Forest and th< Girnar mountain as the best area for resident birds and points out tha though most people know the Gir Forest as the habitat of the Indiai lion, few know it as a bird sanctuary. He also stresses the important of the entire Saurashtra coastline and of the Bhal district as the mail migratory routes. In the second and third chapters, on a seaside seen*

n a February morning and an April day in the Gir Forest, the author lakes his readers share his obvious pleasure and delight in the scene y graphic descriptions of the surroundings and the birds. There then follow full descriptions giving details, identification, otes, distribution, nesting, and food of 357 species. The author is keen falconer and introduces an interesting innovation by trying to onvey, in his notes on the flights of trained falcons, how birds react to ttacks from birds of prey and how they escape. There are 33 colour dates depicting 282 species by Somalal Shah, 40 black and white dates from photographs by the author and others, a colour photo- raph frontispiece by the author, and 16 maps showing distribution and ligration routes of various species. At the beginning of the book is a etailed map of the area under review and at the end a map showing be lakes of Saurashtra. P. B-S.
algorithms.sectionHeader: I POPULATION STUDY OF PENGUINS. By L. E. Richdale.
algorithms.affiliation: Oxford University Press, London, 1957. Price 42^. net.
algorithms.bodyText: The author has made an elaborate study of the Yellow-eyed Penguin, Aegadyptes antipodes , in southern New Zealand, extending over ighteen years. An earlier monograph dealt with Sexual Behaviour in \enguins , and the present work is concerned mainly with detailed bservations in various breeding areas within about twenty miles of )unedin. Four areas were worked thoroughly each season, and it is onsidered that practically all the breeding birds were found each eason, and for some years nearly all resident non-breeding birds. The data are presented in a series of tables dealing with first the mgth of the pair-bond and such factors as divorce, separation, dis- ppearance and death leading to its dissolution. The incubation eriod seems to vary not only among individuals but between seasons, "he chick period lasts on the average about 106 days. The amount f food received by chicks was determined by weighing the chicks )ur times a day. An average of 818 grammes of food per day was iven to two chicks in the last eighteen days of the guard stage, but n. one day the total reached 1,418 grammes. The young birds /andered considerably during the first five years, but then they ecame mature and rarely moved to a new breeding place. Out of II fledglings which entered the sea, 6 per cent returned to breed in leir place of hatching, 8 per cent to the same area, 9 per cent to ie nearest breeding area, and 7 per cent to a more distant area.

About 52 per cent are estimated to die, leaving a balance of 18 pei cent which may breed in areas to the south of Otago Peninsula Survival and mortality factors are given in detail, and the precise composition of a penguin community. There is also a chapter on the moulting season including comparisons with other species of penguins It was essential for these studies to have some system of marking and an aluminium band fixed on the tarsus was the method generally adopted. The numbers were stamped on the band in four places, sc that whichever way the bird was standing the number could be seer and read by the aid of a telescope. Footmarking involving th< punching of six holes in the web of each foot proved much mon; satisfactory, and according to the author, without it the material fo this monograph would never have been obtained. Whilst this is primarily a book for the specialist, the detailed stud; of such an interesting bird will appeal to a much wider public.
algorithms.figure: E. H. * * * NOTES Red-eared Waxbill--Correction regarding Specific Name
algorithms.bodyText: In my note on " A natural colour variety of the Red-eared Waxbill " publishe in the November-December number, 1956, of the Avicultural Magazine, I referre to the Red-eared Waxbill as Estrilda astrild. The specific name I gave is not, howeve correct, and should have read Estrilda troglodytes. C. J. O. Harrison.
algorithms.sectionHeader: CORRESPONDENCE REQUEST FOR OBSERVATIONS ON BIRDS WITH DEFORMED BILL
algorithms.bodyText: I am collecting information about birds with deformed bills and I think possib

It is possible that such deformities may be inherited in some cases and ai evidence of this from breeding--either in support or in opposition to this view-5 would be valuable. I should be very grateful for any information of this sort sent to me.
algorithms.reference: D. E. Pomeroy. Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge.
algorithms.bodyText: The National Council of Aviculture is sponsoring a three-year programme of research into the cause of French Moult in Budgerigars, to be undertaken in the Department of Agricultural Chemistry in the University of Reading. There is some evidence that French Moult may, in certain cases, be associated with a quantitative Dr qualitative deficiency in the crop-milk fed to the young chicks, and, as part of [his investigation, we are studying the structure, development, and possible endocrine control of the glands responsible for the production of this secretion. A condition similar to French Moult has also been observed in some species of ovebirds and in Red-rumps, and there is good reason to believe that all parrot-like birds feed their young on crop-milk for at least the first week after hatching. We are interested, therefore, in studying the structure of the milk-secreting glands in other psittacine birds as well as in Budgerigars, and if any members of the Avicultural Society are unfortunate enough to lose any of their birds while incubating or while feeding young, we should be very glad if they would send the carcases to us, with the date on which the first egg was laid, the date of death, and whether or not young bad hatched. It is not known whether the cock produces crop-milk as well as the hen, so birds 3f both sexes would be equally welcome. It is important that they should be sent as soon after death as possible, and if any substantial delay occurs, it would be very desirable if they were preserved in 5 per cent formalin, or failing this, in 50 per cent methylated spirits. A small cut should be made in the body wall of the thorax and abdomen to allow the preservative to enter and, after soaking in the liquid for a few hours, the bird may be removed and packed in damp paper in a polythene bag for postage. The bodies of any young parrot-like birds which die while in the nest would also be of great value for chemical investigation of their crop-contents. We are hoping that this investigation will make a real contribution to the knowledge of the physiology and nutrition of psittacine birds, and any help w'hich members are able to give will be greatly appreciated. All specimens should be posted to me at the University. T. G. Taylor. Dept, of Agricultural Chemistry, The University, Reading.

After reading in the December number of our Magazine Mr. Gerrits very' interesting account of the breeding of the Australian Black-breasted Plover Z on \f er tricolor, I would like to supplement his remarks by saying that after keeping two or three pairs in the Lilford aviaries for some years, we found them charming subjects to possess and considerably less difficult to maintain in health than some of the rarer British waders. Our examples did well when kept in a large pool aviary with other waders. They partook of the usual waders' mixture and would also eat wheat. I have no reliable bistory of the species available, but should imagine they may frequent dry upland pasture. Mention may be made of this because when purchased I found them in a London store (Messrs. Chapmans) in excellent condition, but supplied with no other food except a dish of dry, small, brownish-yellow millet seed. Unsuitable as this appeared to me they were partaking of it freely and I was assured later that it was the only food that had accompanied them on the voyage. As to the breeding of the Black-breasted Plover in confinement I may add that as the spring approached, paired pairs were better removed to quieter quarters. Therefore our most promising pair were summered in a small aviary the whole floor space of which consisted of a well kept miniature lawn 12 feet by 14 feet. Here, as described by Mr. Gerrits, they made a beautiful rubbing or nest in the short turf and for two seasons around 1930 reared their young, I believe a two and a three. From memory these birds were very noisy and demonstrative at the nest but never seemed really to mind their aviary being entered for supplying food. When the young were newly hatched, however, it was advisable to note the exact position of each squatting chick before stepping inside. My diary of 1930-31 states the young were quite easy to rear. Lilford, Oundle, Peterborough. A. F. Moody.

algorithms.equation: (.Anthobaphes violacea) B y J- J- Yealland (London, England)
algorithms.bodyText: The Wedge-tailed or Orange-breasted Sunbird was originally iescribed in 1766 by Linnaeus when he named it Certhia violacea. [t is the only member of its genus and its distribution is confined to :he extreme south-west of Africa. Stark {Fauna of South Africa , Birds , vol. 1) says : " The Orange- Dreasted Sunbird frequents open uncultivated country, rough hill- iides, and the slopes and summits of mountain ranges, and especially \0x25A0vhere various heaths and proteas abound. It has a considerable /ertical range, from sea-level to a height of 4,000 feet or more, and 3eing a hardy little bird, seemingly indifferent to cold and wet, it s quite at home on the bleak and foggy mountains of the coast ranges n Cape Colony." Stark goes on to say : " These Sunbirds feed largely on the nectar of /arious heaths, occasionally on that of proteas, also on small insects :hat frequent these flowers, and on gnats and flies which they dart apon, like Flycatchers, from a perch to which they constantly return. Like the Long-tailed Cape Sugar Birds, they breed during the winter 'ains, the nests near Cape Town being usually built in June and the Jggs laid in July. This coincides with the flowering season of certain leaths and proteas on whose nectar they feed their young. On one occasion I found a nearly completed nest at the end of March. The aest, oval and domed, with a small side entrance near the top, is built T small flexible twigs of heath, dry grass, and narrow downy leaves, :hickly lined with the soft white petals of a protea. It is not pendant ike the nests of other Sunbirds, but is attached by its sides to the stalks n the centre of a thick bush of heath, a foot or eighteen inches off the ground. The eggs, two in number, are white dotted all over, but most thickly round the greatest diameter, with small spots and streaks

of greyish brown. They measure 0.65 X 0.48. On one occasion I noticed a female remove the eggs from a nest from which I had startled her, and place them under some thick undergrowth a few feet away. She apparently carried them in her bill. A second brood is frequently reared in September and October. From December to March these Sunbirds are generally in small family parties of four 01 six, the parents and their young, one of the band being nearly always a male in full plumage, while one or two are young males showing varying amounts of metallic plumage." The flocking habit is interesting : this Sunbird certainly seem' less aggressive than many others. No doubt it would thrive--as indeed do many of the more tropical ones--far better in an outdoor aviary than in a cage and would need only a little warmth in the shelter during winter. I once kept a pair in a large cage under quite cool conditions and they did well, but then the following summer wher I was away, both escaped and were not heard of again.
algorithms.table: * BREEDING GOLDEN-MANTLED ROSELLAS SINCE 1951 By Dieter Overlander (Honnef/Rhein, Germany)
algorithms.bodyText: When I write " Golden-mantled " I do not intend to say that my Rosellas are pure Golden-mantled but they look like them. I believe that in Germany many, or most, of the birds so called are hybrids or youngsters of hybrids, between cecilae and eximius. These " hybrids ' in many cases look like cecilae so far as the colour is concerned, but ir size they seem to favour the larger eximius. But this is only an ide; of mine and not proved. I hope the reader will not be disappointed that this breeding account is not a story of splendid successes. In 1951 I obtained my first pair of Rosellas, an old cock and ; young hen still in immature plumage. In the middle of April, 1952 the cock drove the hen through the aviary, but as this aviary is 12m in length he could not harm her. Then I realized that she was to( young and exchanged her for another belonging to my uncle. Thi hen after being in the aviary for only eight days was fed by the cock and ten days later she laid her first egg. Unfortunately, this firs clutch, five eggs, was destroyed after two youngsters had hatchec because the log fell to the ground. The parents stopped breeding fo six weeks and then they had another clutch of three eggs, which al hatched and were reared. But misfortune had not ceased as in winte the old hen escaped. Some months later I was told that she ha been caught, fed on poultry food, and then escaped again.

In 1953 I obtained another hen from a first nest of 1952. This hen, hough still in immature plumage, had four eggs in one nest, three of vhich hatched and were reared. Two other young pairs, two birds )f which had been bred by myself, were doing nothing but feeding )ccasionally and inspecting the nests. I suppose it is not so difficult o breed from young hens as from young males. In 1954 I had three pairs in full adult plumage and one young pair. [ hoped to realize good results. The old pair had six eggs all of which latched. The nestlings did well for a fortnight after emerging from he shell, then the eldest fell ill. The down was wet and stuck to the iody. Every second or third day I found another dead young one. ' believe they all died from cold and wet weather. The other pair had a clutch of seven eggs. When laying the fourth he hen became egg-bound. She had left the nest and sat on the ground. - took the bird indoors and tried to massage the egg out of the body. took her in my left hand and with three fingers of the right hand . pressed the egg out. But there are two points which must be observed lou must not try to do things too quickly and must watch the bird md feel or see when the hen herself is straining to get rid of the egg ind just at that moment you must help her. Then sometimes the egg nust be moistened, especially when it is visible. Naturally, this way )f curing is only possible when the bird is in good condition and when he egg-binding is not caused pathologically. In this way I have )een successful three times. I suppose that the birds got egg-bound )ecause the temperature had fallen rapidly. I think, however, that me can very often prevent it by feeding cod-liver oil. Thus in 1954 my losellas had twenty-eight eggs and reared only two young. ! 955 was another poor season. When three young of my old pair lad died I took the remaining two and reared them by hand. They vere fed on milled sunflower seed, oats, and millet. Some greens and :arrots were added and the food was moistened and warmed. The wo youngsters did very well and turned out to be a pair. The male scaped, when I did not think he was yet able to fly ; but the next lay he returned and I was able to catch him. He is still in my >ossession, and when I enter his aviary he takes sunflower seeds from ny hand and sits on my shoulder. Two other young Rosellas I had aken out of their nest some weeks later. These birds were fed for ome time on hulled millet, used for human consumption. Probably ome vitamins were missing in this food and, though I added greens nd carrots every day, the plumage developed very badly. They ould not fly till they were eight months old. Last year (April, 1956) there were three pairs of Rosellas on eggs nd I hoped that we would have a good season. But I believe that his hope is a characteristic feature of every bird-lover all over the

By Professor J. Berlioz (Paris, France) (Address given to the British Aviculturists' Club, 13 th March, 1957*) Among the numerous groups of perching birds, the Humming Birds, which constitute the family Trochilidae, are, with the Trogons certainly the best defined and most isolated of all, really showing no connecting link with any other type. Nothing is known about thei; ancestors and even their actual affinities remain quite obscure, althougl they are most generally considered by modern systematicians to b< more or less closely allied to the Swifts. The chief characters are as follows :-- Mostly of very diminutive size (the largest like a Swift, the smalles like a bumble-bee). Bill, very thin, elongated, tubular, pointed, either straight o curved downwards or, sometimes, upwards. Peculiar tongue, long, protractile, bitubular at the end, and attachec to a curious bony formation encircling the skull, not unlike that of th Woodpeckers. Extreme shortness of the wings and legs, more reduced than ii any other type of birds. The wings always have ten primaries, bu not more than five or six secondaries. The feet, also very short, alway have four toes, often with strong claws. Brilliancy of the plumage, mostly composed of scale-like feathers the tail always composed of ten rectrices, very seldom less. Th shiny appearance of the plumage is due to the physical structure c the feathers, which produces various shades of iridescent colouring unrivalled by other birds, but always devoid of any pigment excep black or rufous. Males and females are sometimes alike, but generall differ in various ways ; however, sometimes they are quite dissimila in pattern and colouring. They are very active, often aggressive and pugnacious little bird fighting among themselves and even attacking much larger an stronger birds, such as birds of prey and Tyrant-Flycatchers, utilizin their wonderful power of flight and their very sharp acute bill. The have but few natural enemies : however, it is said that the smalk species, when hovering in front of flowers, may be caught and eate by aerial predators, such as the Bemtevi Tyrant and even fall victin of the big American spiders. Humming Birds are strictly confined to America, but here they ai to be found everywhere where there are flowers. Although muc more numerous in the tropical parts of America, some of them sprea< during the northern summer, as far north as Alaska and Labrado Similarly, in the southern hemisphere, one species at least is to be loui during the southern summer as far south as the Strait of Magellan.

8 5 The reason why the life of the Humming Birds seems so closely onnected with the existence of flowers is because in flowers they ind both food and drink. It has long been wrongly believed that their Dod was essentially composed of the sweet secretions of the flowers ; >ut it is now well known that animal food is much more necessary o them and in fact they feed chiefly on very small insects which are hemselves attracted by the liquids inside the flowers. Humming lirds are perfectly able, too, to catch the flying insects on the wing, ising their long protractile tongue for this purpose quite as cleverly ,s in picking them out from the flowers. Even in some countries where flowers are scarce, as is the case in he Juan Fernandez Islands, Humming Birds remain almost strictly nsectivorous. In other very dry parts of the American Pacific Coast, diere there are only few soft insects, Humming Birds may in some ^ay become more or less frugivorous, feeding mostly on the juice f damaged cactus fruits, when the latter have been attacked by ants >r other animals. Considering the wide variation of food these birds may adopt ccording to climatic conditions, it is less astonishing to find them so ddely spread everywhere in America, from the low tropical rain- orests to the highest mountain ranges or in subdesert areas. Owing o their perpetual need of food they are particularly numerous in ultivated areas, where gardens and orchards provide all kinds of lowers and insects nearly the whole year round. For the same reason, he Humming Birds which nest in temperate countries are migratory nd several species every year make very long voyages, starting from heir breeding grounds in Canada and Alaska and reaching as far outh as Central America and Panama, where they spend the autumn nd winter months. The peculiar structure of the wings affords the Humming Birds most peculiar and unique mode of flight ; it consists in an un- aterrupted sequence of very rapid wing-beats, the speed of which lay attain 50 or more per second for the smaller species. The name Humming Birds " is actually derived from this flight, which closely esembles the flight of certain moths and produces similarly charac- eristic sounds. Another peculiarity of their ability of flight is that they re the only birds which are able to fly backwards, which they can 0 at the same speed and quite as easily as in any other direction. >ut, on the other hand, they cannot use their feet for any motion t all when perching on a branch or sitting on the ground. They dll be seen remaining nearly motionless on the same twig for several ainutes, then they will suddenly fly away at an astonishing speed nd, after acrobatic flights in the air, come back to the same place, ast as flycatchers do. Nearly all their food is obtained on the wing, both the small insects

captured in the air and the food sucked from the flowers. The hover rapidly at the same place in front of the flower and push in th long bill and protractile tongue to reach the nectar and insects inside However, on a few occasions, and especially in the case of certaf mountain species which are more sluggish in their habits, they perc' close to the flower, taking their food from the latter just as most of th Passerine nectarivorous birds do. Nesting habits : there is still much to be learned about their nestin habits. Until quite recently it has been accepted as a strict rule tha Humming Birds are polygamous and that both sexes, except for th short period of mating, live quite independently apart from each othe] even during migration. Their nests are generally most delicati though solid, cup-shaped structures, attached to twigs or varioi other supports, and the building of which is done by the females alont They almost invariably lay two eggs, the latter being uniformly whit and comparatively large for the size of the bird. Females also undei take alone the entire incubation and the rearing of the chicks. Thes remain about twenty-four days in the nest, until their wings ar completely grown, as they are unable to move until they acquire th same ability of flight as the parents. However, some very recent observations made in Venezuela seei to prove that, at least in a few cases, the male does not remain quit so indifferent to the rearing of the young as is generally believei These observations concern a somewhat large and common species ( Humming Bird, Colibri coruscans. The observer (Dr. E. Schafei discovered a nest containing one young, newly hatched, and or egg, to which obviously male and female came alternately both 1 incubate the egg and to feed the young bird (although both sex' of this species are more or less similar in appearance, the male ha an abnormal feather pattern which rendered him unmistakable). It is impossible to ascertain whether the same habits are to be foun in all individuals of the same species or not. But it may be recalle that there is a modern theory that among birds in which the tw sexes are similar in appearance, both parents generally assume tl same duties in the rearing of the young. And, on the other han< it is a well-known fact now that in many so-called " polygamous birds, individual cases of monogamy may exceptionally occur. Finally some words may be added concerning Humming Birds i confinement. At least three conditions are necessary for their goc health and maintenance : space for flying ; insects as their fund, mental food ; water and moisture for most species. For more than half a century efforts have been made to kee these beautiful tiny creatures in confinement. But after many failur it was not until some thirty years ago that these efforts became real successful. The long delay involved in bringing them from Ameri'
algorithms.sectionHeader: VISIT TO THE ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS, CHESTER
algorithms.bodyText: 0 Europe, the need of fresh food every day, the wrong idea that sweet iquids constituted their normal diet, have been the chief causes of so nany failures, and, for the few specimens able to reach Europe at hat time, they generally died suddenly after a few weeks at most. remember in 1922 visiting one of the first attempts made in Paris 0 maintain a small collection of living Humming Birds in Count de iegur's aviary. Each bird was kept alone in a special cage, and several imes every day was given a few minutes of freedom in a very large 00m. In more recent times great improvement has been achieved both n transportation and in giving the best conditions of life in con- inement. There is no doubt that when still more has been learned .bout their life in the wild, it will become still less difficult ; but t is certainly rather unlikely that they will ever become real " pets " or their owners.
algorithms.sectionHeader: VISIT TO THE ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS, CHESTER
algorithms.bodyText: The Council of the North of England Zoological Society, through he Director-Secretary, Mr. G. S. Mottershead, kindly invite members >f the Avicultural Society to lunch at the Zoological Gardens, Chester, in Tuesday, 25th June, 1957. The invitation to lunch is confined to members. Free admission to the ffio is offered to friends, and lunch may be reserved for them. Members ntending to accept the invitation must notify the Hon. Secretary, )i Chase Road, Oakwood, N. 14, before 18th June, 1957. The Chester Zoo is 180 miles from London, 15 miles from Liverpool, fo miles from Manchester, and 72 miles from Birmingham. Suggested trains (subject to confirmation) from and to London ire :-- Leave Euston, 8.30 a.m. Arrive Chester, 12.24 p.m. Leave Chester, 5.10 p.m. Arrive Euston, 8.50 p.m. Fares (subject to revision) return, 1st class, 4s. 10 d. ; 2nd class, #2 i6j-. 6 d. There are excellent bus services from Chester Market Square, service No. 13, to within 150 yards of the main entrance to the Zoo, md a regular direct Zoo service to the north entrance ; also a direct tervice from " Woodside ", Birkenhead, to the north entrance. Visitors arriving by train will have to proceed by bus to the Market Square in order to catch a bus to the Zoo. If members arriving by he London train would kindly advise the Hon. Secretary, arrange- ments could be made for them to be conveyed direct to the Zoo from he station.
J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS

By J. R. van Oosten (San Marino, California, U.S.A.) ('Continued from page 50) During the month of January, 1956, I was very fortunate in beim able to purchase from Professor Carl Naether a beautiful pair of Black chinned Yuhinas in excellent condition. I already had one hen whicl had been imported a few years ago from India. In the same ship ment I received a Golden-eyed Babbler and the two arrived as gooc friends and have remained so. It was a funny sight to see the Yuhin; follow the Babbler, about twice her size, everywhere it wen Never having seen any of these Babblers I was unable to sex mine but I am sure that it is a male as it sings all the time. The new pai of Yuhinas were liberated after four days in a holding cage to allov the other birds in the aviary to get used to them. My greatest fea was that the cock might kill the odd hen, but upon being released th< pair paid no heed to her. Therefore I left her in, a thing which I nov very much regret. Sexing these little birds I find fairly easy as there is a difference o colour on the breast of the hens. The colour throughout is uniforn in both the male and the female with only that one exception. Thes< breast feathers are almost a fawn grey, the male's being dark grey Also I found that the male is somewhat larger than the two hens. Thi I noticed when I bought the pair, but with the three of them it is quit< unmistakable. Both sexes have a little song, but the male's last longer and is uttered more often and is a little deeper in tone. On of their characteristics is when they are apart they call to each othe in a short one-note call, which increases if something is found ; where upon the other one comes at once. They are extremely inquisitiv and spent the first few weeks exploring all the corners of the " glas house " and adjoining flight. They also spend a great deal of tim hawking fruit-flies, and with each fly caught one hears the snaj which most Flycatchers make. This sound also reminds one of th snap which Manakins make. One day while visiting Mr. Isenber; I heard his Black and White Manakin make the same snapping noise but I believe that Manakins make this noise when not hawkim insects. In March the pair was observed inspecting the nest-boxes and finall' they settled on a small finch nest-box which had a platform in front The materials they used were string, cotton, pieces of burlap, sma twigs, dog hair, with a lining of bird feathers, string, and dog hair Being drafted into the military service at the end of March I wa unable to keep any notes of what happened during the following tw< months. Upon my return in June I at once noticed that my Yuhina
J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS

iow totalled five instead of three. No doubt the success can be once igain attributed to the fruit-flies as there was always an ample supply to le had. I feel strongly that with cultures of these flies, two or three o an aviary when young are in the nest, plus a few mealworms, and vhere possible other live food, it would not be impossible to rear many nore of the baby softbills to maturity. The young were decidedly on heir own because when they begged their parents for food and none vas offered they flew to the feeding tray and proceeded to eat by ihemselves. They ate soaked currants, egg food, apple, grapes, and frank a little honey-water ; also they were able to hawk flies, so ;hey were definitely not dependent upon their parents. I had noticed that since my leaving the male had become somewhat more aggressive and that should have been the sign for me to remove the three birds. However, as we often do, I left them in there and the day before I left to go back to the Navy after a fourteen-day leave [ found three dead Yuhinas on the ground. The old hen was taken lo the taxidermist as were the two young, but I had all the insides taken to a lab and as luck would have it the young were a male and female. There is no doubt the male Yuhina killed the other three but of this I cannot be sure. These graceful little birds are hard to come by here in the States and the loss was very saddening. If I should lose one of the pair, especially the hen, it would be a long time before I could replace it. However, if the success is repeated next year the young will be separated as soon as they are able to feed by themselves. The young resembled the parents except for being lighter in colour throughout the body and their crests were not yet as black. The bill did not show the colour of the parents. When adult the lower mandible has a spot of red at the joint where the bill meets the body, their feet were also not as full of colour. Beyond this they resembled and possessed all the funny and comical antics and habits which one associates with this family. Some other attempts were made but nothing came of them. 1 his was the first year that I was able to rear any young ones. Softbills are very funny in this respect as sometimes they breed and other times they do not even make an honest effort. One pair of Pagoda Mynahs built a nest, but no eggs were laid and the nest was finally destroyed. A pair of Red-eared Bulbuls and a pair of Yellow-winged Bulbuls were seen carrying nesting materials but nothing came of it. All my White- eyes--two pairs of Indian, one pair of Australian (obtained from Mr. Isenberg), and a male Australian which mated with a female Indian--have never shown the slightest interest in breeding or even building a nest. Mr. Isenberg each year always rears a few and I believe this may be due to the large clumps of dwarf bamboo which he has in their aviary. The clump I have is not thick enough so this could very possibly be the reason why they have not shown the least interest.

J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS The group of birds which fascinates me the most is the Tan age family. I find these birds full of antics besides being extremely colourful I have at the present quite a few of these gems, but in all the time sine beginning with softbills I have run across very few females. Thes birds should be easy to breed if one could find the hens. One pai I obtained a few years ago from Mr. William Krebs were sittin; on a nest of two eggs, but as he did not want to bother with the youns he broke up the nest and I took the birds. Both were in excellen condition, but after seven days the hen succumbed. For what reasoi I was unable to find out as the death report showed no signs of anything wrong. The pair were the lovely Golden-headed Tanager. The mal( passed on about six months ago and I have not been able to fine another. At the same time I had one Yellow-headed Tanager whicl looks the exact duplicate of the Golden-headed in body, size, anc distribution of the colours j the only difference, of course, was tha they were not the same in colour, the former being gold on top anc the sides of the head with a metallic green body and black wings back, and tail. The latter s head is yellow, body a metallic sky-blue wings, back, and tail black. Another very interesting one is the Blue-backed Tanager, which closely resembles and is related tc Desmarest s Tanager. The difference is that the rump and front of the former is a metallic light royal blue instead of green, and the heac is bnck-iecl instead of scarlet. The little yellow band which separates the led ol the head and the green of the back is not very noticeable in the blue-backed. Also from Mr. Krebs I obtained a female Blue- crowned Chlorophonia , otherwise known as the Emerald Tanager. I had for years been worried about these birds, as I lost over ten after each had been in my collection for no more than two months. I finally decided to cut down on the banana and orange and that did the trick. By doing this I forced them to eat more egg food, which before they only pecked as il there was nothing else left. Now with the hen, I purchased from a dealer two young males which were coming into theii adult moult ; both did well and the three were together all the time. After about two years I found both the males in the pond and have no idea how they got there. Fortunately I still have the hen and a male will not be hard to procure. Also I have had pairs of the Violet Euphonia but was never able to keep them more than a year for the same leason as the above birds. I also have had females of the Blue, Copper-headed, Palm, Maroon, Blue-and-Black, Superb, and Pectoral Euphonia. Three of these I still have left to-day. Last year I was very lucky in importing eighteen of the beautiful Red-eared Tanagers from Ecuador. I have eight left after losing two and selling eight. Mr. Charles Gordier brought thirteen back with him some years ago and one of these came to the San Diego Zoo. This is where I first saw the bird and fell in love with it. This year my wish came true and not

J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS 91 nly did I get some of these birds but amongst them were three hens, f I were an artist I would make a plate for the Magazine, as their ieauty can only be appreciated if seen in life ; however, a description /ill have to do. To begin with we will imagine that the bird is jet dack ; in size it is just a little bit smaller than the Mountain Tanager. ust behind the eye is a small crescent-shaped spot of scarlet-red, rom which the bird derives its name ; in the female the shape ol his crescent is smaller and not as bright. Then from just below the hest in a straight line across, through the belly and rump is the other irea of scarlet-red, which again is several shades lighter in the hens, rhe bird also has a spot of blue at the first wing joint which shows vhile sitting still, but much better when flying. It is the same metallic ight royal blue which the Mountain Tanager has on its wing ; also ipon close inspection it will be noted that this spot of blue in the hen s not as large as that of the male. They were very nervous when they irst arrived, but now have settled down and three ol them will take nealworms from the hand. In the same shipment I received another Tanager which reminds one in size and shape of an Emerald Tanager )nly bigger. The colour is a very deep and bright royal blue all over, vith the front, from the neck to the vent, canary yellow ; the wings md tail have a greenish sheen to them when the bird is sitting in the ;un. I could find no description in Aviculture , Vol. I, to fit the bird, 50 I am not able to name it. I sold the bird to Mr. Jerome Buteyn md the last time I saw it it had fully feathered out and looked beautiful. 1 hope in future to have as many of the Tanager family as I can as they are very interesting and always full of life. In the same shipment I received five other birds which I can find no description of in either the back issues of this Magazine or in Aviculture , Vol. I, or in any of the books which I have seen. These birds arrived two days before I went back to the Navy and unfortunately all I have left are the skins. I hope that as soon as I am back in civilian life I will again be able to procure some more ol these birds. The first bird was some type of giant Ant-Thrush or Ant-Pitta which belongs to the New World. Few of these birds have ever been imported because of the fact that they are hard to trap as well as hard to see in the jungle. Mr. Cordier imported some a few years ago, from, I believe, British Guiana, but these were smaller and, I remembei, they were called Helmeted Ant-d hrushes. The bird that I had resembled in body that of a Pitta, only about three-quarters again as large, with a little longer tail. The head was similar and the beak was longer and musty black in colour, the feet were a dull flesh colour. The eye was light brown with a black iris. The head above the eyes, back, rump, and upper side of the tail was dark grey-blue ; the chin to the sides of the neck and three-quarters of an inch below the chin

J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS was a light rusty or copper brown. The rest of the bird--chest, belly vent, and underside of the tail--was the fawn colour of a fawn Zebra Finch. The chest, belly, and vent were also dotted with black spots each spot being one-quarter of an inch in diameter and surrounded by a ring an eighth of an inch wide, of the above-mentioned light rusty or copper brown. Each dot was roughly half an inch away from the next. The bird was quite tame, but when food was placed in the cage it would pounce on it like a dog. It would eat nothing but canned dog food, mealworms, cut up raw meat, some egg food, and a few raisins. The next two birds were the same and in size resembled a Magpie Tanager, but with a more streamlined body. They looked like a member of the Tanager family but I could not tell for sure. The beak and feet were black and the eye was scarlet red with a black iris. This was the most outstanding feature of the bird. The top of the head was black with three red feathers which began at the crown and ran back to the back of the head ; these the bird would raise a half an inch, along with the black feathers, when it became excited in any way. The rest of the plumage was a light blue-grey, more blue, which became almost black on the wings and tail. The birds were not nervous and they would eat anything put before them. They preferred soaked currants, egg food, grapes, and milk sop to anything else. I could not tell if they were young or not, but it seemed that there should have been a few more red feathers on the head instead of just the three. I should mention here that all five of these birds arrived in perfect condition without so much as a spoiled feather. 1 he last two were members of the Cotinga family, a cock and a hen. These birds are very rare and not easy to come by, not even in the jungle. I his was my saddest loss, for there will be one chance in a hundred to replace them. The hen was an evergreen green with yellow feathers dotted over the lower chest and belly, and her beak and feet were a yellowish colour. In size she was a little larger than a Mountain Tanager. About six months before I had seen the same bird in a shipment which Mr. Ray Thomas received from Colombia and which now is in Mr. Jean Delacour's collection in Los Angeles. Upon looking through an old issue of the American Aviculture magazine I saw a coloured picture of a pair of Swallow Tanagers and the hen looked exactly like the two birds in every way. However, while visiting Mr. Delacour one day, and seeing the bird, I was informed that it was a hen Cotinga of some sort. The bird was in beautiful shape and seemed to be quite happy in its new surroundings. With this in mind the next bird which I shall describe could very well have been the male of the species, for it had all the characteristics of the Cotinga family. The size and shape of the body was very similar to that of a Naked- throated Bell Bird, though it was not so large. The beak and feet were
J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS

orange, like that of the bill of a Toucan, and the e.ye was orangeish with the black iris and a black eye cere. The whole head and neck were jet black, the back, wings, and upper side of the tail were a dark evergreen green, while the chest, belly, vent, rump, and under side of the tail a green colour like the breast of a Blue-throated Barbet, only a shade lighter. The belly, lower half of the chest, and vent were dotted with black dots which were surrounded by a very small ring of white. The dots were about half an inch apart and about three- eighths of an inch in diameter. The ring was roughly a sixteenth of an inch wide. Both birds were very quiet and were not easily disturbed upon someone entering the room ; they only moved to eat, drink, bathe, and preen themselves. They would take only egg food made into small balls, a few mealworms, small pieces of cut-up apple, pear, banana, and tomato, and catoniaster berries and grapes, which they liked the best. Another shipment came to me in November, 1955, which contained three of the very rare and beautiful Apricot Cocks-of-the-Rock. These birds are larger than the Scarlet Cock-of-the-Rock, of which I have a male, but look the same in all respects except that the scarlet is replaced by a deep orange. Upon arrival two birds did not look to be in good shape. I stayed up two nights following, hand-feeding them, but on the third day one was lost. A week later one was sold after it looked to be in good condition, but it died within two weeks. The death report on both these birds showed that they had a disease in the intestinal tract which they had had for some time. The last one was liberated after two weeks in the " glass house ", after the Scarlet had been transferred to the " medium size " aviary, and lived for another six weeks before it died. The bird was in perfect condition and seemed to be fine and healthy. As I was away at college I fear that the bird was not fed correctly, which caused its death. The death report stated that the lack of food had been the cause, and so, had the bird been fed correctly, it would have lived. I have found that importing birds is not as expensive as one might think. I have also found that by shipping the birds in reinforced aluminium transport cages one cuts the air freight cost by half; this is where most of the money goes when importing birds. I also have the transport cages made collapsible so that I can send them back to the collector for the next shipment. Being able to import, one is able to get some of the rarer birds plus the ones you can buy from your dealer. Of course you are going to have losses, but if the food and water vessels are hung properly and enough food is provided and fixed so that it cannot spill on the bottom of the cage, you will eliminate another cause of death. In this way I have cut my losses down fifty per cent of what they used to be. I would also like to add that I have imported the greater part of my collection as it would have been almost

J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS impossible for me to purchase them here in the States. On the whole the members in England and Europe can obtain foreign softbills more easily than we can here in the States. No doubt the reason is that more people are interested in softbills over there than here, but I, like others, hope that some day people here will take more of a lancy to them. One reason for this lack of interest may be that it is imagined the cost of feeding this type of bird is an expensive affair, but I think that the following might change some minds. Much has been written by various members of the Society on the feeding of softbills and therefore I would also like to throw my hat in the ring. There are many ways of feeding and each person has his or her own idea on what is the best. I have tried to feed my birds in such a manner as to keep them in excellent condition and yet not spend a fortune on them. At present the birds are being fed by our German cook and I must say she does a better job than I do. As has already been pointed out the only live food which is given are the fruit-flies, but during the winter months this is supplemented with mealworms. Also there are other insects which are available to them in the green moss around the waterfall, off plants, and from the ground. I might add that freshly cut grass is always given to them and they seem to enjoy poring over it in search of all sorts of things. The mainstay of their feeding is a ready prepared Mockingbird food which I buy from a dealer. This is made of one-half Spratt's Mockingbird food and one-half finely ground enriched dog meal ; to this is added equal amounts of cod liver oil and wheat germ oil to make it still fairly dry, but so that each ground is well soaked in oil. Then ten pounds of dried flies are added to a hundred pounds of mixture. To this I myself add one box of pablum and one of wheat germ cereal to each ten pounds. This dries it up a bit more and adds a few more desirable ingredients. This is fed to all the birds and is also relished by doves, quail, cardinals, and Rainbow Buntings. The next main item which I have found to be very good, and probably most lesponsible for keeping my birds in good health and excellent condition, is the egg food formula mixture which I have worked out. It consists of the following :--
algorithms.figure: 6 (six) tablespoons of Pablum. 6 , i (one) I 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55 55
algorithms.reference: ,, Wheat Germ. , Powdered Grade A Milk. ,, Horlick's Malted Milk. ,, Mellin's Food. , Powdered Carrot. ,, Fish Meal. ,, Meat Meal. ,, Bone Meal. ,, Powdered Sea Kelp. ,, Spratt's Red Colour Canary Food.
algorithms.bodyText: J. R. VAN OOSTEN-ADVENTURES WITH SOFTBILLS

After thoroughly mixing all the above together, five grated hard- >oiled eggs are added and mixed thoroughly with the mixture. The [fixture will turn out crumbly in texture and will keep in glass jars Dr a week if kept in the ice box. My birds prefer this mixture to any- hing else I feed and nothing much else is touched until it is all gone, feed it in very generous amounts to all my birds. The last two items, olour food and sea kelp, which contains iodine, are, I think, responsible or keeping the reds, yellows, and oranges from fading during the noult. This was especially noted in the Scarlet Cock-of-the-Rock, or after four moults his colour was the same as the day I got him. Then, while away, my father ran out of both the above and the bird noulted twice before I could obtain any more. Now that it is back >n the mixture the bird seems to be regaining some of the scarlet and is edder now than he was last year at this time. The same thing held rue for a male Red-rumped Tanager which never lost any of the brilliant ed colour of his rump after five years in my collection. Along with the two above items the following things are also fed. V jar of peanut butter, two jars each in the two larger aviaries, is kept n front of them at all times, also a bowl of sunflower seed and raw jeanuts mixed together. Soaked currants and soaked raisins, for he larger birds, are given fresh daily, as is fruit. The small birds receive resh honey-water daily and three times a week five drops of Zyma- Irops and ABCD drops are added. This gives the birds much of the dtamins and minerals which they do not get otherwise. Twice a week :anned dog food, a brand with no gravy, is given to all the birds, vlilk sop is fed once a week during the hot months and twice a week luring the colder months of the year. It is made in the following
algorithms.equation: vay :-- # quart of Grade A Milk. 2 (two) tablespoons of Honey. i (one) ,, ,, Armour Beef Extract. 5 (five) drops of Zymadrops. 5 ,, >, ,, ABCD drops.
algorithms.bodyText: This is then heated until thoroughly mixed, and cooled before being ed. Every other week they receive a bowl of cottage cheese, of which hey are extremely fond. Occasionally they are also given cooked peas ind diced beet and carrots. During the various seasons of the year many wild berries are to be tad and a bowl is always kept full in all the aviaries. The rest of their eeding consists of fruit. Being fortunate in having a little acreage md a good climate we are able to grow some fruit trees which produce enough for home consumption as well as for the birds. We have ig, avacado, persimmon, apricot, orange, plum, peach, and nectarine rees on the place. Apple, banana, and tomato is purchased the year iround, and pear, grapes, melon, and cantaloup are purchased when n season. All the fruit is eaten by all the birds, but the inhabitants

R. E. B. BROWN-BREEDING TANAGERS of the " glass house " will not touch plums, peaches, nectarines, melons, or cantaloup. Once a week we purchase two lug crates froir. the market of apples, tomatoes, and bananas, and the other fruii mentioned above when in season. This costs us seventy-five cents s week. This fruit is not saleable to the public because it is somewhat damaged but for the birds it is perfect and I have never lost one bird because of bad fruit. The fruit is kept in a separate ice box in the garage and stays perfectly good for a week. This then is the extent of what I feed my birds. I have a little ovei 200 softbills and the cost of feeding them ranges from ten to fourteer dollars a month, which I feel is very cheap. I hope that this article will be of interest to the members and thai more will write on the adventures of their birds. The keeping of bird; is a greatly expanding hobby and pastime and the more interest the more we can learn. As for myself, as each day passes I find out some- thing new in the habits of the birds or how better I may take can of them. It is up to each member to support the Magazine, for I an sure that each one of us has learned much by reading its pages.

By R. E. B. Brown (Newcastle, N.S.W., Australia) At the end of the war an absolute ban was imposed by the Veterinary Authority on the importation of all birds into Australia, for fear of th( introduction of Fowl Pest, or Newcastle Disease. This is said to bt widespread in the world, but has never occurred in Australia. Th( ban, coming when it did, at the end of the war, found our aviarie: much depleted with regard to foreign birds as, of course, none hac been imported during the war. Although I am of the opinion tha Australian birds are second to none, both in beauty and interest, it i: sad to be cut off from many old friends among the foreigners. At the time I had three red Tanagers, a pair of Scarlet (Brazilian) and a hen Maroon, so I thought I would try to breed a domestic race of these birds. In this I have had some success. I have now brec them to seven generations, and have four main kinds, pure Scarlet obvious hybrids, Maroon with a dash of Scarlet, and Scarlet with # dash of Maroon. I have others showing various degrees of mixec blood. The hybrids are very beautiful birds. I first paired the Scarlets together, and next summer mated theii son to the hen Maroon. A point of interest is that I successfully mated him before he came into colour ; he had white patches on hi beak, but was quite brown. The hybrids are fully fertile, and Maroor is dominant over Scarlet. The Tanagers are all perfectly tame witl people they know, but it is surprising how they can distinguisl strangers.
algorithms.reference: R. E. B. BROWN-BREEDING TANAGERS
algorithms.bodyText: These birds are kept in open garden aviaries with natural trees owing in them, and no other shelter is necessary in this climate ; have never been able to persuade them to go to nest in anything but living natural tree. They will live in small aviaries, but will not eed, and they do not look well in them, and tend to lose their ight red colour. The smallest aviary I have ever successfully bred em in is 18 feet long, 6 feet wide, and 6 feet high, with a privet tree one end and a shelter at the other. But they do much better in rger aviaries ; the larger the better. My largest is 25 feet long, ; feet wide, and 12 feet high. When breeding only one pair of anagers can be kept in an aviary, but they do not interfere with her birds. My birds are fed on softbill mixture to which freshly grated hard- hied egg is added to the daily ration. Fruit is, of course, essential, id I always provide banana, apple, pear, and orange, and paw-paw, apes, and mangoes, etc., in season. In a country where fruit is hard get, banana and one other fruit would be enough, but the birds ould always have green food, grit, and crushed egg shells. They ould also have insects daily. They like white ants themselves, but ill not feed the young on them. I think I should describe the breeding of these closely related >ecies together, merely mentioning the differences. They both lild cup-shaped nests of grass, small twigs, teased rope, and cotton ool. They often place broad leaves on the bottom of the nest. The :arlet builds a very strong nest, the Maroon a much weaker one. get over this by giving the hen Maroon some cotton wool, noting here she puts this, and placing a wire gauze shape at the exact spot here she wants to build. Nearly all hens will go ahead and build 1 the wire shape. The eggs of both species are blue with reddish-brown spots, the laroon eggs being smaller ; the Scarlet often lays three eggs, the laroon never more than two. Incubation for both is twelve days, 'hilst the young are in the nest live food only is given, and most of te feeding is done by the hen. The young are coloured like the hens, hey always leave the nest on the twelfth day ; they cannot fly well this stage, but are able to hop about in the trees. As soon as they ave the nest the parents start giving them banana and soft food i well as the live food. The live food given should be varied as much as possible, the irents will not give the young white ants at all, but demand larger sects. I have on one occasion reared a nest of Scarlets on mealworms one, but much better specimens are reared if a variety is given. 3 me hens flatly refuse to feed two days running on the same insects, at simply demand a variety. My old Maroon hen, now 19 years of and still breeding, does this. I use mealworms, casemoth grubs,
algorithms.page: 98 D. WEST-BREEDING THE SUPERB PARROT IN CALIFORNIA
algorithms.bodyText: grasshoppers, mantins, crickets, spiders, and the large green gri found on privet trees, and sweet potato vines (the latter must be cut u, The green foods most relished are thistle buds and fresh lettuce. The young are not independent of the parents until three we.: after leaving the nest ; they must then be caught up or they v] interfere with the next clutch. The Scarlet Tanager cocks come ii; full colour when 12 to 15 months old, and the Maroons 10 mom to two years.
algorithms.figure: * * * BREEDING THE SUPERB PARROT IN CALIFORNIA (.Polytelis swainsonii) By David West (Montebello, Calif., U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: The breeding of three young Superb Parrots in 1955 and three age in 1956 in California has been something of an avicultural triump Doubtless members in Europe will not feel this is a very accurate a: warranted statement, but it is now some fifteen years since this beautii species has been bred in the United States. Probably I ought to say that the term " Superb " is not vu frequently used in describing Polytelis swainsonii and Barraband's is t: more commonly used name. But I have always felt that the appellatii " Superb " is wonderfully accurate for this species. The beauty] plumage and elegant shape, accompanied by its winning ways, ma: it a favourite. The only other recorded breeding of the Barraband's or Supc Parrakeet in the United States is the record by Mr. I. D. Putnam, i San Diego about 1940. The late Mr. Putnam told me that three you; were reared from this breeding. One young from this breeding wan tame male which Mr. Putnam kept for a pet ; later it passed into T hands of Mrs. Hubbell, of San Diego, and was the father of the you; hybrid Barraband's X Rock Pebblers she raised a few years ago. It is odd that this species has proved to be so difficult to breed he in America. They are easily kept in good health and always appear] be happy and contented, but somehow they just don't nest. Howev\ hybrids between male Superbs and female Crimson-wings were rearl on several occasions by the late Dr. Ralph Woods and they wu exceptionally beautiful birds. These hybrids all appeared to have bet sterile when mated back to parents or inter se. My own pair did not nest in 1952, 1953, or 1954. In each of the years the pair were obviously in breeding condition and matings a1 feedings were observed, but they never settled down to an aetd nesting. During 1955 and 1956 the male came into breeding condition sligh
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. WEST-BREEDING THE SUPERB PARROT IN CALIFORNIA
algorithms.bodyText: lead of the hen. Male Superbs display spasmodically throughout the ?ar and their display is not unamusing. Beginning in March, the male *gan calling and displaying to a rather bored and uninterested female, his process continued and late in March the female became more 'ceptive and interested. Very suddenly, in April, the female allowed le male to feed her very frequently and invited pairing. Even so, she id not visited either nest-box and did not seem to approve of either te grandfather-clock nest or the smaller box. In late April, following period of about ten days where pairings took place several times a day, Le female entered the smaller of the two boxes provided and began *sting. Incubation apparently began with the first egg and from that me until the young were about two weeks old the hen was observed lly twice. She was a perfect prospective mother and did not leave le nest when I entered the aviary to replace food, etc. During the incubation period the male would visit the nest-box and ed her. At this time the squeaking sound the hen would make when le was being fed by the male could be heard. The nest-box chosen as about 18 inches wide, 18 inches deep, and 18 inches tall--and so was sufficiently roomy to permit the male to enter and easily feed Le hen without the danger of scattering or breaking the eggs. The sound of young being fed was heard on the twenty-second day ter incubation started. From about the third day following this the ale began to enter the nest and to (apparently) feed the young as ell as the hen. As Superbs are good-sized birds the male was observed >ending an unusual amount of time eating to provide the necessary od for the family. Fruit, as apple and orange were appreciated, and ssh corn on the cob was also devoured. Greens, as poa annua or ass clippings, and the berries of the pyracantha were also given. iaked bread was given in the morning and again in the evening and ed was scattered on the aviary floor where the earth's dampness .used some of it to sprout. The aviary the parents occupied was 17 feet long, 3 feet wide, and leet tall. A shelter at one end was provided for inclement weather-- hich we do have in California ! The nest-box was hung at the edge the shelter and faced north. Rough wood chips were used as nesting aterial. A large stick was placed just below the entrance to the :sting-box and the male seemed to enjoy sitting on this perch and Iking to his mate inside the nest every now and then. He would casionally fly to the box, look inside, and then fly away--satisfied at all was well. The youngsters prospered and the mother bird brooded them very \0x25A1sely for the first two weeks. An observation of the nest revealed at three of the four eggs had hatched and that the young were -veloping nicely. About the end of the third week a second look vealed that either the mother or the father were picking the feathers

100 D. WEST-BREEDING THE SUPERB PARROT IN CALIFORNIA on the back of the babies. Since the guilty parent was unknown anc the picking was not dangerous nothing was done other than to keej hoping ! About the end of the fifth week the first two youngsters came out o the nest. They were strong on the wing and quite steady, but lookec very unattractive because their backs were all feather-picked. Tht third youngster left the nest three days later and from the very minut( she left the nest the mother began to pick her back so severely that th( youngster would bleed. Neither parent would try to feed the thirc youngster once she had left the nest (for it was a young hen) and so thi baby was taken to a friend who very kindly offered to hand-feed it fo: a few days until it was on its own. Eventually all three of the young Barraband's or Superbs wen placed together in an aviary where they have done very well. At thi time (November) they appear to be two cocks and one hen--thougl no definite red feathers have come in on the youngsters thought to b< cocks. The feathers on the back have grown in and one could not, a this time, tell that they had ever been picked. I should like to add that Mr. G. Rayson Brown was also successfu with this species during 1955 and 1956, rearing four youngsters ir I 955 at a bout the same time my breeding took place and thre( youngsters in 1956. If anyone could throw any light on the reason why the female picket the youngsters I should appreciate the information so that a recurrenci could be avoided. From past experiences with this type of thing I hav< had females pick their youngsters one year and then skip two or thret years. It certainly is an interesting problem and probably not too akii to the same problem in Budgerigars, because these larger birds do no over-nest (would that some of them would !). It is interesting to note that the Barraband's in my collection an( also Mr. Brown's have been old enough to nest for several years, bu not until this year did they attempt to do so. Now one can only hop* that other reluctant species will follow their lead.
algorithms.sectionHeader: E. EISNER-THE BENGALESE FINCH IOI THE BENGALESE FINCH
algorithms.bodyText: By Erica Eisner (Oxford, England) The Bengalese is well known as one of the hardiest and easiest to reed of the weaver-finches ( Estrildinae ) commonly kept in captivity. ; is now also showing itself to be an excellent animal for laboratory udy. The most frequent type is a piebald of brown (' chocolate ') id white, and fawn and white birds are also common. Pure white irds have been bred for a long time, but it seems to be more recently nly that ' self-coloured ' browns and fawns have been noted, idging by advertisements and the statement in a recent book ^isdon, 1953) that " I have never seen or heard of a self-coloured locolate or self-coloured fawn ", these seem to be not yet well known. The classification into piebalds and self-coloureds is in fact quite "bitrary, for there is an unbroken gradation from birds with no hite feathers through piebalds of different degree to birds with no doured feathers. The ancestral bird was surely not a piebald or a ure white, but a self-coloured bird ; this is not only obvious of self, but there is evidence for it. Taka-Tsukasa (1922) quotes a escription of the original Japanese stock, which apparently had no lain white feathers. Wild birds with an odd few white feathers are not rare, but it ould seem that natural selection keeps this tendency towards piedness ippressed, so that the normal type is maintained. A reasonable <planation for this is that birds showing clear patches of white others are more conspicuous than normals, and therefore more kely to be killed by predators. In captivity, a bird which had white athers would not only not be eliminated, but would probably be lerished as a rarity and used for selective breeding. According to 'aka-Tsukasa, the white Java Sparrow was produced in Japan from rey birds with white feathers in their wings. It seems most probable lat the Bengalese was developed similarly. The genetics of variation in the amount of white shown has not een worked out in the Bengalese, and as it undoubtedly depends pon a multiplicity of genes it would probably be extremely difficult ) do so. Such is certainly the case in the mouse. Although that nimal has been the subject of a vast amount of genetical work, it is nly in recent years that much progress has been made in the analysis f ' spotting ', i.e. of the variation in the distribution of white areas, ike that of all products of long-continued selective breeding, as hiineberg (1952, p, 65) says, the genetics of spotting in the mouse i very complex. There is little reason to hope that the Bengalese rovides an exception. On the average, the offspring of any pair of lese birds tend to be intermediate in piedness between their parents,

but exceptions to this rule are frequent. I have no experience of pure white birds, but self-coloureds can be obtained by careful selection from pairings of birds having few white feathers. In contrast to the complex problem of the genetics of piedness, that of the alternative colours is simple. When a bird has coloured feathers they are either brown or fawn, and these colours are mutually exclusive. Indeed, it is not only the plumage which shows this, for fawn-feathered birds have fawn pigment on beak and legs, and newly hatched chicks which will later grow fawn feathers have fawn coloured mouth markings and eye-balls, while future browns have the mouth markings and eye-balls dark. Incidentally, the mouth markings reflect also, though not so reliably, the future degree of piedness : self-coloureds have the complete horseshoe pattern characteristic oi the Mannikin group of the Estrildines, but future piebalds have it disrupted to a degree correlating roughly with the disruption of the plumage pattern they will later show. It is altogether evident that the genetic character of * fawn 5 is a simple Mendelian recessive to that of ' brown '. Two fawn birds mated together will invariably produce fawn offspring, and no browns. Two brown birds which are known to have had no fawn birds in their ancestry will likewise be true breeding, but brown birds can carry the factor for fawn without its being evident except from the results of breeding tests. A pure brown mated to a fawn will produce only brown offspring. If these are then mated to each other, approxi- mately one quarter of this second generation will be fawn ; if they are mated to fawn birds about one-half of the offspring will be fawn. If a pair of brown birds breed occasional fawn young, then they must both carry the factor for fawn ; if only one of a pair of brown birds has the fawn factor then that pair will never produce fawn offspring. Again, it is most probable that some wild birds do carry such recessive colour factors, but the chances are against their mating with another bird which also carries it. If this were to happen, the unusual offspring would probably have a smaller chance of survival than the normal type. In captivity, however, such recessive characters rapidly become more common by inbreeding and selection. My aim in the foregoing genetical discussion has been to clear the ground for a discussion of the ancestry of the Bengalese, which has so far constituted a very vexed question. Some accounts (e.g. Risdon, 1953) say that the breed originated in Japan, but more cautious authorities say only that it has been bred for many years in Japan, or is often bred in Japan (e.g. Neunzig, 1921). Taka-Tsukasa (1922) gives the most informative account of the history of the Bengalese. He says that according to an old Japanese book on cage birds, the original stock was imported from China " about 200 years ago ". He does not say whether these were wild birds or an already domesticated stock.
Plate i ic. Mag. 1957 A self-coloured male Bengalese courting a pied female. This shows in particular the slight markings on the belly feathers where these are not pure white. To face p. 102.
algorithms.construct: Avic. Mag. 1957 . Plate 2. Copyright J [/* 5. Haywood Fig. 2.--Skin of Bengalese Finch. This shows especially the light edges of the breast feathers and the sharply pointed tai Copyright ] [D. J. Morris Fig. i.--Bengalese Fledglings.
algorithms.bodyText: The bird on the left is a perfect self-coloured fawn, while two of the brown birds may be classed as self-coloured, although they have a few white feathers--the male of Plate ( 1 ) is one of these. Such a simple juvenile plumage is shown by many mannikins ; the dark upper parts and light belly are differentiated at about three months old. To face p . 103.

it gives a description of the original species and says that the white id fawn varieties appeared considerably later. It may therefore be id that the Bengalese breed as we know it to-day originated in pan, but from non-Japanese ancestors. The latter part of this itement is necessary also because no possible ancestral species occurs ild in Japan. What, then, was this ancestral stock ? It is quite obvious, and nerally recognized, that the Bengalese resembles the Striated and larp-tailed Finches more than it does any other. However, it is iwadays quite generally, at least in this country, supposed to be me kind of hybrid of these types and possibly also the Silverbill ; ) evidence is ever given for this view. Probably, the present acceptance of this hybrid theory stems from the eference of Dr. Butler (1894) for it. In the first two decades of this ntury, though, this view was frequently contested, and even Butler mself (1907) decided against a hybrid origin. The Bengalese was en usually thought to be a domesticated strain of the Sharp-tailed nch. For instance, the reviewer writing on p. 112 of the Avicultural [agazine for 1902--3 says : " Domestication is also responsible for . . . id white and pied forms (Bengalese) of the Sharp-tailed Finch. We Meetly agree . . . that there is no reason for supposing the latter rds to be hybrids." Recently, Steinbacher and Wolters (1956) have ritten that it is certainly wrong to suppose that the Silverbill (p. 119) an ancestor of the Bengalese which they think is most probably domesticated Sharptail (p. 142), but they do not discuss the matter, hope to give convincing evidence that this is the correct view. Possibly the Silverbill was suggested as a part ancestor in order to :plain the occurrence of fawn individuals, for the Silverbill is fawn tough of rather a different shade. The knowledge that fawn colour a mutant inherited in a perfectly normal way makes such an explana- \0x25A1n altogether unnecessary, and there is no evidence supporting it. ideed, if their statement is well established, Steinbacher and Wolters ve the strongest possible evidence against the view that the Silverbill an ancestor of the Bengalese. They state (p. 152) that although the engalese produces fertile hybrids with some Mannikins, hybrids etween the Bengalese and the Silverbill are sterile. However, especi- i\y as elsewhere (p. 119) they suggest that a hybrid between the harptail and the Silverbill can be fertile, this point should be checked. The Striated and Sharp-tailed Finches are considered to be members r the same species, Lonchura striata. (I use the generic name Lonchura "ter the most recent revision, that of Delacour (1943), although the ames Munia and Uroloncha are more frequently applied.) The iggestion that the Bengalese is a hybrid of the Striated and Sharp- liled Finches (and these do hybridize freely, according to Hopkinson, ^38) is both unnecessary and contradicted by the evidence. A

detailed account of the species is given by Stuart Baker (1926). There are two sub-specific groups which are distinguished on various grounds, the most obvious of which is the occurrence of ' lace markings ' or squamations on the belly and rump feathers. The one group, native to Ceylon and India, forms the Striated Finches ; the other, distri- buted from Nepal and Bengal to Malaya and China, consists of the Sharp-tailed Finches. My descriptions are based not only on those given by Stuart Baker and others, but also on my own examination of the collected skins in the British Museum of Natural History. In all birds of the species the head, breast, back, wings, and tail are brown, while the belly and rump are lighter. In the Striated Finches the brown is very dark, tending to be almost black on the head and breast ; the belly and rump are almost white and contrast markedly with the dark regions, especially as they show no squamations. The tail is not especially pointed, and is rather shorter relative to body size than in the Sharp-tailed Finches. The Sharptails have much less contrast between the dark and the light regions than do the Striated Finches. The brown tends to be of less deep a colour, and of a rather more reddish shade (this is not altogether clear in Stuart Baker's description, but is stated clearly by Vaurie (1949) and I have confirmed it). The appearance is further lightened because the central shafts of the brown feathers are much more conspicuously pale than in the Striated Finches, and because the edges of the breast feathers are outlined in a lighter shade. This last character is not shown by the Indian and Andaman Striated Finches but is shown by the Nicobar race. This race does, however, agree in all the other distinguishing characters, and also its limited distribution makes it unlikely to be relevant to this argument. The ground colour of the belly and rump is slightly darker in the Sharptails than in the Striated Finch ; specimens from different regions show squamations to a varying extent, and where these markings are prominent they give a grey effect. The tail, as the name implies, is very sharply pointed : each feather individually is pointed and there is a marked gradation in length towards the central, longest, feather. How, then, does the Bengalese compare with these wild birds ? The easiest comparison to make is between them and a self-coloured brown Bengalese, and it is immediately obvious that this is quite different from a Striated Finch, as from all other species, but resembles some Sharp-tailed Finches greatly. The brown colour is not as dark as that of the Striated Finches, but has the same tone as that of the Sharptails ; the belly and rump do not contrast strongly, and bear squamations. The tail is beautifully pointed. The shafts are prominent on the brown feathers, and the breast feathers have light edges. All these characters can also be seen on the brown and white piebalds, though of course there is no such striking general impression ot
