From left to right : Striated finch from Madras, India ; Sharptails from : Mussoorie, Nepal ; Henzada, Burma ; * __Penang, Malaya ; Szechuan, China ; Fukien, China ; Formosa.
algorithms.bodyText: ;imilarity. As long as one remembers that the white feathers of the \0x25A1iebald are superimposed upon the characteristic species plumage pattern, it is obvious from examination of the feathers that the Bengalese is a tame Sharp-tailed Finch, and does not have the charac- teristics of a Striated Finch or any other species. Unfortunately I have not been able to compare the Bengalese with living Sharp-tailed Finches, as these are not freely on the market. Dr. Desmond Morris (unpublished) has compared the behaviour of the Bengalese with that of the Striated Finch, and with other species af Mannikin, in detail. He found that the behaviour patterns of the Bengalese were essentially the same as those of the Striated Finch, while differing from those of the other species. It is especially note- worthy that the Bengalese has no behaviour components characteristic of the Silverbill, whose behaviour is very clearly distinct from that of the Striated Finch. It is a pity that we do not know how far, if at all, the behaviour of the Sharp-tailed Finch differs from that of the Striated Finch ; one would expect that any difference which may exist would be very slight. Mr. William Bain, vice-chairman of the National Bengalese Fanciers' Association, wrote to me that " the Sharp-tailed Mannikin closely resembles the Bengalese in shape, size and mannerisms I think there can be little doubt that the Bengalese is a domesticated form of a Sharp-tailed Finch, i.e. that it is a member of the aculicauda subgroup of Lonchura striata. This view has frequently been expressed in the past, and I believe the evidence necessitates its acceptance in place of the theory of hybrid origin. It is less easy to say from where exactly the ancestral stock must have come. The most comprehensive account of the L. s. acuticauda group, that of Stuart Baker (1926), is rather unsatisfactory. This account recognizes three subspecies : L. s. acuticauda itself from Nepal and Bengal, L. s. subsquamicollis from Burma, Indo-China, Malaya and Sumatra, and L. s. squamicollis from China. The distinction depends largely on two characters : the nature of the light edges to the breast feathers, and the strength of the markings on the belly feathers. However, as so often happens, the natural populations do not fall clearly into separate groups, but instead there seems to be a continuous change between one area and another ; such continuous change can never be shown by the usual type of classification. The majority of the British Museum specimens from the Indian end of the range are admittedly like Baker's L. s. acuticauda , which is described as having breast feathers with rufous edges and only faint squamations. Similarly, birds from peninsular Siam and Malaya have strong squamations and conspicuous pale edges to the breast feathers, in accordance with the description of L. s. subsquamicollis. But birds from areas in between, such as Burma, are quite clearly

South-East Asia : The region in which Lonchura striata occurs wild. intermediate. leakers description becomes much more seriously inadequate for birds from regions eastwards of Indo-China, for it does not suggest that there is a comparable trend of change across China. The description of L. s. squamicollis applies well to birds from the West China province of Szechuan. These have very heavily marked belly feathers and very clearly defined broad pale edges to the bi east feathers, which are of a yet lighter brown than those of the otliei sub-species. This characteristic type of breast feather is shown by all specimens from China but birds from the east coast provinces, especially f ukien in the south-east, again have less strong squamations. .The belly feathers ol these birds are comparable to those of specimens hom lower Burma, but their brown feathers are distinctive in being consideiably paler. Birds from Formosa have even less clear squama- tions, and also their brown feathers are of a slightly richer tone than that of the Chinese mainland birds ; this has previously been pointed out by La louche (1925)5 ar *d Oberholser (1926) has even created a subspecies for the Formosan type of Sharptail. The Formosan specimens are in fact extremely similar to birds from Nepal, the only 1 easonably apparent difference being in their having slightly more conspicuous pale edges on the breast feathers.

The Bengalese clearly does not resemble the birds from the central art of the Sharp-tailed Finch's range, for it never has such strong [uamations. The common name of ' Bengalese Finch ' might be msidered as circumstantial evidence of origin from the Bengal area, ut this would be extremely unreliable. The name c Bengali ' w r as riginally applied to the Cordon-bleu from Africa and may have een a corruption of Benguela. It was later used indiscriminately i the bird trade for many of the weaver-finches, and was then istricted to the Pied Mannikin as a result of Dr. Butler's influence ?low r er, 1906). It would be interesting to know what the Japanese ernacular name for this bird signifies. It seems much more likely lat the ancestral stock came from South-East China and/or Formosa. aka-Tsukasa says that the original Japanese stock came from China nd that the feathers of the abdomen were " white with pale, dusky reaks Amongst my own stock of Bengalese, comprising over a undred birds, the intensity of these streaks is rather variable, but >ems to be usually less strong than that of the Fukien specimens hile stronger than that of specimens from Formosa, to which that rovince is nearest. Specimens from other parts of China, whether om the Shanghai region further north along the coast or westwards, 11 have too strong markings. As the breast feathers of the Bengalese re clearly of the Chinese type, with conspicuous pale edges and of a ather pale brown, I think it must be concluded that the ancestors of ae Bengalese most probably came from this South-East China region. In summary, the Bengalese is a domesticated form of Sharp-tailed inch which was developed in Japan from stock probably originating 1 South-East China or Formosa. There is no reason whatsoever to appose that it is a hybrid of the Sharp-tailed Finch with any other *ird.

I am most grateful for the help given me by Mr. J. D. Macdonald nd the staff of the British Museum Bird Room, and by Mr. W. Bain nd Mr. N. Tolmaer of the National Bengalese Fanciers' Association, would like to thank especially Dr. A. J. Cain and Dr. D. J. Morris Dr their encouragement and advice, and Dr. Morris and Mr. J. S. laywood for the photographs. I am extremely indebted to the Nuffield Foundation to whom I owe my apparatus and birds.

By J. J. Yealland A White-necked Picathartes has been received from Sierra Leone as a present from Mr. J. I. Menzies who hand-reared the bird from a nestling. He fed it on small frogs, lizards, mealworms, grasshoppers, insectile food, and minced lean meat. It is now living with the one collected by the first " Zoo Quest " in 1954, and is, of course, only the second living specimen to be brought from Africa. Like the first specimen, this young bird has several filoplumes on the top of the other- wise bald head. The Grey-necked Picathartes brought by Mr. Webb from British Cameroon during 1948 continues to thrive. Other gifts are a Citril Finch from Mr. W. Schenck, two White- throated and one Red-throated Humming Birds from Mr. Randau, an Indian Broad-billed Roller and a Loo Choo, or Lidth's Jay from Messrs. Brooke Bond and Go., a Fohkien Grey-headed Crow-Tit from Mr. G. H. Newmark and a small number of various insectivorous Indian birds, of which a Black-naped Oriole is the most noteworthy, from Mr. C. E. Engledew. A fine Masai Ostrich has been received in exchange from the Bristol Zoo and a Pileated Kingfisher has been deposited. The Cormorant hatched on about the 20th of February is now fully grown and flying. A second nest has been built and probably contains eggs. A Gannet's egg is being incubated in the same aviary. Three Black-footed Penguins, five blue-bred green Masked Lovebirds, and two Gockatiels have been bred. Four Swinhoe's Pheasant chicks have been hatched and are being reared by the parents which success- fully reared two last year. It is a pity that this handsome pheasant is

>t more widely kept, for, like the Mikado, it is found only on Formosa id may be in danger of extinction there. Great Eagle-Owl, Spotted Eagle-Owl, Maned Goose, and Impeyan aeasant are the most noteworthy of the birds now incubating eggs, he " Homing " Budgerigars are, of course, breeding, not all of them . the boxes provided, for several pairs are nesting in the trees about Le Gardens and in Regent's Park. The Reeves deposited by the Norfolk Naturalists' Trust last autumn ave now been sent to the Cley marshes.
The fifty-seventh meeting of the Club was held at the Rembrandt [otel, Thurloe Place, South Kensington, S.W. 7, on Wednesday, th May, 1957, following a dinner at 7 p.m.

algorithms.bodyText: Members of the Club, 32 ; guests, 12 ; total, 44. Mrs. Rosemary Upton showed slides to illustrate " Some Shetland firds ". But let it not be supposed that this was just another talk on he Islands' birds, illustrated by the inevitable series of slides of little nterest to anyone other than the photographer. Mrs. Upton revisited the Shetlands in May--June, 1955? with the :xpress purpose of photographing the Whimbrel and its nest. In this he succeeded admirably, and procured a fine series of photographs )f a pair of nesting birds and a complete record of the hatching of bur chicks. The time from when the first egg starred to that of the ast chick leaving the nest was 46 hours--no less than 32 of which Mrs. Upton spent in observation. We were also shown excellent pictures of the Great Skua and its nest, Arctic Skua, Dunlin, Red- :hroated Diver, and others. Enjoyable though the pictures were, the

speaker's amusing description, enhanced by humorous sketches, < how they were obtained, greatly added to the enjoyment. Altogethi it was a very happy blend of scientific information and enjoyab narrative. E. N. T. Vane deserves a special credit for the efficient way in whic he handled the projector. Arthur A. Prestwich, Hon. Secretary.

An overseas visitor recently exclaimed, " Why, there's the Magazine all in one row, I never saw that before ! " Actually, it is not in on< row but in three ; the 62 volumes occupying 7 ft. 2 in. of shelf space- 18 volumes, 20 inches, to the credit of our present Editor.

Frank A. Hartman, of the Ohio State University, writes : "I kep a pair of Sparrow Hawks in a cage in the laboratory for more thai ten years. The female laid eggs and incubated them, but they neve: hatched because apparently they were not fertile. These birds wen taken from the nest and kept in a flight-cage throughout life."

G. A. Gjessing, Drammen, Norway, reports an interesting event. In January his Rock Pebblers started to lay on the ground of the flight. I he egg was put in a box on the ground and three further eggs were added to it. On the 10th February the first of three chicks was hatched, and all three, possibly one male and two females, are now fully independent. The temperature during this time was down to 20 0 F. in the heated shelter and about o* F. outside.

algorithms.bodyText: 'igeons have laid several eggs, but only one pair of Pied is sitting in arnest : Major V. Dilwyn Jones, Red-bellied Conure, three young >nes in the nest and three eggs still to hatch : Kenneth Russell, Senegal Parrots, two eggs failed to hatch, contained well-developed mbryos.

Some of our members do not seem to be familiar with the universally ccepted rules governing the publication of notes and papers. When writer submits a paper to a journal for publication, it is understood hat he has not submitted it to any other journal, and will not do so inless it is rejected by the first recipient. Our Editor has recently received several items it was intended to >ublish, only to find them appearing in other publications. Editors
algorithms.listItem: enerally do their best to prevent duplication, but such is occasionally "eyond their endeavours, and the same paper appears in more than ne journal. We trust our contributors will lessen our Editor's worries *y submitting only original matter. A. A. P.
algorithms.sectionHeader: REVIEWS >IRD WONDERS OF AUSTRALIA. By A. H. Chisholm. Fourth
algorithms.bodyText: edition revised and enlarged. Angus and Robertson, London, 1956. Price 25^-. net. As the author states in the preface, this is not intended as a text- >ook of Australian birds, but its purpose is to present a factual, gossipy ccount of the " Believe-it-or-not " features of Australia's remarkable *ird life. The book is divided into two sections--Biographical and General--and in the first part all the outstanding groups of Australian >irds have been dealt with. Aviculturists will find much of interest oncerning the habits in the wild of the birds they have known only a captivity, and many will wish that the chapter " The Land of 'arrots " had been longer. Though admittedly a popular book, it ontains a wealth of information, and many problems are explained a a clear and concise manner. To quote the titles of some of the hapters in the second section--" Good neighbours--sometimes a study of the relations of birds and man in Australia) " ; " Queer elations of birds and insects " ; " Carrying the baby in birdland "-- ;ive some idea of the diversity of aspects of bird life the author deals vith. The final chapter, " To settle an argument," is devoted to

discussion of various questions concerning birds which have bee raised by correspondence during the author's conduct of Natui columns in various newspapers. There are 64 photographic illustn tions and a coloured photograph frontispiece. P. B-S.
algorithms.sectionHeader: SOME COMMON AUSTRALIAN BIRDS. By Alan Bell wit
algorithms.bodyText: drawings by Shirley Bell. Published by the Oxford Universil Press. London, 1956. Price 35J. net. This small handbook contains descriptions and illustrations of ju; over a hundred of the 650 or more birds native to Australia. As th author states in his introduction, the book is designed to help peopj in the more closely settled parts of Australia to recognize birds the may see at home in the garden or during a day's outing. In eac species the range and salient points of its appearance on a brief vie 1 is given, and followed by more detailed description and an accounl in somewhat picturesque language, of habits, behaviour nest, et" The illustrations have been executed with the aim of giving an impre, sion which will help in quick identification. Some are good but othei are out of drawing. Eleven species of the Parrot family have bee included, but the illustrations of some of these are not very happy.
algorithms.table: B. B. F. * * * NOTES Song of Violet-eared Waxbill I feel I owe an apology to the charming little Violet-eared Waxbill for saying ; my book, Foreign Bird Keeping, that it has nothing much in the way of a song. Whe I wrote this I had not kept the species since before the war, and I still cannot rememb:
algorithms.bodyText: that the male of a pair in breeding condition we then had was much of a songster-1: but it is a long time ago ; I should say about 1935. Now, however, we have a pair that have just gone to nest, and the exquisite beaui' of the cock is quite matched by the beauty of his song. When one thinks of small foreign seed-eating songsters one's thoughts natural s turn to members of the Serin family and chiefly perhaps to the well-known Gree'i and Grey Singing Finches--both delightful songsters--particularly the latter. Waxbills, on the other hand, are not remarkable for their song, so it is all jtll more unexpected that the Violet-eared should have such a fine one. Its song, thougc perhaps rather more varied, is remarkably like that of the Skylark, and if it had til same astonishing volume in relation to the bird's size as is the case with the Gre Singing Finch, I have little doubt that it would be acknowledged as one of the finei,: songsters of all the small seed-eaters. Edward J. Boosey.

The Ostriches at the Age of Six IVIonths
algorithms.sectionHeader: WICULTURAL MAGAZINE THE JOURNAL OF THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY AND THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA
algorithms.bodyText: _ ill. 63.--No. 4 .--All rights reserved. JULY-AUGUST, 1957 -
algorithms.sectionHeader: OTES ON CAPTIVE-BRED OSTRICHES AT THE BASEL ZOOLOGICAL GARDEN
algorithms.bodyText: By Dr. H. Wackernagel (Basel, Switzerland) During 3rd-gth September, 1956, eleven healthy Ostriches were Ltched at the Basel Zoo after an incubation period of 47-53 days. ie clutch of sixteen eggs was incubated by the parent birds them- slves. Seven eggs were placed in an incubator after 38, and the imaining eggs after 48, days of incubation, because of the cold and iny weather. Four eggs did not hatch. They proved to be infertile or 1 ntained dead embryos. One Ostrich hatched under the parents was !und dead in the nest. The newly hatched chicks were placed in a odified poultry house which serves mainly for raising birds. It has wooden floor, big windows to the south, and access to a lawn. The )or was covered with sand and the room was heated by infra-red mps to a temperature of 25*~30* C. At the beginning the tempera- re was never allowed to fall below 20 C. The little birds soon emed to find places under the lamps where they felt comfortable, key were left without food for about two days, then dishes were put Fore them containing chopped fresh alfalfa, carrots, leaves of indelion and, at times, lettuce. In addition, they were given a dieted all-mash mixture designed for pullets, containing about \[ per cent of crude protein, Spratt's Weetmeet, some hard-boiled egg, id crushed Ostrich-eggshell. From the beginning the green stuff, pecially alfalfa, was much liked but the pellets, too, were accepted increasing quantities and we feel that we owe much of our success this well-balanced diet. Water was offered about twice daily and the rds took to it most of the time, but we do not think that it is essential, t first the birds seemed quite avid for their own droppings but this ibit was soon lost. Anyone who has tried raising Ostriches knows how uch devotion and skill it takes to induce these birds to eat sufficient

I 14 H. WACKERNAGEL-NOTES ON CAPTIVE-BRED OSTRICHES quantities of food. When left alone they will walk about, peck now am then at conspicuous objects, and finally die of starvation. In captivit' someone has to take the place of a parent bird, not only during the firs days but for a number of weeks, and knock at the dish or the floo where the food is placed, or move the food in the dish or let it drop ir front of the birds, etc. It will pay to take this trouble. Of course, it i easier to raise a whole flock, but even so the mutual stimulation doe not seem to suffice. I often put this sentence in my notes : " Now i seems that the birds will soon settle by themselves "--but invariably i proved necessary or at least advantageous to keep them company. B\ touching the bellies it was possible to find out if they were duly filled It seems to be advisable to keep them company up to the age of aboui three to four months. Our birds developed nicely and never caused much worry. On sunny days they were allowed to exercise freely in the open, which stimulatec their appetite and made them less excitable. Furthermore, plenty o exercise seems desirable for sound development. On the lawn the birds revealed their herbivorous nature by pulling out and eating grass, denuding whole areas of growth down to the ground. Eating, sleeping, and preening were performed at regular periods. Feeding was most intensive during the two to three hours before sunset and stimulating the birds during this time of the day is considered most effective. In other words : the opportunity of obtaining full bellies in the evening should not be missed. One of the birds was lost at the age of about three weeks. It had not eaten for about two days and the dissection revealed its intestines heavily filled with small pebbles. We do not know, however, if this was the actual cause of death. When the birds were about two months of age the pellets could be offered dry in a separate dish and a calculated dose of a calcium- phosphorus-vitamin-D-preparation was given in addition. At that age the daily allowance per bird was about i kg. of chopped vegetables (mostly alfalfa) and about half a pound of pellets and Spratt's Weet- meet. I he daily exercise on the lawn was never discontinued, in spite of the increasingly cooler weather and occasional fall of rain and snow. Gold alone did not seem to hurt the birds when they were exposed, as long as they kept moving. The birds obviously enjoyed these outings, mostly indulging in lively dances. Room temperature often fell below 20* G. As the birds grew bigger enormous quantities of food were eaten. In December cabbage was introduced in place of alfalfa, which was not available any more, and the pellets were given as the only concentrate. Consumption then amounted to about i kg. of concentrate and at least twice that amount of vegetables per bird per day. Dancing was often performed in the stable, too, which occasionally
algorithms.sectionHeader: BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADISE I 15
algorithms.bodyText: tused skin lesions and bruises on the birds and broken windows in the hiding. The windows consequently had to be screened by wire itting. We did not worry about the birds' injuries at first, taking them a sign of health and vigour, but after a while it became necessary to ove the birds to larger quarters. In February the Antelope House icame the new home of the birds, which had almost attained the iight of a man. After a few days of excitement and decreased food msumption the Ostriches settled down nicely. Soon the appetite as regained and in March the daily consumption of each bird had sen to 2 kg. of pellets and about 7 kg. of vegetables. "They continue develop into splendid specimens, pleasing their keepers by their me and mannerly conduct.
algorithms.table: * * * >N THE DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF THE KING IRD OF PARADISE, CICINNURUS REGIUS REX (SCOP.) IN CAPTIVITY By Sten Bergman (Ronninge, per Stockholm, Sweden)
algorithms.bodyText: sprinted by kind permission from NOVA GUINEA. New Ser., Vol. 7, Part 2, "th November, 1956. The King Bird of Paradise, Cicinnurus regius (Linnaeus), is certainly le of the most magnificent birds of the world. The vermilion colouring ' the head and upper parts of the body, shimmering with every move- ent, is of a supreme beauty. Even more remarkable are the adorn- ents with which the male bird is furnished : the two superbly seeping tail wires, each tipped with a gleaming, spirally curved disc. 1 addition, there are the brown, fan-like side-plumes bordered with nerald green, which lie folded under each wing and can be spread it at will. Although the King Bird of Paradise was given its name by Linnaeus . 1758, its life and habits in the tropical jungle are still very little lown. When Hartert, in 1910, wrote an article about those Birds of aradise whose eggs were at that time known (Novitates %oologies , 17 : I4-490), he expressed his surprise that nobody had succeeded in ading the nest of Cicinnurus , since in certain parts of its range in New uinea and on a few neighbouring islands the bird is not, after all, > rare. At the end of March, 1929, however, Wilfred Frost discovered the rst and, as far as I know, hitherto only known nest. Phis find revealed Le quite unexpected fact that the King Bird was a hole-breeder in intrast to all other species of Birds of Paradise, which have open -sts. The nest found by Frost was built in a small tree, about 7 feet om the ground. He describes the nest as follows : " The nest hole

I I 6 S. BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADIS was small, about i^ inches in diameter, and approximately 18 inch deep, but filled to within a few inches of the lip with palm fibre. Th eggs, two in number, measuring 27-5 X 21 mm., were of a cream white, flushed with pink, typically marked and curiously resembliru except for size, those of Paradiscea apodal (Avicultural Magazine (4), 8 33 - 5 5 i 93 * 0 < The first live Birds of Paradise which came to Europe--two Parc discea minor --were brought home in 1862 by Alfred Russel Wallac and placed in the London Zoo, where a number of different specie have since been kept, as in many other Zoological Gardens. Up to the present, no Bird of Paradise has been bred in Europe although some instances of egg-laying have occurred. As far as I know the only species which has ever successfully bred in captivity befor 1956 is " Empress of Germany's Bird of Paradise " (. Paradiscea apod augusicevictorice Gabanis), of which in 1942 one young was reared h Prince Dharmakumarsinhji's aviarium in Bhavnagar, India (^oologica New York, 28 : 139-144, 1943). In the Zoo of Surabaia, on Java a King Bird of Paradise, according to Frost, laid two eggs which wen hatched out, but the young died in the nest. The same female late laid one more egg but failed to incubate it (. Avicultural Magazine (4), 8 33 ~ 5 > ^S 0 )* I his, as far as I know, is the only attempt made by < King Bird to breed in captivity before 1956. When returning to Sweden from two journeys to Dutch New Guinea in 1948--49 and i952~53 ornithological research, I was permittee by the Dutch authorities to bring to Sweden a number of live Birds 0 Paiadise for the purpose of continuing my studies and observations or these birds and, il possible, to make breeding experiments with them for my first permit I am much indebted to my colleague of the 1948-4C expedition, Dr. M. A. Lieftinck, then Director of the Zoologica Museum in Bogor, Java. For my second permit I have to thank II.fi. the Governor ol Dutch New Guinea, Dr. J. van Baal, the formei resident of West New Guinea, Mr. L. L. A. Maurenbrecher, and Professor Dr. L. F. de Beaufort. Among my Birds of Paradise were some male King Birds, Cicinnurus regius rex (Scopoli). I did not, however, succeed in bringing home any female of this species, but through the courtesy of Director S* van Reesema and Ir. F. J. Appelman, of the Rotterdam Zoo, I was permitted to exchange one male Cicinnurus for a female of the same species. In October, 1955, this female was joined with a male that had just changed its plumage and the pair was allotted a space of i7^m 3 in my house. 1 he room was planted with a number of Monstera , Ficus, Bougainvillea , and other tropical plants. The floor was covered partly with sand and partly with moss. 1 he room had a constant temperature of 25 C., legulated by thermostat, and the necessary moisture was
algorithms.sectionHeader: BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADISE I I 7
algorithms.bodyText: ected by squirting all plants and the moss with water every day. vo sides of the room were lighted by two double windows on each le and two electric tube lights were burning in the King Bird's room : twelve hours a day--from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.--all the year round. As nesting sites a vertical log and two nest-boxes were installed. All e three nesting sites had different-sized entrance holes. Shortly after the male bird had been let into the female's room, in lich she had spent over three months waiting for him to finish his oult, he started his courting. He knew her well, since their rooms id been separated only by wire mesh. He began his courtship by raising his tail and tail wires forward until ey lay at right-angles to the length of the body. He then spread out s wings so that they were slightly cupped, as shown in Plate 4. arning towards the female, he constantly vibrated his wings, which ere soon spread out to their full length. Suddenly he changed his display completely. Instead of sitting on e branch the next instant he was hanging upside-down with his feet inging to it. His wings were still fully expanded and vibrating. The 11 was open, so that the yellow-green gape was plainly visible. After hanging in this manner for nearly ten seconds he closed his ings and, still in a hanging position, swung his body from left to right r a few seconds. He then released his hold, dropped a short distance, id flew on to the branch. Some days later, at 11 a.m., the male bird was singing. The song is mewhat similar to the song of the skylark, although not so loud, /hen the male bird sings, the discs of the tail wires are in constant otion. Whilst he was singing the female flew over and sat on a ranch near to him. He then expanded his wings and vibrated them. He moved closer " her and sat on the same branch. Then he began displaying in the $ual manner, i.e. he expanded the fans and drew them up towards is head, as shown in Plates 2 and 3. At the same time he puffed out le white feathers of the underside, so as to become almost spherical, veeping his tail wires up over his back as illustrated by the photographs 1st mentioned. His head was raised obliquely upwards and constantly vayed slightly from side to side. During this display the male sat with his back turned towards the male. She moved nearer to him, so that she was at a distance ol pproximately 5 cm. from him. While he was displaying she ccasionally picked at his feathers. All through the winter the male was observed displaying for the male almost every day and sometimes several times a day. I he most sual time for the display was in the morning hours between 8 and 1 o nd in the afternoons from 3 to 4. This applies to the winter months. )uring the summer months the birds were not excluded from the

I l8 S. BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADIS Swedish summer daylight, which during the lightest period, in June lasts for approximately twenty-one hours out of the twenty-four, i the Stockholm area. In their native country Birds of Paradise are used to approximatel a twelve-hour day and a twelve-hour night. During the winter month in Sweden, where, in the Stockholm area, there is only about six and ; half hours' daylight at the darkest period, the birds were, as alread mentioned, exposed to twelve hours of artificial light. I have neve noticed that they suffered any inconvenience from the long daylight ii summer. As a compensation, they took one or several naps during th day. During the summer, also, the display-times have been assigned t< the same time as in the winter, but the variations in regard to the tim. have been greater. The most frequent way of display of the King Bird is illustrated 01 Plates 2 and 3 ; in exceptional cases it continued for two minutes, bu usually it was considerably shorter. When the male is really in th< mood for display he repeats his performance many times and it may b< observed at any time of the day, or in the evening. When the display has continued for a while in the normal manner with outspread fans and upbent tail wires, often the male will suddenh turn round and continue the performance in the opposite direction Usually he alters his display after this complete turn, so that the fan; are drawn in under the wings and the bird, with wide-open beak sways his tail from side to side in the manner shown in Plate 1 A departure from this attitude is that the fans remain expanded whik the tail wires are swayed from side to side. The body remains stationar) during this display. Since 10th October, when male and female were placed together. I have seen the inverted display many times during the course of the winter and spring. Members of my family have also sometimes seen this display on other occasions and, without doubt, the male often performed his inverted display when he was not under observation. I he first part of the upside-down exhibit usually continues for five to ten seconds and the second phase, when he hangs with closed wings and sways from side to side, takes a similar amount of time. But on one occasion he hung with closed wings, completely motionless, for almost one minute. 1 he various forms of display which I have observed agree in all essentials with those described by Ingram for a bird kept in captivity (The Ibis (9), 2 : 223-9, 1907). During the course of the spring the female began to show increasing interest in one of the nest-boxes, the one with the largest entrance hole (diameter 8-5 cm.). In the middle of December, 1955, she had been observed for the first time to sit in the entrance hole and look in and a few days later she went inside. During the four following months she made short, sporadic visits to the nest-box. In May, 1936, however, she
algorithms.sectionHeader: BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADISE I I 9
algorithms.bodyText: ew in almost every day, and sometimes she would stay in the nest-box .r half an hour to a few hours. I provided the nest-box with moss, ried fern leaves, and very thin grass so as to imitate a kind of nest, loreover I put fern leaves and dried grass into the birdroom. The male accepted this nest but completed it with the finest grass straws le could find in the aviary. In connection with her growing interest in the nest, the male became lore ardent in his courtship. On the 24th May the male chased the \0x25A0male from branch to branch. She moved slowly out of his way. Now nd then she stopped and for the first time I saw her sitting in mating osition with her body lowered against the branch and her tail raised, ler head was pointed in an upward direction in exactly the same lanner as the male's during the normal display. But when the male ame near she flew away again. This happened several times. As soon s the male saw her take up this position he immediately flew to her, ut she continued to avoid him. Consequently no mating took place. After the male had been pursuing the female for some time he isplayed in inverted position, but even this acrobatic performance did ot lead to any mating. On 11 th June the female was in the nest-box the whole morning. Vhen I left home at 10 a.m. to drive 30 km. into Stockholm she was till inside the nest-box. The male displayed outside the nest-box in the lorning, although the female could not see the performance. At noon ay wife telephoned me to say that there was an egg in the nest-box. Vhen I returned in the afternoon the female had come out and was ating. I then went in and looked into the nest-box, which was so onstructed that part of the front could be swung open by means of i hinge. The egg was exceptionally large in comparison with the bird and >roved to be a typical Bird of Paradise egg : cream-coloured, with mmerous chocolate-brown streaks on the large end. The female >rotested strongly when I approached the nest and she continued to :xpress her discontent all the time that I was inside her room. She lew right up to me at the nest to see what I was doing. Since there had been no egg in the nest the previous evening and as he female had not spent the night in the nest-box, the egg must have )een laid either in the early morning or forenoon ol 1 ith June. As the emale was in the nest-box all through the day of the 11 th, except when mating outside, the incubation must have started as soon as the egg was aid. The following day I did not see her when she came out to eat and, is I naturally did not want to drive her out of the nest-box to see il she lad laid another egg, it was not until the 13 th June that I was able to iscertain that two eggs were present in the nest. During the incubation the male bird sat almost continuously on a branch close beside the nest-box. He would occasionally stretch his

S. BERGMAN DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADIS head to have a look, but he was never seen to enter the nest-box h therefore never relieved the female during the incubation, neither di he give her food during this period. On the other hand, he displayed diligently for her in the neighboui hood of the nest, partly in the usual manner, with expanded fans an tail-wires erected over his back, and partly, on many occasions, in th inverted position. He also repeatedly sat on a branch in front of th nest-box and vibrated with expanded wings directly outside th entrance hole, so that the female could not avoid seeing his courting. On numerous occasions he sang his bubbling song right outside th nest-box while the female was incubating. When she came out to ea or to take a bath, he took the opportunity to look at the eggs and, later at the nestlings, through the entrance hole. As part of my preparations for eventual breeding I had placed i bowl of finely crushed shells in the King Bird's room.' Before laying he: eggs, I had often seen the female eating these shells, but during the incubation period I never saw her swallow any pieces of shell when sht came out to eat. After the eggs were hatched and the young birds wen in urgent need of calcium for bone-formation, she ate the shells several times a day. During the incubation period the female came out three or four times a day to eat. As a general rule, she also took a bath once a da\ and preened her feathers very carefully. The length of her visits to the ee mg place varied from a few to forty-three minutes, which was the longest absence from the eggs that I observed. On that occasion the female, after she had fed, had a thorough bath and then preened her leathers for such a long time that both the male bird and I began to be nervous about the eggs. All the time the male sat beside the nest-box and repeatedly uttered his call of enticement : a-a-a-a-a (pronounced as in English) when she seemed in no hurry to return to the eggs. I had not seen the birds mate, and I dared not take the eggs out of the nest to see if they were fertile. It was therefore with eager expectation that I waited to see if there would be any results at the time I had estimated. On the morning of 28th June, after seventeen days, the eggs were still un latched. At 3 p.m., when she came out to feed, I again inspected the nest-box and to my great joy found a newly-hatched, dark red little t ling anc one egg in the nest. 1 he egg-shell was not in the nest but was found at the other end of the aviary. I immediately went out to find fresh " ants' eggs " (more properly tie pupae of ants enclosed in their cocoons), which are the finest food one can give to an insect-eating bird. In an ant-heap about 10 km. 10m my house I succeeded in obtaining a good portion, which the lemale readily consumed. At 7 o'clock the following morning I looked into the nest-box and
tc. Mag. 1957.

algorithms.sectionHeader: COURTSHIP ATTITUDE OF ClCINNVRUS REGIUS REX (ScOPOLl), TAKING POSITION IN FRONT OF THE FEMALE WITH OUT- STRETCHED QUIVERING WINGS.
algorithms.figure: Plate 5 0pyright ] Young King Birds of Paradise in the nest. SIX DAYS OLD. [Sten Bergman One is five, the other
Plate 6 Avic. Mag. i Copyright] TWO PICTURES OF YOUNG ClCINNURUS , FOURTEEN AND IN THE NEST. [Sten Bergmc
Mag. 1957 Plate 7 , . , , [Sten Bergman pynght] Female Cicinnurus , approaching and feeding her young, which in these pictures are twenty-one and twenty-two da\ s old. IK
algorithms.table: Plate 8 Avic. Mag. Young Cicinnurxjs nineteen days old. Copyright] [S tcn B, rEMALE ClCINNURUS WITH HER YOUNG OUTSIDE THE NEST, WAITING FOR THE REMOVAL OF DROPPINGS.
algorithms.sectionHeader: I 21 BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADISE
algorithms.bodyText: >und that the other egg also had hatched. It was evident, therefore, lat the second egg was laid one day later than the first. When the female returned to the nest-box, after I had visited it, could see through the large entrance-hole that she regurgitated food om her crop to feed her young. During the whole feeding period she id her young in this manner. Apart from fresh ants' pupae the family were given the following )od : chopped yolk of hard-boiled egg, fresh raw meat in very small ieces, finely-chopped apple, boiled rice and finely-chopped tomato, laked raisins, small mealworms, small live grasshoppers, and fresh whortleberries. The fact that the eggs were hatched during the summer considerably icilitated the feeding problem. I was able to obtain fresh ants' pupae, ve grasshoppers, and fresh whortleberries. Six months before the seeding I started to give both birds daily a portion of thawed deep- rozen ant pupae. When supplied with food the young emitted a suppressed, feeble, leeping sound, rather like small mice. The nestlings had smooth, laked bodies and were blind. All the young birds' droppings were wallowed by the mother. When the delicate young birds would not *pen their beaks she touched their heads very carefully with her bill. On the fifth day I saw the young open their eyes for the first time. Their gapes then were vivid yellow. When they were a week old happened to open the front of the nest-box and swung it to one side. Vfter a moment's hesitation the female fed her young just the same. Bach young bird was usually given three to four regurgitated portions it one time. Every day I released a number of small grasshoppers in the King Bird's room. The female caught them and, after she had pulled off heir legs and swallowed them, regurgitated them to feed her young. When the young ones were eight and nine days old respectively, she vould feed them while sitting in the entrance hole, stretching towards :hem and the young towards her. It was evident that the female selected the food offered to her young. 3nce I watched her standing beside the young and regurgitating the xmtents of her crop when a whortleberry appeared. She re-swallowed this and regurgitated a mealworm instead. I his she placed well orward in her beak and stuffed it into the gape of one of the young. Thereafter she regurgitated again, brought up a whortleberry, re-swallowed it, and instead regurgitated another mealworm, which she gave to the other nestling. Since the young birds' droppings never showed any trace of blue colouring, it is obvious that the female did not feed them with whortle- berries, though she ate these berries herself several times a day. When the young birds were twelve days old nearly all their feathers

S. BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADI were still in their quills, which were bluish grey in colour, though oi or two wing feathers had begun to sprout and these were brow When not asleep or feeding the young birds spent nearly all their tin preening their sprouting feathers. At the age of fourteen days all feathers, both on the upper and unde side, had sprouted. During this latter time the female had fed h< young almost exclusively on grasshoppers. When the young wei fourteen days old I saw, for the first time, the female emerging froi the entrance hole with the nestlings' droppings in her beak. She the dropped them on the ground instead of swallowing them, as she ha always done previously. Between their twelfth and fourteenth day the young birds develope so quickly that one could scarcely recognize them. At the fourteent day the whole of their upper side was brown with more red-brown o the wings. The underside was grey-brown with dark cross-bars. Th legs and feet were blue, but duller in colour than those of the parent: I hey could now sit like proper birds, preening themselves incessantly or stretching their legs and wings and fluttering comfortably. When, having taken some photographs of the young in the ope next-box, I had reclosed it and had been absent for a while, I found o my return that one of them was sitting in the entrance-hole. Shortl afterwards it flew out and sat on a branch close by. I picked up th young bird and held it in my hand for a while. The female flew roun. about and warned very loudly and incessantly. She crept witi expanded wings and tail along the ground and among the branche and leaves round me. \\ hen I moved the fledgeling from one hand t the other, the mother alighted on my head and pecked my crown witl hei beak, beating me also with her wings. I he bird was very excited but the male merely sat calmly at a distance and looked on. He ha never been observed feeding the young ones, either in the nest-box, o outside it. d he following morning both fledgelings were out and were regularh fed by the mother, as they sat on different branches. As the young wen hatched on the 28th and 29th June, the eldest one had flown out or 12th July and the other on 13th July, they thus had left the nest at the fourteenth day. In the jungle they would undoubtedly have remainec longer in the nest and this would have happened here also had they noi been disturbed by being photographed, when the front of the nest-box had been opened. Despite their youth, the young birds were quite sure holding on tc their branches and flying to the branch for which they were aiming, although they could only fly in a straight direction, as their tail-feathers were only half a centimetre long. On the fifteenth day they could already sit on one leg and scratch their heads. Sometimes one of them would bend forward, turning round the branch and come up on the
algorithms.sectionHeader: BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARADISE 123
algorithms.bodyText: [her side without releasing its hold, an art with which all my full- rown Birds of Paradise are experts. All of them also are capable of oing both forward and backward somersaults on their branch. The female, after having fed the young in the nest, always waited for leir droppings ; but she changed her behaviour after they had left the est and spent the day in the open. When she had finished feeding her oung she had the amusing habit of bending her head inquisitively nder the tail of one of them and then sitting motionless waiting for the roppings, but always in vain ! When the young were fifteen and sixteen days old, I saw them fight ach other for the first time, which also happened the next day and on weral later occasions. They would peck at each other with flapping rings like small cockerels. Sometimes they would swing round the ranch until one of them would force the other to loose his footing and utter down. Every evening towards dusk the young birds began to grow restless, ying from branch to branch and from one end of the aviary to the ther. It was obviously an expression of anxiety which so many birds -el in the evening, when it is time to seek a resting place for the night, it this time they uttered a cry which may be transcribed as tjao-tjao. couple of weeks later they produced a flutelike complaining whistle, iften uttered twice, and which later could be heard at any time ol the lay. When the young birds were fifty days old I heard them for the irst time give their warning cry, which was reminiscent ol the parents , ilthough it was not so harsh. At the twenty-fifth day the young birds' appearance may be lescribed as follows : beak, dark horn-coloured, lighter at the base, ris, grey-brown. Upper parts ol the head, brown tinged with russet, rhe back, grey-brown. The wings, grey-brown like the tail ; the wing eathers decidedly darker brown. The greater wing-coverts and outer vebs of the primaries red-brown. The underside, light grey with dark :ross-bars, curved on either half of the underside. Closer dark cross- )ars on the under tail-coverts. A light bar immediately above the eyes, md over this a dark spot. The chin, grey-brownish yellow with small lescending streaks and points. 1 he gape vivid yellow. The inner interior part of the lower mandible and its borders, yellowish-green, is also the upper mandible. 1 he legs and feet were blue, paler than the female's. At the twenty-fifth day the young birds' tail feathers were appr oxi- mately 3 cm. long. At this age they were fed every day with whortle- berries, which, as mentioned before, were never given to them when >till in the nest. Grasshoppers now formed a very substantial part of their diet. At the age of one month the young birds' tail leathers were nearly as long as the female's. The young ones were much lighter on the under-

S. BERGMAN-DISPLAY AND BREEDING OF KING BIRD OF PARAD side than the female. The mother still fed them and when they begg for food they uttered feeble cheeps whilst fluttering their wings. The male's moult began by casting one of his tail-wires on 18th Ju and the other on 19th June, while the female was incubating. T female started her moult on 1 oth August, when the young were fort one and forty-two days old. When the young birds were nearly two months old they changed ; their feathers on the sides and top of the head, and the entire ba acquired a pure grey colour. They had also grown new feathers on t under parts, where the dark cross-bars, especially on the flanks, we strongly marked. These bars were broader than in the female, whi< was generally browner on the under parts than the young ones. T 1 greater wing-coverts, the primary coverts, and the outer webs of tl primaries were vivid red-brown. As I write these words the young birds are three months old. Lii their parents they are both in splendid condition. They feed ther selves with all the food they get, but the female gives them a titbit no and then. The male has now almost completed his moult and is extreme elegant. It is only the tail-wires which have not yet reached their fi length. The fans are not yet full grown either. Feeling that he h;i regained his splendour he has started to sing and display. The fema has completed her moult of all the feathers on the neck and head, ari has also grown new feathers on the underside. It now remains to be seen whether my King Birds will repeat the breeding. As far as I know this has been the first successful attempt at breedir that has ever occurred with a Cicinnurus held in captivity.
Grateful acknowledgment is made to E. J. Brill, Leiden, publishers of NOV GUINEA, for the loan of the blocks of the illustrations of this article.--ED.
J. M. SPENCE-MALACHITE-CRESTED KINGFISHERS

(Corythornis cristata) By J. M. Spence (Port Elizabeth Museum, South Africa) A nest containing five young Malachite-crested Kingfishers was und near Port Elizabeth on 19th January. It was about 10 feet up . a river bank, and had a tunnel about 12 inches deep, the actual nest ivity was about six inches in diameter and extremely foul smelling, he young were estimated to be about three weeks old. They were wered with feather sheaths, some of which were already splitting to weal the blue feathers on the back. A week later all the sheaths had inished and the birds were fully fledged. Their droppings were sry liquid and quickly absorbed in sand. When first taken from the est the young would defecate in all directions, and il the droppings appened to fall on the feather sheaths they would just run off, thereby seping them quite clean. As they grew older the chicks would ack away from the others and deposit the droppings well away "om them. Three of the young were taken and hand-reared ; they thrived n strips of fish as well as ten to fifteen small whole fish per bird per ay. When fed whole fish they would throw up a cast of the scales nd bones. For the two days after they were feathered the young birds made o attempt to fly, then on the morning of the 28th they jumped one y one to the edge of their box and flew strongly around the room. Jeedless to say, they were immediately caged. The next day they tarted to take an interest in any food that accidentally fell to the oor while they were being fed, but made no attempt to pick it up. "he following morning a dish containing some small live fish in hallow water was placed in their cage. Although obviously interested, hey made no attempt to catch any until the 31st. Next day hey were taking live and strips of fish. I found that raw fish is ather inclined to come to pieces in water, so strips of donkey heart ^ere tried ; this proved very successful, and they took to it without ny trouble. They were not hand-fed after they were five weeks old. They are great bathers, and if not given a dish of clean water each lay they use the feeding dish to wash in. Their quaint habit of >obbing their heads up and down was obvious from the day they could ly, but they very seldom raise their crests. They have two methods of " catching " their food, one by diving ither from a perch or hovering above the food or else, by alighting >n the edge of the dish and pecking the strips of food out. These are isually thoroughly " killed " before eating by being beaten on a )erch. If the food is small fish they are always swallowed head first.

126 O. HIRTHE-FIRST BREEDING IN CAPTIVITY OF SEVERE MACAW Although they are not as brightly coloured as the adult, they ai nevertheless very beautiful, having the area between the eye and lor< a light buff. The cheeks and breast are dark grey-brown, with th throat and crown as in the adult. The abdomen is a lighter color orange than the flanks and shoulders. The rump and upper tai coverts are bright metallic blue, while the mantle and back are brig! metallic greenish-blue. The primaries are black, and the secondarit and coverts dark blue with bright turquoise spots. The feet and lee are orange underneath and grey above, while the beak is black wit a white tip. As you can imagine, they are very interesting and beautiful littl birds, and make a wonderful addition to our fast-growing collection of live birds.
algorithms.table: * * * FIRST BREEDING IN CAPTIVITY OF THE SEVERE MACAW (Ara sever a (Linnaeus)) By Otto Hirtiie (Copenhagen) (Translated from the Danish by C. af Enehjelm) ! 953 I bought a nice pair of Severe Macaws from the anima
algorithms.bodyText: dealer C. H. Krag, of this town. The birds were almost identical, onh the ltd coloui on the forehead of the bird believed to be the cock wai somewhat more pronounced. The birds seemed very attached to eacl other, so I thought they must be a true pair. I put them in a compart- ment of my largest aviary. This consists of a long brick building 60 feet long, 8 feet wide, and 8 feet high. The house is divided intc eighteen compartments, each approximately 3 feet by 5 feet, with a 3 feet passageway running along the back of the house. Each com- pai tment has an outside flight, approximately 3^ feet wide, 20 feet long, and 7 feet high. One box was hung in the shelter and another in the outside flight. I he boxes were made of 1^ inch boards, approxi- mately 1 foot by 1 foot and 2^ feet high. On the bottom of the boxes I placed a layer of moist earth, and on the top of this a layer of peat- moss, about 6 inches deep in all. Neither of the boxes was used for sleeping. In spite of the very cold winter, 1953-54, the birds spent all day in the flight, even the cold nights did not seem to hurt them in any way. The food consisted of sunflower seed, various millets, peanuts, and groats. 1 hey also got all kinds of sweet fruit, apples, oranges, grapes, etc. Strangely enough the birds did not seem to appreciate bananas. Raw canot was given freely, and should, in my experience, always be fed to nesting parrots and parrakeets. Also sprouted oats and

o. HIRTHE-FIRST BREEDING IN CAPTIVITY OF SEVERE MACAW 127 routed spray millet were given daily. The birds did not take ordinary sen food, as usually given, with the exception of the yellow dandelion 3ssoms, which they took readily, but not the ripe heads. The acaws seemed to thrive excellently on this food, and at the end of ay, 1954, I thought that the birds would start nesting, as they smed to be interested in the nest-box. Things, however, went Terentiy. I give fresh branches in the flight, and every time I bring w branches, the Macaws first bite off all the leaves, then the twigs, d finally, gnaw off the bark. Macaws should always have fresh anches for gnawing. This does them a lot of good and keeps them cupied. At the beginning of August the birds started to feed each other, d I also saw a single attempt at mating. It really was a true pair, n the 6th August the hen disappeared into the box in the outside ^ht and the cock spent most of his time in the neighbourhood of e box. He also visited the hen several times a day and slept in the >x every night during the period of incubation. A nest inspection is very difficult, as I was usually attacked by the birds. On the ith of August I took a thin lath and gently pushed away the rds from the centre of the nest, and an egg was visible on the bottom the box. When checking again on the 24th of August, I saw three gs, and these comprised the whole clutch. Apparently the eggs were id every other day. I did not inspect the nest again until the 12th of :ptember, when I saw a young bird, which seemed to be newly hatched. hree days later, when checking the nest, I found another young one ing dead, apparently crushed under the mother. The third egg was fertile, and was removed. The remaining young one throve cellently. Besides the ordinary food, I gave eggfood (hard-boiled ;g with biscuit), and boiled rice with milk and sweetened with sugar id different sweet jams--this food, by the way, also being given at tervals all the year round. The youngster left the nest on the ith October, beautifully feathered, and was greeted by the parents ith loud cries. A little later the young bird flew with the parents rough the long flight, the parents taking good care of it. 1 he bird )pears to be a cock, the red patch on the forehead being as big as that the old cock. It is delightfully tame, and takes food from my hand. The incubation period of the Severe Macaw is obviously 25-28 tys, and the young birds leave the nest when about 7 weeks old. 1 hey e fed by their parents for quite a long time, but are independent )out six weeks after leaving the nest. In 1955 another young bird was bred, and in 1956 three. I hese ere exhibited at the large bird show at Copenhagen in November, id were awarded the c Sluis ' cup for meritorious breeding.
C. J. O. HARRISON-NOTES ON THE DARK FIRE FINCH
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON THE DARK FIRE FINCH
algorithms.bodyText: (Lagonosticta rubricata) By G. J. O. Harrison (Tooting, London, England) These notes are an addition to the previous article (Aviculture Magazine, vol. 62, 1956, p. 128), and complete the study on the Fire Finches commonly available to aviculturists in this country. Appearance I he Dark Fire Finch ( Lagonosticta rubricata) is also known as tl Blue-billed Fire Finch, though this name is usually applied to tl West African subspecies, which is the one most frequently importe and the one on which these observations were made. The cock is dark, perhaps dull, scarlet on the head, breast, and bell and the mantle is a dark slate-grey. In this subspecies the dark gr< extends on to the nape and crown, but in others the head may 1 entirely red. The wings are a similar colour to the mantle, but perha] a little browner. The rump is scarlet, as is the base of the black ta: while the under tail-coverts are black. There is a faint white rim the eye, and the bill is steel-blue. The hen is pinker than the cot on head and breast with a small area of buff on the belly. The gener shape is that of a small squat bird with a narrow head and prominei bill. This species is unfortunately being widely sold and exhibited ; another species--Jameson's Fire Finch (L. jamesoni) . At one tin the two were considered to be related subspecies, but they are no separated. Jameson's Fire Finch is pinker on the head, light red c the breast, and brown on the back : but the principal distinguishir feature is the shape of the second primary feather. The first primary j both species is vestigial, and what appears to be the first is in realii the second. In Jameson's Fire Finch this latter feather tapers a litt towards the tip, but in the case of the Dark Fire Finch it is cut awa on the inner web towards the tip, so that the feather narrows sudden] and the terminal portion is very slender. This feature is constant i the different sexes and plumages. General Behaviour It is a rather nervous and furtive bird, resembling the Bar-breaste Fire Finch (L. rufopicta ) in its habits. Like that species it has a crouchin posture. If alarmed it tends to hide, and if free in a room will disappea into the darkest corner or under furniture, and remain still and silen I found that it quickly learnt to find its way around a room. Eve before a nest had been made it showed preference for roosting i

C. J. O. HARRISON-NOTES ON THE DARK FIRE FINCH 129 box. In spite of its furtive manner I found it an aggressive species. Vlien two cocks were put together one would chase the other con- nually, one of the birds (I am not sure which) uttering a low, soft tuc " note. When I put one with Senegal Fire Finches (L. senegala ) nd Lavender Finches (L. caerulescens) it dominated both. all-note The call-note is low-pitched, nasal, and slightly harsh--" kyew " r " kyah ". It has a wide range of expression, from a soft, subdued ote used between a pair when feeding or on the move, to a loud, arsh version used in periods of excitement or isolation. larm-note This differs in form from that used by the Senegal and Bar-breasted ire Finches. It is abrupt, similar to theirs, but higher in pitch, nd is repeated in a rapid series that run together to form a single ittling trill. The pitch is variable, becoming higher as anxiety lcreases. It is accompanied by a crouching posture similar to that f the Bar-breasted but with the head raised on a rather thin neck, he tail is held to one side, half-spread and jerked sideways at each 'all. ong The dangers of generalizations based on a study of too few specimens rere brought home to me with this species, for the first cock that possessed had a song which consisted merely of a long-drawn toneless ill on a single flat note. It was only with subsequent birds that heard the more normal song. The cock of a nesting pair did not sing r hen the hen was on the nest, but used instead, low-intensity alarm- otes together with a more melodious form of the call-note. When the hen died the cock began to sing immediately and per- stently. The song was melodious though generally high-pitched, irprisingly loud, and consisted of short phrases frequently repeated. )uring one period I timed it and found that it consisted of phrases \- 2 \ seconds long, uttered at intervals of 5-6 seconds. In volume nd pitch it reminded me of a Robin's song, but the style was mock- iightingale. A typical phrase would consist of the rapid repetition f a note, seven or eight times ; but there were frequent changes of itch between phrases, suggestions of crescendo and diminuendo, and jmetimes a short descending cadence. Once or twice I did hear a lort trill reminiscent of the first cock's song. iest-call This was heard frequently during, and just after, nest-building, t was a faint persistent clucking note repeated with great rapidity.

I 3 * C. J. O. HARRISON-NOTES ON THE DARK FIRE FINCH I was not able to compare it directly, but would have said that i was lower in pitch than the Senegal Fire Finch's call, which is ir turn lower than the Bar-breasted's. Display This is similar to the display of the Bar-breasted Fire Finch. The cock holds a piece of grass or a feather by its tip. It stretches ven straight upright with head thrown back and head and neck feathers sleeked down, while the belly feathers are a little fluffed and the tail, half-spread. T he movement consists, as in the other Fire Finches, of a series of vigorous upward jerks, usually in repeated sets of four bobs. At each jerk there is an upward movement of the bill and in many, possibly all, cases the head is turned alternately half to one side and then the other, so that the grass or feather appears to be waved jerkily from side to side while the bird is bobbing up and down. There does not appear to be any special movement at the completion of die display. I did not notice any specialized flight of the cock while carrying display material. Unmated cocks showed what I took to be an undirected display homologous with the " stip " display in the Senegal Fire Finch. In it the bird had a rather tense posture, upright, with head raised. It continually repeated a single note which I called a "squelch" note since it reminded me most of the sound when air is squeezed out of a wet rubber sponge with a rush of tiny bubbles, and was also reminiscent of the lwit of a thin twig swished through the air. Each note was accompanied by an upward movement of the bill, and terminated in a subdued click. I was surprised that it did not appear at the end of the display of the paired cock. When the hen died the cock began to intersperse its song with periodic repetitions of the note. Finally, about two weeks after the hen s death, it picked up a grass-stem and indulged in a momentary display during which I was able to detect that the note occurred, with the lifting of the grass-stem to one side or the other, at each upward jerk of the bird ; but it was normally masked in my cages by the heavy thud of the bird's feet on the perch as it bounced up and down. Other postures \\ lien the pair were first put together there was a certain amount of what appeared to be aggressive behaviour. I thought for a few days that I might have two cocks. Both birds would take up similar postures side by side, with neck stretched straight upwards, head thrown back and bill raised, while the tail was cocked and half- spread. In this position they would pivot from side to side, the bill- tips occasionally touching as though one bird was parrying the thrust

the other. This occurred not only in the pair-formation period, also in the early stages of nest-building. ting Vithin a few days of being placed together a pair built a nest a cardboard box that had been put up for that purpose. The t was of coarse grass and leaves, and lined with feathers and fibre, in the other Fire Finches the cock brought all the material and It the outer, rough shape of the nest, while the hen lined the nest h material brought by the cock. In this case the hen began to 1st before the outer shape was complete. t script rhese notes complete my observations on Fire Finches to date, will be seen that they are, with the exception of the Lavender Lch, very similar species, with distinct differences of song and ;hter variations of display and calls that serve to illustrate both ir relationship and the differences which enable them to preserve ir specific identity. [f it should be asked why they appear in these pages I would plead it it is only through a knowledge of a bird's life and behaviour it we can understand how best to keep it, and that it is only through culture that it has been possible for the observations to be made, tailed studies on these species in their natural habitat are still king, and I hope that these notes will be of some value to future dents.

By A. A. Clarence (Parkstone, Dorset, England) Of my birds, I think a pair of Indian Zosterops has given me as iat pleasure as any. This, I say, even though I have an Indian ama who on many a warm night has charmed the silence with tes that would intrigue a Nightingale. The Zosterops arrived in the late spring and were liberated into aviary considered suitable to their needs. Luckily the weather held e for a considerable time and they did not appear to find the iglish climate anything unusual. In Northern India, the sun deals nstroke by day, and it can be cold to freezing at night. The aviary, 15 feet long by 4 feet wide and 8 feet high, was built ainst a very old brick wall. This was riddled with crevices and holes ide by the hand-cut nails of former generations. They formed ideal

A. A. CLARENCE-BREEDING ZOSTEROPS hide-outs for spiders and other insects. The wall faced south, and t] aviary was also protected from east and west winds. An apple tr sapling, self-sown, grew tight to the bricks. It's branches radiate and pressing hard against the wire roof, formed a canopy of leav which effectively kept out rain. For those who have not seen a Zosterops, let me say that they a small, short-tailed, insectivorous birds, about the size of an Engli Wren. Their colour is a warm grey-green with a grey-white stomac which merges into yellowish-green on the breast and lemon-yello under the beak. The eyes are their most arresting feature. These a bordered with white rims, which have earned them the name Spectacled Zosterops. Knowing nothing of the nesting habits of the active little birds, I gave them soft, dry meadow-grass and ha In due course they became interested, and wove the hay into a rou# bundle between the fork at the end of a horizontal branch aboi six feet above ground. Adjoining this aviary was another, but of larger proportions, beir 40 feet long, 8 feet wide, and 12 feet high. It contained some Chinqu Pheasants, a pair of Senegal Touracous, a few parrakeets, and ah a pair of Zebra Finches. At the partition top, a strip of wire allowe the inmates to look into the Zosterops' aviary. The Zebra Finch appeared to be fascinated by the " goings on" of the Zosterop and were desperately anxious to get a closer view of the nest. I last they discovered that a heaven-sent mouse had enlarged a hoi where the wire adjoined the wall, and through this they squeezed. I don't know what goes on in the minds of birds, but these Zebn had fully made up theirs long before they passed the wire nettini In no time they had that bundle of hay torn to shreds, and wei preening themselves on a good day's work. You could almost he< them say " Good-bye to all that " ! Later, finding seed only in a tra cage, they were soon caught and transferred elsewhere. It so happened that two little French poodles were being clippe for show at that time. I threw a couple of handfuls of their brow curly hair into the aviary. With evident delight, the Zosterops seize upon it, and set to work to create a masterpiece of constructor Choosing as before the flat fork at the end of a branch about 3 fee above ground, they tightly wove a small, deep cup as neat as thei first effort had been ragged. It was interesting to note that this tim the nest was not visible from the next-door aviary. It hung under th fork and was bound to it by two hinges, each about an inch long. Som small feathers were used for lining, and two diminutive, blue green eggs were laid. These could be seen with the aid of a can through the wire, to which was attached a small looking-glass. The little hen sat deep in her cradle, showing only the tip of he beak and tail, while one beady eye, made very visible by its whit

ectacled rim, missed nothing that passed. She had the delightful ibit of pulling a solitary large white feather over her back when e weather was cold. I do not know exactly how long the incubation ok, as she sat close and gave little or no chance of looking into her 'st. However, in a seemingly very short time, about a fortnight, e was off hunting for insects. Two children gathered ant-eggs from under the stones which irdered the paths of the garden, and swept the hay-fields with itterfly nets, catching quantities of flies, etc., from the grass tops, t first the two babies looked like black spiders at the bottom of the > s t. They grew fast, and no parents could have been more zealous caring for their wants. Eventually they left the nest as two grey- een balls of fluff, and were coaxed by their parents to the top of the )ple tree and on to the sleeping perch. With the two chicks between iem, they made a charming picture. Later on they placed one baby -tween them--the other had to take an outside seat. Somehow think that the favoured infant was the hen. It appeared to be nailer. When the youngsters had grown to full size, and were able to fend >r themselves, the parents decided to build a new nest, and pulled le old one to pieces. The cock, however, apparently also decided that e could not tolerate another of his own sex in the aviary, and unseen y anybody, he slew his son, reducing his pretty young head to a iw skull. His daughter continued to live and sleep between the arents as before. Unhappily the weather changed, and they apparently decided that le conditions were unfavourable for building, this much to my igret, having just bought a colour film.
algorithms.table: I * * * BRITISH AVICULTURISTS' CLUB Meetings and dinners during the 1957-58 session have been arranged ir the following dates :-- gth September, 1957 nth November, 1957 13th January, 1958 10th March, 1958 12 th May, 1958 Will members please note that in future the Meetings will be held
