algorithms.sectionHeader: N. GRAVEM-BREEDING THE STAR FINCH OR RUFICAUDA BREEDING THE STAR FINCH OR RUFICAUD
algorithms.bodyText: (.Bathilda rujicauda) By Nicholas Gravem (Mill Valley, California, U.S.A.) Of the so-called Australian grass-finches, I personally believe tl Star finch or Ruficauda (Bathilda rujicauda) has been rather neglecte as an aviary subject and particularly as regards its breeding. Here j California, imported Stars are plentiful enough ; however, aviary-bre birds are sadly scarce. I understand that this same state of affairs ah exists, more or less, in Britain. Perhaps a few remarks on breeding the; finches, over here, may be of interest. I breed Stars and Gouldians indoors in cages measuring about 24 b 18 by 15 inches deep. These cages are built in batteries of four in a un and aie tiuly box-cages with only the fronts open. I have never know Stars use a nest-box like Gouldians ; and they are furnished with on of those tiny, wooden-barred canary travelling-cages, with the bottor knocked out, and fitted within the cage on its side. It has been my experience that these birds generally, as Gouldian; come into condition and breed during our winter months, going int post-nuptial moult in our late spring or early summer. Howevei I have found that Stars are very much more flexible than Gouldian with regard to adapting their breeding cycle to the spring and summe of our northern hemisphere. After mating (by mating ", I mean pairing, not coition), the cod pioceeds with most of the work of nest-building, the hen assisting to ; minoi degree. Compared with a Gouldian nest, this is a very nea piece of work. 1 he nest, built within the canary travelling-cage, is ; globular affair with entrance in the side and is usually started with tin coaisest material at hand and then receiving an inside lining of fine dry grass and (supplied) feathers. " Egg sandwich " architecture--s( frequently employed by over-zealous Zebras and less frequently b} frustrated Gouldian cocks--is seldom resorted to. rinee to five white eggs seem to be the rule, incubated for some twelve or thirteen days. Very little egg-binding seems to occur witf Stars, even when breeding is controlled in small cages affording so little exeicise. (Gouldian hens, of course, are rather prone to this complaint and I find that if a hen of this species becomes egg-bound and, more particularly, il she reabsorbs the egg instead of expelling it, egg- binding will always recur and the only thing to do is to retire thal particular hen from the breeding-cage.) Diurnal incubation is usually shared by cock and hen, with the hen alone incubating at night ; though in occasional pairs both will occupy the nest at night. 1 he incubation patch in the median apterium of the hen is not as easily seen as it is on the abdomen of, say, a hen Gouldian.
algorithms.sectionHeader: N. GRAVEM-BREEDING THE STAR FINCH OR RUFICAUDA
algorithms.bodyText: believe cocks of the genera Bathilda and Poephila are without this a tch--even though they do a large amount of daytime incubating-- ad perhaps this is why these cocks incubate only during the day and le hens at night when greater heat is required to keep the eggs warm, oth parents also share in brooding duties. Upon hatching, the young are fed by both parents by regurgitation, ith the cock perhaps doing more of the feeding as the nestlings grow, oth cock and hen usually being model parents. I believe insect lare is ecessary, or desertion will result. I use cut-up mealworms : one worm iree times a day upon hatching and increasing the number of worms y one each day until they have fledged. This is along the lines iggested by Mr. Brooksbank in his excellent book Foreign Birds for 'arden Aviaries. Mealworms are used as a matter of convenience and ndoubtedly any number of other insect forms would also fill the bill, have not found mealworms overheating to the parent birds or other- wise objectionable, at least not while following the rationing schedule s above. Millet sprays are before the birds at all times ; soaked sprays /hen feeding young. I have had no real success with egg-food, bread nd milk, sponge cake, etc., in regard to nestling grass-finches. The basic seed diet consists of about three-quarters small canary aixed with one-quarter white millet, shaken with a little G.L.O. dost so-called finch seed mixtures are predominantly millet; mine nostly canary. Also available at all times is a supplement mixture of nore or less wild seeds that consists of: water-grass, sweet Sudan (red ,nd yellow), brassica, kohlrabi, lettuce (black and white), clover, rye- grass, and phalaris. This latter gives the birds, I believe, more than nough variety. Cuttlebone in its original form is not given. Instead, 1 mixture of ground cuttlebone, ground oyster shell, and ground >oiled egg-shells, in equal parts, with a bit of flaked charcoal added, s supplied. The only green food offered is the small, young shoots from ilanted rape seed. I am successful with this diet 5 and I am suie othei iviculturists have equally sound diets, as well as successful systems of ireeding and management for grass-finches. I don t belie\e in logmatic ideas in reference to things avian. I leave young Stars with the parents as long as possible after leaving he nest, but still manage to get two nests per pair (infrequently three) aer year. The young, upon leaving the nest, roughly resemble young Glouldians, but with darker bills, and completely lack the papilke-like >pots of colour in the malar region, as possessed by the Gouldians , out, before leaving the nest, the young Stars have well-developed v\ hite areas at the commisural point (angle of the mouth), as well as coloured mouth linings. Incidentally, young Stars have quite daik toe-nails compared with the lighter colour of tarsus and toes. Sexing ol young prior to the postjuvenal moult is considerably more difficult than with Gouldians (in which case the young hens exhibit darker bills than the
algorithms.footnote: 1 3^ A. A. CLARENCE-THE STORY OF A LAPWING
algorithms.bodyText: cocks) ; however, the fledged male Stars very soon attempt their sma] warble of a song. \oung Stars bathe almost immediately upon quitting the nest unlike Gouldians, which I find a bit reluctant to bathe. (However young Gouldians placed with young Stars soon imitate the latter am bathe several times a day ; but when separated from the Stars, thes* ablutions soon taper off. This would indicate that their innate bath ing behaviour can be readily accelerated by visual stimulation.) One drawback with aviary-raised Stars is that they almost alway tend toward xanthochroism ; that is, the red feathering is replacec with yellow or yellowish, quite unlike freshly imported specimens Most aviculturists claim, I believe, that this is due to a dietary deficiency and particularly as regards live insect food. However, as red in feather; results usually from chemical substances (carotenoids) taken wifi green stuff, I wonder if live food has any bearing on the matter. I have heard that soya bean, in some form, has been successful with Tanagen in this regard.

By A. A. Clarence (Parkstone, Dorset, England) Some years ago I was at a partridge " shoot ". It was of the " set- piece " kind : every stand marked, with its number embossed in black on a large white metal plate, which was fixed to a rod and stood about 2 feet above ground. At the first stand of the day my position was near the corner ol a high-hedged field. There I was surprised to see a Plover standing motionless. I soon realized that it could not fly and without difficulty caught it. I was astonished when I saw that it had only one wing--the other was missing at the shoulder. It had been cut off clean as a whistle '. dhe skin had drawn together over the bone and there was no blood. A surgeon could not have done a neater job. I put the Lapwing in a gamebag and passed it to a farm-hand, who was acting as my carrier. 1 his youth collected some worms and gave them to the bird, which was very hungry. At the last stand of the day I found myself in a field which adjoined the one in which I had begun the day. At the base of the number plate lay a severed wing. No doubt the Plover had struck the plate in one of the fast swooping dives which these birds delight in during the twilight hours when, as though at a given signal, the whole world of night life awakens, and Plover, Snipe, duck, and Curlew break into a cacophony of sound, a chorus of calls, and whirring wings. On the
algorithms.sectionHeader: SPENCE-SUCCESSES AND FAILURES OF A SCOTTISH AVICULTURIST I 37
algorithms.bodyText: her hand, the Plover may have mistaken the white plate for one ' his own kind, and on a tour of inspection met his Waterloo. We put him in a rabbit hutch, well supplied with water and earth- orms. Next day he was liberated into a 15-ft. square roofless pen, > which another pen of the same size adjoined. These pens were Itiilt on solid sand and were used for rearing baby pheasants. An Derture 10 inches long and 3^ inches high was at ground level in der to allow the chicks to pass into the second pen, where grass ifts and a dead mouse or two acted as cover and bait for flies. I knew that Lapwings were quick-eyed birds, but I did not expect lis one to find the " bob hole " instantly, the exit being so well elow its line of vision. Having examined the second pen it returned > the first, and never faltered or had to look for the opening, railed Partridges would wander up and down the wire division all ay and never find it. " Mr. Pee-Weet," as he was called, soon grew tame, and flourished a the worms and insects brought to him by children, who were athusiastic hunters on his behalf and derived great entertainment om the bobbing and bowing, which he did from the top of a box 3vered with turf. The winter set in and he looked very handsome and glossy standing n this box. It was meant for him to shelter in, but he never used it. In January there was a severe night frost ; this proved more than is exposed side could stand. He was found frozen dead on top of le box, much to my sorrow and that of his young friends, who uried him in a boot box, with a wooden cross, flowers, and all !
algorithms.sectionHeader: SUCCESSES AND FAILURES OF A SCOTTISH AVICULTURIST
algorithms.bodyText: By Tom Spence (Newburgh, Fife, Scotland) Ill-luck or bad management, I don't know which, but certainly have not done well with breeding of birds so far this season. I or xample, out of about forty Ruddy Sheldducks eggs I have only eight ucklings. The fertility was poor, but there was a dreadfully poor ,atch with deads-in-the-shell ; and of those that hatched a lair lumber were murdered by the unnatural wretches ol broody hens hat I had bought in. I have, however, a nice strong young brood ,f New Zealand Sheldducks, which by their very strength must invite nisfortune on them ! The only lories which have laid have either eaten their eggs or efused to sit on them, and truth to tell I am beginning to lose interest

138 T. SPENCE-SUCCESSES AND FAILURES OF A SCOTTISH AVICUL,TURIS r in them. I still have about a dozen pairs and a good few single birds^ mostly hand-tame. Last year I did very badly and reared very few birds. The only relatively bright spot was the " Foxwarren " Green Peafowl. Thf Peahen laid no less than 18 eggs before going broody, really three clutches. Of these one was clear and one was infertile because of ar imperfect shell. The rest were all embryonated, but unfortunatef nearly all of those I trusted to an electric incubator died in the shell Of those left with the Peahen or with broodies, nine hatched. Had ]P written sooner, as I had intended, I might have been able t( say that I had reared them all without loss, for until they were abou' seven or eight months old, I had no losses. Since then, however one was killed (by a broody), one died of " cold weather Pasteurel losis ", and two developed such crippled toes that I destroyed them The survivors, one male and four females, are all good birds. Phis year the Peahen has already laid two clutches totalling 14 eggs The fust four hatched, four out of four, yesterday. They look strong one male and three females, I should say. All the eggs so far candlec have been fertile. My little Demoiselle, a tame one, laid within about ten feet of the dinmg-i00m and seemed likely to sit well, dhe egg, however, was stolen, piesumably by the Jackdaws that infest my place, and the shell found under a nearby tree. I was very sad at this and made even more so by the way that her ladyship followed me around as though I had stolen it. Luckily she has laid again and this time I quickly substituted a Barnacle Goose's egg, boiled in coffee and ink and splodged to simulate the Crane's egg. She took to this without demur and is incubating within ten feet of the door ! If the egg is fertile I may return it to her when nearly ready to hatch, or I may lie tempted to try to rear it myself. I think the Stanley Cranes are a paii , so do they most times and they are defending a nest area quite fiercely. My attitude is one of interest quite purged of hope or expectation. The European Cranes are still too young to breed, though they are taming nicely. I have a veritable drove (six) ol Vulturine Guineafowl, but they are all juveniles except for one, and I can t expect anything this season, though they look in better form than any ol my birds and are so tame that they follow me closely round their acre paddock. I hav c quite a few ducklings ol different species of Sheldduck and geese, and of these I am particularly watchful over the New Zealand Sheldducklings. There are also a few (precious few) baby pheasants. Of the softbills, the Spreos finally revealed their sexes by laying thice infeitile clutches at the same time. I know now that I had thiee females. Luckily I had already a cock " which I now intro- duced. He was a real " Peer Gynt " and a-man-for-all-three-of-them.

wo of them (females) laid again and there are now (about) seven mng in one nest which all four are feeding. Strangely the third male has not laid again, probably inhibited from doing so by the mulus of the young. These four get on without a sign of discord, it when I introduced a second male, a beautiful bird the " size of a ckdaw," there was a most dreadful melee, and later I took out the bits " which I was able to blow life into and which has recovered, f course this second " male " even though big, is almost certainly female, for I have put it beside yet another male which has espoused her " right away.

By J. J. Yealland The Toucan-Barbets, presumably so called because of the large Tow and black, though not very Toucan-like bill, inhabit sub-tropical rnes in the Andes of north-western South America where there are ^o forms :-- Semnornis ramphastuius of Ecuador and S. r. caucae ol Colombia, third member of this genus is the Costa Rican Barbet (, Semnornis antzii) of sub-tropical zones in Costa Rica and western Panama, specimen of the first of these, new to the Collection, has been received l exchange ; it makes a particularly interesting and attractive exhibit t the Bird House. Another bird not previously exhibited here is the Dusky Miner Myzantha obscura ), one of the many Australian Honey-eaters. 1 he ame used to be spelt Minah, and, of course, a better one would be (usky Honey-eater, but there is another, Myzomela obscura , already aown by this name. Two White-bellied Storm Petrels ( Fregetta grallaria) flew on board ..M.S. Dunnottar Castle off Ascension. The ship's cat soon filed one and the second was rescued by the wireless operator and rought to London ; it lived only a few days. Six King Penguins were brought from the Antarctic by H.M.S. ' rotector and presented by the Captain and Ship s Company.
algorithms.reference: L Cape Robin-Chat ( Cossypha caffra ) has been presented by Capt. R. S. e Q. Quincey and two Malayan Coast White-eyes (Zosterops palpebrosa ureiventer) by Mr. J. Newmark. An interesting addition to the 1 arrot louse is a Cuban Conure ( Aratinga euops ), also known as the Led-speckled or Euops Conure.
algorithms.bodyText: Mr. M. Horwood collected two nestling White-necked Picathartf in Ghana, feeding them mainly, I believe, on earthworms, and friend of his brought them to London by air. They are strong birc with enormous appetites and they are so far thriving on the insecti) mixture used at the Bird House and some mealworms. Two Maned Geese, another Cormorant, various Gulls and Pheasant: including four Swinhoe's, have been bred in the Gardens. Th Green-winged King Parrakeets are nesting and another Swainson X Red-collared Lorikeet has been bred. The Satin Bower-birds buil a flimsy nest of twigs, bamboo and privet leaves. One egg was laic but it was broken soon afterwards. Four Greenfinches have bee bred in the British Birds' Aviary where a Stone Curlew is incubatin three eggs. Four Zebra Finches have been bred and there are nests c Blue Tanagers, Black-throated Cardinals, Malayan Glossy Starlings and Black Crakes. The Snowy Owls nested as usual and eight eggs were laid. Thre of these were given to a Spotted Eagle-Owl whose own eggs wer infertile and she hatched all three, of which two are surviving am are now quite large. The Snowy Owl itself hatched several chicks letting them all die but one which is flourishing and growing fast An Australian Stone Curlew that was in Mr. Spedan Lewis's collectioi at Leckford before the war now lives in the centre aviary at the Bin House and continues to lay one or two eggs each year.
algorithms.table: * * * NEWS AND VIEWS Miss Phyllis Barclay-Smith represented the Society at the firs Pan-African Ornithological Congress held at Livingstone, Northen Rhodesia, on i5th-20th July, 1957. * * * 1 he Bronze Medal of the Avicultural Society of South Australis has been awarded to A. Phillips, for breeding the Red-chested Quail * * * D. Lievens, Moerzeke, by Dendermonde, Belgium, has a quit( exceptional pair of Mealy Rosellas. In three breeding seasons the} produced 32 eggs, of which 30 were fertile and 30 young were reared 1 954> 6 and 4 ; 1955, 5 and 4 ; 1956, 6 and 5. * * *
algorithms.bodyText: dhe Edinburgh Zoo continues to be successful in breeding Penguins For 1956? the report is that the King laid 13 eggs from which 8 chick: were reared ; Gentoo, 10 eggs, 9 hatched, 3 chicks reared ; Maccaron 4 e ggs and Ringed 2, none hatched.

The Keston Foreign Bird Farm has recently received a few pairs rarely imported birds. They are the Crimson-rumped or Sundevall's 'axbill ( Estrilda rhodopyga) ; Alexander's Cut-throat (Amaditia fasciata txanderi) ; and Abyssinian Red-cheeked Cordon-bleu ( Uraeginthus ngalus schoanus )--all native to Abyssinia.

Last year a pair of Princess of Wales' Parrakeets owned by C. Newton apron, Lake Worth, Florida, was triple brooded ; nests of 3, 2, and were reared. So far this season they have 2 young flying, with 4 in a cond nest. It will be interesting to see whether they again rear broods.

Sixty-five members and guests accepted the invitation of the Council * the North of England Zoological Society to visit the Zoological ardens, Chester, on 25th June, 1957. Mr. G. B. Groundsell, President ' the Society, presided at the lunch and welcomed the visitors, and ir Vice-President Jean Delacour replied in his own inimitable manner, he Director-Secretary, G. S. Mottershead, and his staff, were untiring their efforts to make the visitors welcome, and the warmest thanks 'all are accorded to them for a very enjoyable and memorable visit.

Breeding reports : E. J. Boosey, the " Keston " Senegal Parrots rve three young flying : " Darenth-Hnlme ," the Green Imperial igeons have one young one three weeks old ; Common Mynahs, vo flying : Sqd.-Ldr. C. Everitt, Black-crested Finches, two young /ing : Major V. Dilwyn Jones, Red-bellied Gonure, nest ol five :ared : R. G. Kirkham, Peach-faced Lovebirds, " now up to the aist in them " ! : C. M. Payne, three Derbyan Parrakeets flying : aptain R. S. de Q,. Quincey, Shamas hatched two young, one of hich soon died ; the female was killed by a Jay and the male unaided :ared the survivor until fully fledged, when the latter, too, was killed y a Jay : R. C. J. Sawyer, Roulrouls laid nine eggs which were iven to a bantam ; all were fertile but being rather stale only two atched ; one young one was accidentally killed, but the other is

algorithms.bodyText: Last year Mr. and Mrs. Eric C. Kinsey and Mr. and Mrs. William J. lieffler made an extensive European tour. During their stay in ngland many members had an opportunity of meeting them. T hey ;pecially will be very sorry to learn that since returning home Irs. Kinsey's health has steadily deteriorated.

The Kinseys established " Manorin " thirty-two years ago, and bui up very considerable collections of birds, camellias, and orchid Unfortunately, the time came when Mrs. Kinsey found the strai of supervising the collections too great and it thus became necessar to dispose of them and the property at Manor. And so, in the wort of Mr. Kinsey, " Manorin is no more." A. A. P.

Das Buch vom Wellensittigh. By Curt af Eneiijelm. Edited b Dr. Joaciiim Steinbacher. Verlag Gottfried Helene, Pfungstad Darmstadt, Germany. Price 21.50 DM. (approx. 36^.). Curt af Enehjelm, Director of the Helsingfors Zoo, is well know to all readers of the Avicultural Magazine both for his achievemeni in the field of aviculture and for his articles on the subject. Th " Book of the Budgerigar " has been produced with the assistance c Dr. Joachim Steinbacher and, as might be expected, this collaboratio between two such well-known aviculturists has resulted in a moJ comprehensive and informative work. Every aspect is dealt witl starting with a description of the species Melopsittacus undulatus Sha^ in the wild, the history of its early importations and first breedings, an the development of the varieties from the first mutation known, i Belgium in 1872, to the countless colours which are available to-da) 1 he chapter on housing deals fully with cages, aviaries, and flight and is illustrated with photographs, drawings, and diagrams. Advic is given on buying birds, the points to look out for and avoid bein clearly given, and the author emphasizes that the cheapest bird i seldom the best. His recommendations on how to treat birds durin the period immediately after purchase is particularly helpful. He als says that in buying Budgerigars it should be borne in mind for wha purpose they are required, whether as a pet, for the pleasure of keepin a few birds, or for breeding. He states that, as with all breeding c animals, it is better to start in a small way with first-class specimens In the chapter on breeding the following aspects are dealt with- choice of birds, breeding season, number of broods, pairing, laying c e gg s ? aR d brooding, young, control of nests, foster-parents, rings an< the keeping of a record book, and points out the importance of th latter. There are also chapters on feeding and care of Budgerigan moult, illness, l,t French moult," tame and speaking birds, and keepin; Budgerigars with other birds. Finally, there is full information oi colour breeding which occupies more than half the entire book. 1 here are 6 coloured plates, each depicting two varieties, by th English artist, A. Vowles and 41 black and white illustrations. P. B-S.
algorithms.sectionHeader: fLDFOWL OF THE BRITISH ISLES. By Peter Scott and Hugh
algorithms.bodyText: Boyd. Country Life, London, 1957. Price 2i.r. net. There is no doubt that the group of birds popularly known as Wild- d, which includes the swans, geese, and ducks, has become much 1 re popular in recent years than was the case formerly, when most iple thought of a wild goose or duck only as something to be shot and en. This increased interest is due, no doubt, to the very fine pictures 2 sees nowadays of the various species, drawn by the few artists who \0x25A0cialize in the painting of these birds ; and in the establishment of the ldfowl Trust and its grounds at Slimbridge where the finest collec- n of wildfowl is to be seen. Very few people have an idea of the mber and variety of species of these birds that occur in our own mtry and a book dealing with them was much to be desired. Such jook would not be of much value unless it were well illustrated, and th pictures in colour; and it must include all the species that occur in itain. Such a book has now appeared and we welcome Wildfowl of the itish Isles, by Peter Scott and Hugh Boyd, as adequately filling a gap, it contains a full description of plumage, nesting habits, and range, well as a first-rate coloured illustration, of every species, even :luding some that are only occasional visitors and some, such as the andarin Duck and Canada Goose, which were introduced but have :ome established with us. There are fifteen coloured plates, some itaining three or more species, all drawn by Peter Scott, and hough we have seen some of these before in his very excellent ports of the Wildfowl Trust, they are none the less welcome in this npact form. The only fault we have to find with an otherwise excellent book is ; absence of an index, of which the Table of Contents does not quite te the place. D. S-S. IE RING. Edited and published by Dr. W. Rydzewski, Croydon, England. Subscription, 1957, 16.U or 2.50 U.S. dollars. This private publication was started in 1954 and has now attained circulation in most countries of the world where bird banding is rried on. It is issued quarterly and is devoted entirely to bird nding, its aims, tasks, results, and methods, and is a useful medium ' the exchange of ideas and experience. General articles on banding various countries have been included, and also notes on trapping :hniques, records of longevity, etc. Up to date eleven issues have peared, including two for 1957. Subscriptions and requests for ck numbers should be addressed to the Editor, Dr. W. Rydzewski, W tyre Road, Croydon, Surrey. P. B-S.

Notes on a Collection of Parrots The following notes on my birds may possibly be of interest to some of our reader Starting with the successes :-- Roseate Cockatoos.--The cock of this pair is one of the late Duke of Bedford split-albino Roseates and was obtained from Mrs. Clark, of Maidsmere. Last year tl hen laid three eggs, and reared three beautiful youngsters, one of which is an albin< It is white where the normal is grey, its breast is a lovely pink flecked witl white, giving a pearl effect, the under-wing feathers are very deep pink--nearly m it has the red eye, a flesh-coloured beak and feet. From what records I have been ab! to look up, I believe this is the first albino Roseate to be reared in captivity. Leadbeater's Cockatoos, reared three youngsters. Blue Ring-necks, reared two youngsters. Lutino Ring-necks, reared three youngsters. Turquosines, reared three. Splendids, reared one. Illiger's Macaws, laid three eggs, all were fertile, but did not hatch. Pileated, hatched two youngsters which lived for three weeks but died of col when the hen stopped brooding. Brown's, had three youngsters in the nest on the 2nd March, but all died on th night of the 15th March, when we had snow and 19 0 frost. Crimson-wings, laid three eggs, two were fertile but did not hatch. Derbyans, laid two eggs which proved infertile. Amazon Parrots, laid two eggs which proved infertile. I am afraid the hen is to old for any further breeding successes. An interesting happening was that three 1955 bred lutino Ring-necks developeJ their pink rings ; two of these birds were bred by Mr. E. N. T. Vane, the other b, Mrs. Clark. At the time of writing the Cockatoo population at Mount Pleasant is as follows seven Leadbeater's, four Citron-crested, seven Roseates, two Gang Gangs, and on
algorithms.figure: Lemon-crested. Arthur Lamb. * * * CORRESPONDENCE
algorithms.bodyText: How does one sex softbills ? Raymond Sawyer returned my other Rothschild' Grackle two weeks ago, and when I put them together they looked as obvious a pai as one could imagine. To confirm this my old bird sang like mad, and they preenec each other and he started breaking off twigs in a most business-like manner. Thei the " hen " began to pursue the " cock " in a rather half-hearted way and he looket quite dejected. A few days ago the " cock " began to pursue the hen in a decidedh purposeful way, and later I rescued the hen from the ground, luckily before then was any real damage done to her. I still think they are a pair ! ! As Frost says these grackles, sing, mate, or fight, quite irrespective of sex.

algorithms.affiliation: Green Imperial and Pied Imperial Fruit Pigeons
algorithms.sectionHeader: I \VICULTURAL MAGAZINE THE JOURNAL OF THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY AND THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA
algorithms.bodyText: ol. 63.--No. 5.-- All rights reserved. SEPTEMBER-OCTOBER, 1957

(Ducula aenea ) By A. A. Prestwich (Southgate, England) The Green Imperial or Bronze Fruit Pigeon has a very wide dis- dbution, being found in India, Ceylon, Burma, Thailand, Indo- china, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java, Flores, Borneo, Celebes, hilippine Islands, etc. There are, consequently, numerous races, s many as fourteen being recognized. This pigeon may be common in the wild state, but it is very seldom ien in captivity in Great Britain. The Zoological Society of London iceived their first specimen in 1866, a second arriving the following ear, with three more in 1871 : other arrivals were 1878, one ; 883, one ; 1884, three ; 1892, one ; since when there have probably een others. The only record of private ownership is the pair of the hilippine race ( D . a. chalyburo ) collected in 1903 by Walter Good- llow for Mrs. E. J. Johnstone. Pigeons collectively do not enjoy the popularity with aviculturists ley perhaps deserve. The smaller Fruit Pigeons, on the rare occa- ons they are imported, usually find ready buyers as the majority ~e so very beautiful. But the larger species, such as the present hich measures 15--17 inches in length, would probably prove almost asaleable, except to a zoo--and that is really the best place for them. In August, 1954, a London dealer offered us five Green Imperials heir origin being unknown it was, of course, impossible to determine te race) and despite the fact we had no suitable accommodation e bought them. Fortunately, John Yealland, as on many other :casions, both before and since, kindly eased the situation by taking iem on deposit at the London Zoo : and there they remained for iarly two years, until May, 1956, when they were finally trans- rred to our newly constructed range of pigeon aviaries. Having "en at the Zoo for so long one would have thought they would have ien very steady and that nothing could disturb them. But such

146 A. A. PRESTWICH-BREEDING OF THE GREEN IMPERIAL PIGEON was far from being the case ; they were exceedingly timid and on the slightest pretext would panic, somehow " half-roll " and hang suspended from the roof of the flights--it will perhaps be remembered from past accounts that the flights of these particular aviaries are composed entirely of close-woven wattle fencing, except the roof which is wire-netting. However, they gradually quietened down and at the present time are as steady as one could reasonably expect. We assumed that if, as we hoped, they attempted to nest it would be some time during March, April, or May. We were reconciled to the fact we had missed the 1956 breeding season and so we were not disappointed that they showed no signs of nesting during the remaining summer months. Autumn and winter passed and they appeared to be troubled not at all by the cold. At the Zoo they had had a heated house to use if they were so disposed, but with us they have only half-open shelters, facing north ; and as often as noi they did not use them but roosted out. So they may be considerec quite hardy. We experienced considerable difficulty in pairing them up as ir coloration and size the sexes appear to be exactly similar. Finally mainly as a result of trial and error, we sorted out what we believec to be two pairs ; the odd bird being paired with a surplus Piec Imperial. Wooden seed-trays were provided as platforms for the expectec nests, and roughly formed foundation nests of straw were added as ai incentive. Straw, however, proved an unsuitable nesting material In common with some other Fruit Pigeons this species has somewha specialized feet, very strong with broad soles, developed to enable it t< clamber about branches and so reach fruit that would otherwise b difficult of access. While indulging in courtship pursuit they frequent! landed on the platforms, with the result that the straw was draggei out and scattered. Hay proved a quite successful alternative. Th actual nests were of a very scanty nature--little more indeed tha a few wisps of hay. At the beginning of January we started dusting the food wit powdered cuttle-fish bone--this with a view to obviating egg-layin troubles that might be due to any calcium deficiency. It certainl had the desired effect as none was experienced. Pair No. 1. On 9th March an egg was laid in the sand at the froi of the flight. It was unfortunately punctured. On 1st April an egg wt laid in the sand at the back of the flight and another was found in t! nest : both of these were transferred to domestic pigeons, but the proved to be infertile. A fourth egg was laid on 22nd April, but w; deserted after a week or so and was removed on 3rd May. The measur< ments of three of these eggs were 42 X 32 mm., 42*1 X 32-6 mrr and 42*2 X 32*5 mm. ; they were pure white with a slight gloss.

A. A, PRESTWIGH-BREEDING OF THE GREEN IMPERIAL PIGEON 1 47 Pair No. 2. An egg was laid on 27th April, but was thrown out of le nest and broken on 7th May. A second egg was laid on 1st June, he female settled down and as incubation progressed she became icreasingly tame, eventually so much so that towards the end of the eriod she even allowed herself to be stroked while on the nest. Both arents spent a great deal of time on the nest. We were unable to scide whether the male was actually assisting in the incubation or hether he was merely keeping his mate company. During the iree or four days prior to the hatching both hardly left the nest, he egg was found to have " starred " on the afternoon of the 20th id had hatched by next morning. The incubation period is believed ) have been eighteen days. It is, however, rather difficult to determine lis point with any accuracy because the female did not begin seriously > incubate until several days after the laying of the solitary egg. The nestling in down was dark rufous above and pale rufous-brown clow. The female brooded it very closely, so closely in fact that it ive cause for anxiety as the weather part of the time was very hot ideed. This close-brooding lasted for about a week and may have sen the reason why the young one appeared to be very slow to svelop--at least by domestic pigeon standards. It then grew rapidly, est it leave the nest prematurely a heap of straw was placed beneath > break its fall. This, however, proved to be an unnecessary precau- on. It was strong and robust and by 1 ith July was perching on the Ige of the nest, managing to reach a perch the following day and Lenceforward finding its way round the aviary quite easily. On leaving the nest the young one appeared to be an almost exact :plica of its parents except that it was, of course, very much smaller, was a little less brightly coloured, with the legs and feet paler, but it ad quite a high gloss on the back and wings. It throve amazingly id was, and is, a great credit to its parents who, in their turn, at 1 times behaved in a really exemplary manner, even now with wer a hint of spitefulness. Food. In captivity the feeding of these large pigeons presents little fficulty : they will thrive on a very wide variety of foods. We have lown one species do very well, for a time at least, on damsons and >aked brown bread ! Our own staple food consists of apples, bananas, tomatoes, and dates, iced, mixed together and dried off with coarse biscuit-meal. The "ying off is very important, otherwise the birds will soon become iry soiled round the head, neck, and breast, and look very unsightly. It have tried several biscuit-meals and found the most satisfactory > be " Stamina " Poultry Biscuit Meal, which we put through a incing machine. To this staple mixture we add, as available, a rge variety of extras, grapes, cherries, plums, pears, pomegranates, een peas, chopped lettuce ; boiled potatoes, carrots, rice ; soaked

148 A. A. PRESTWICH-BREEDING OF THE GREEN IMPERIAL PIGEON sultanas, apricots, and figs. We do not give any form of milk-soj soaked sponge-cake, or insectivorous food, as is sometimes recommende for some of the smaller species. The food for a dozen Green and Pied Imperials takes quite a b of preparing. It does not, however, need to be chopped very fine! Both these species have enormous gapes and are capable of swallowir incredibly large pieces. In the wild state they are partial to nutme; which they swallow whole with ease : later, when the peel has bee digested, the nut is disgorged. From the time the young one was hatched a heaped teaspoonful <' " Bemax " containing a couple of drops of cod liver oil was sprinkle on the food. Water. The authorities are still somewhat divided on whether tb pigeon drinks in the wild state. There can really be little doubt th; it is a regular drinker. Naturally, we provide water at all times, bu as yet, have never seen one drink. Postscript .--The young one was separated from its parents c 6th August as they showed signs of nesting again. An egg was in fa laid on 9th August and duly hatched on 1st September. The squc is at present only two days old, and much now depends on the weathe As described above, A. A. Prestwich has bred the Green Imperi Pigeon (Ducula aenea). It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of tl species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to cor municate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.reference: J. L. THROP-KEEPING THE PALE-BILLED WOODPECKER
algorithms.bodyText: By J. L. Throp (Curator, Buteyn Bird Ranch, San Luis Rey, California, U.S.A.) There is a group of large woodpeckers found in North and Central merica which are regarded as being the most impressive of all wood- :ckers. Members of this group practically all fall under different nera, the only reason for calling them a group at all is their somewhat nilar appearance. They are all crested and have some semblance of a hite V on the back. This group contains the rapidly disappearing orth American Ivory-billed Woodpecker and the Mexican Imperial bodpecker, the largest of all woodpeckers, measuring 20 to 22 inches, hese two species, due to their specialized feeding habits, cannot survive e encroachment of civilization. Other members are much better voured, the Pileated Woodpecker and the one we are now concerned ith, the Pale-billed Woodpecker (Phoeceastes guatemalensis ) are two. ther members are found south of Mexico. The members of this group have not often been kept in captivity, he feeding habits are so demanding that few people would assume ch a burden. George and Evelyn Whitney, of Elsinore, California, d assume this challenge, and the following information was compiled the hope it may add to the general knowledge of these magnificent rds. George Whitney, Jerome Buteyn, and Pat Murphy took a trip to in Bias, Nayarit, Mexico, in the early part of May, 1955. They are 1 bird enthusiasts and the trip was one of observation with the hope bringing something home for their collections. A Pale-billed Woodpecker's nest was discovered a few miles from in Bias along one of the forest tracks. The nest was in an old, rotten ilm tree about 16 feet from the ground. The palm had broken off the junction of a previous woodpecker's nest. The wood was soft id pulpy. Two unfeathered young were taken ; from the colour of ie skin and pin-feathers of the crown, we know they were a pair, ne was red and the other was black, the red-crested was the male id was also the larger. The two birds ate mealworms readily, and p meals were missed. The female, regrettably, was accidentally lied before they got home. Coming back from Mexico, 108 degrees temperature was en- mntered in the Arizona desert and all the mealworms died. T he hole of the last day home the bird survived on those worms. A short while after the bird's capture several black specks were )ticed under the skin. These grew quite large ; one of them was need and a large grub-like creature filled with blood was squeezed

I50 J. L. THROP-KEEPING THE PALE-BILLED WOODPECKER out. Seven or eight of these parasites were removed and what futur effect these might have had can only be speculated. The bird was fed exclusively on mealworms for the first two month' By this time he ate about fifty a day in two feedings. Other insect lif was tried during this time and it invariably caused indigestion Hard-boiled egg yolk was introduced and eventually the whole c the yolk and part of the white was consumed every day. He had , liking for " mocking bird food ", though objected if it was dampened The most notable thing connected with this bird was his sensitiv digestive system. It was felt that an effort should be made to get the bird on a mor varied diet, and since these woodpeckers eat a small quantity of berrie and fruits in season, one soaked raisin was fed the bird. For two days b moaned and complained with a stomach-ache. A week later he wa again given a soaked raisin and again he complained, but for a shorte time. The raisin was given with increasing frequency until it became ; staple item. In season he also got two grapes each day, but he had t( be started on these half a grape at a time and still he was upset. Th< tiniest piece of apple produced the same results until eventually he wa eating a piece about the size of a thumb-nail at each feeding. At one time the woodpecker got indigestion that continued for tw( days. The Whitneys were at their wits end trying to figure the cause It was found that when potatoes, for moisture, were put in the brar containing mealworms the worms became toxic and the bird invariable was sick. Apples used for the same purpose caused no ill-effects nor die the flat cactus leaves. These leaves are preferred by most California aviculturists and are cut in strips and laid on top of the bran. He wa' very fond of bread slightly dampened with milk but this always gave him indigestion so it was given sparingly. The moult was made gradually so the bird always looked in top con- dition with a fine sheen on the feathers. George thought it odd, but the\ never found any of the red crest feathers. In the spring the normally white areas of the bird, the wing patches, and the V on the back, turnec bright yellow. George thinks this may be due to the sulphur conten in the egg yolks given. The woodpecker was given a lot of freedom in the house anc became increasingly destructive until he was about two months old At this time he attacked the wood panelled den and in a short time had a hole that soon would have gone through the wall to the outside. He was put in an all-metal cage 4 feet square and 2 feet high where he quickly adjusted himself. For preoccupation he would busily pulverize a piece of two by four wood put in his cage every few days. He disliked a small clapper bell intensely and spent much time worrying it. George found the bird would go into battle stance, raise the crest as far forward as it would go, when he tapped the water container with /
algorithms.listItem: E. J. BOOSEY-BREEDING OF THE SENEGAL PARROT 151 * lis finger. The bird would dance along his perch and his eyes would
algorithms.bodyText: take on a glazed stare. It was definitly threatening. The woodpecker never acted this way to Mrs. Whitney. The loss of the bird was caused after two years in confinement when the Whitneys ran out of mealworms, the principal item in the diet. When their stock got down to 500 they would order more from their dealer. The 500 reserve would last ten days, it generally took only three or four days to receive the worms but they allowed a grace period to cover any delay. This time a severe delay occurred and the worms were not sent until fourteen days after they were ordered. The Whitneys made every effort to get them from local people, but nobody carried them in any quantity and with the diminishing supply of worms the bird soon died. The loss was felt very strongly. From the trials encountered with this bird, they feel it would be impossible to maintain a captured adult. The Whitneys plan to obtain another youngster of this group and see just how much they have
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING OF THE SENEGAL PARROT (POICEPHALUS SENEGALUS) AT THE KESTON FOREIGN BIRD FARM
algorithms.bodyText: By Edward J. Boosey (Keston, Kent, England) I have always had a particularly soft spot in my heart for Senegal Parrots as I had a delightfully tame one for 21 years, and I am conse- quently very pleased to be able to record the successlul bleeding of the species here at the Keston Foreign Bird Farm this 1957 season. It seems that this may be a first breeding. Apparently they are said to have been bred in 1886, before the Avicultural Society had come into existence, but our Hon. Secretary, Mr. Prestwich, who is I think acknowledged to be the chief authority on the subject, wi ote to me saying that he had " always regarded the. 1886 report as rather more than suspect ". Before the war we had a very fine-looking, and I should ha\e said obvious, pair of Senegals here at Keston, but, although given every opportunity to do so, they never made any attempt to breed, so after we had had them for about three years, we parted with them. Then after the war we decided to try again, this time with a couple consisting of one we had purchased and one that had been kindly sent to us by Miss Knobel. They are by no means easy birds to sex, particularly single individuals, but Miss Knobel had rightly assumed that her bird was a hen and ours fortunately turned out to be a cock. As a breeding proposition, however, they did not seem a vciy

E. J. BOOSEY-BREEDING OF THE SENEGAL PARROT promising pair owing to their extreme wildness, both of them--as they still do dashing panic-stricken into their shelter uttering their worst slate pencil screeches, if anybody went near their aviary. They were very secretive about their nesting operations and I personally never saw either of them taking the slightest interest in their nest-box, but, as the hen eventually disappeared and as there was no sign of a corpse in the aviary, we assumed that she was sitting. This was in May and some time later, when both birds were in the flight and dashed headlong into the shelter, we decided to shut them in and have a look in the nest-box. The inspection revealed three half-grown young ones, all of which have been sucessfully reared and are now flying with their parents. The first one to fledge, which had the curious habit of frequently going back to spend long periods in the nest-box, came out about 6th July, and the other two some four days later. They are very fine young- sters, as will be seen from the accompanying photograph, which my partner Alec Brooksbank took when the youngest of them had only been out of the nest a couple of days or so. Actually the first intimation I had that they were starting to fledge was when one morning I approached their aviary and was astonished to see a Senegal Parrot sitting calmly on a perch instead of dashing wildly into the shelter ! Closer inspection of course revealed its dark eyes, but the only difference from its parents in plumage was its very dark grey crown and pale ashy grey cheeks, as is the case with the other two. Altogether I don't think I have ever seen such grown-up looking young ones--newly-fledged Blue-fronted Amazons, for instance, looking such very obvious juveniles. 1 he nest-box, measuring about io inches square by 24 inches deep with half a coconut husk fixed in the bottom, was hung up under over- head cover in the open flight. In addition to their staple diet of sunflower, canary, hemp, and peanuts, the parent Senegals were given, while rearing their brood, a considerably increased amount of hemp and various extras. These consisted of boiled potato and carrot as well as a large cube of stale bread previously soaked in sweetened milk to which Virol, etc., had been added. These were given daily and we also offered them boiled white fish of which my tame Senegal was so fond--but this they refused to sample, so it was discontinued. They always have spinach beet leaves and apple about twice a week throughout the year, and during the rearing period, both were given daily. Finally, for the benefit of anyone who might not be familiar with the appearance of these small parrots, I would just add that the Senegal is green with a grey head, and with the lower breast and abdomen 01 ange-yellow. Its total length is a little over 9 inches.
algorithms.affiliation: Three young Senegal Parrots (3 days after the last one was fledged)
