algorithms.figure: Avic. Mag Dufresne's Waxbills
algorithms.sectionHeader: Avicultural Magazine THE JOURNAL OF THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY AND THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA
algorithms.bodyText: Vol. 63.--No. 6 .-- All rights reserved . NOVEMBER-DECEMBER, 1957

('Coccopygia melanotis melanotis) By J. J. Yealland (London, England) Dufresne's Waxbill, also known as the Yellow-bellied Waxbill and, in South Africa, as the Swee Waxbill was first described in 1817 by Vieillot who named it Fringilla dufresni, but the description was considered by Sclater to be inapplicable because of being so faulty, and Temminck ( PL Col., livr. xxxvi, 1833, pi. 221, fig. 1) is now the accepted author. This Waxbill inhabits south-eastern Africa, being said by Stark to be migratory in part of its range, but resident in Natal and the Transvaal. Sclater recognized five races, the Angola Yellow-bellied Waxbill (C. m. bocagei), the Kenya (C. m. kilimensis), the Uganda (C. m. nyanzae ), and the Abyssinian (C. m. quartina ) being the others. Stark says, " In Natal this pretty little species is, when not breeding, usually met with in small parties of ten or twelve, feeding on the ground on grass-seeds. . . . This Waxbill breeds in Natal not un- commonly, but not, so far as I have observed, near the coast. Not far from Howick, at a height of about 3,000 feet, I have met with their nests in some numbers. Unlike many of the Waxbills, they build in tall bushes and young trees, at a height of from six to ten feet. The nests are rough-looking, oval structures, with an entrance hole on one side, constructed of fine dry grass. The flowering ends of the grass being woven together, the stiff stalks are left projecting in all directions. The interior is lined with grass tops, down, and feathers. The eggs are very small, pure white in colour, and four or five in number. When first hatched the young are fed on small caterpillars." Dufresne's Waxbill was first bred in the British Isles by Miss Elsie Robinson, who wrote a good account of the occurrence for the Avicultural Magazine (1934, p. 249) and was awarded the Society's medal. Mr. H. S. Sewell bred it in Adelaide during the following i79

180 E. H. HAWKE--BREEDING SUCCESSES IN LOURENQO MARQUES year ( A.M . 1935, p. 182). The most recent published success ( A.M . 1949, P- 9 ) was Mr. Dulanty's at Chorley Wood, Hertfordshire, when; two broods were reared. These articles contain valuable information on the care and breeding of this charming Waxbill.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING SUCCESSES AND FAILURES IN LOURENgO MARQUES
algorithms.bodyText: By E. H. Hawke (Lourengo Marques, Portuguese East Africa) Although I appreciate all too well how boring accounts of breeding this and that can become, it does occur to me that some of the successes; (and failures) in this part of the world, where, I think I am right in saying I am the only member, and which is probably not well known to many of your readers, might be of interest. Lourengo Marques, the capital of Portuguese East Africa, is situated on the mainland some 250 miles (as the crow flies) north of Durban. It enjoys one of the finest climates of the world during four months of the year (May-August) ; is very pleasant during another four (March- April and September-October), but from November-February, it is not to be recommended. Our rains fall during the summer months except for odd showers and when it rains, it rains. Aviary drainage and shelters therefore need careful watching, otherwise there is a risk of finding oneself with accommodation more suited to fish than birds. In all I have at the moment twenty-four aviaries, with another five about to be constructed. Four of these are planted, the largest measuring 15 feet by 45 feet by 18 feet. The rest, including those to be constructed, are in the main, breeding cages. They vary slightly in dimensions and shape, but roughly are in units measuring 4 feet by 8 feet by 12 feet, which can be combined if required to form larger areas. From both the ornithologists' and aviculturists' point of view, Portuguese East Africa is an area which delights both the heart and the eye. Still, in many districts, comparatively unspoiled by the advent of man, there are some 900 different species of birds ranging from the lordly Ostrich down to the tiniest of the warblers, in greater or lesser profusion, and no matter where you may roam, it will be a rare exception if no bird is in view. One would think that with such a wealth of bird life close at hand, no one in their sane senses would look beyond our boundaries for aviary stock, but what aviculturist is sane ? Naturally my collection, which now comprises some 100 species and 500 birds, is made up mainly of locally procured stock, but I am always ready to accept

E. H. HAWKE-BREEDING SUCCESSES IN L0UREN#0 MARQUES 1 8 1 gangers, and I have a few representatives from Australia, India, nd South America amongst my birds. The largest of my planted aviaries houses hornbills ( Lophocerus asutus epirhinus), rollers ( Coracias garrulus, Coraciura caudata, Eucoracias wsambicus), weavers, starlings, bulbuls, doves, barbets and thrushes nd the smallest, a wide variety including most of our waxbills and unbirds. It is, of course, difficult to keep such mixed families on ood terms with each other, and every now and then a dispute ends 1 tragedy but, by and large, they seem to get along reasonably well. )f course, I do keep the worst offenders to themselves, but it is quite stonishing--at least to me--how frequently one can find a real bad-egg " amongst what normally is considered a peaceful species. As I write, a new breeding season is upon us and there is activity 1 all directions. As usual, I am hoping for miracles but will, of course, e satisfied with whatever the fates permit. I hold crossed fingers for ly African Greys, down on eggs for the fifth or sixth time, but who ave never yet " delivered the goods ". I have hopes that my Lilac- reasted Rollers and Sunbirds will this season do something more lan play at raising a family--a pastime which they apparently enjoy, always feel that it is a poor reward for days spent rushing around the eighbourhood collecting cobwebs--arousing in the process the ravest suspicions amongst individuals who, at the best of times, are pt to look upon the aviculturist as not quite " all there "--and etching a beautiful nest grow before one's eyes, to find the couple iddenly lose interest. Incidentally, I have in my aviaries Scarlet- reasted, Amethyst, Marico, Purple-banded, Neergaard's, White- reasted, Collared, Grey, and Olive Sunbirds, and such attempts at est construction that I have witnessed, both in the aviaries and out, ave been the work of the female only. The male appears to spend lost of his time urging his wife to greater and greater efforts, though e is never averse to passing the time of day with any other member f the opposite sex who might pass his way. Just in case it might be of interest to fellow aviculturists, I list the )ecies which have bred successfully in my aviaries, i.e. the young ave perched and grown to maturity. Ruddy, Common, Orange-
algorithms.reference: reasted, Blue-breasted and Jameson's Waxbills, Hooded Finches, ed-backed Mannikins, Streaky-headed Seed-eaters, Melba Finches, olden-breasted Buntings, Cut-throat Finches, Magpie-Robins lopsychus saularis), Red-vented Bulbuls ( Molpastes cafer), Crested arbets, Ring-necked and Laughing Doves, Speckled-backed and olden Weavers, Speckled Colies, Peach-faced and Nyasa Lovebirds, idian Ring-necks, Eastern Rosellas, Cockatiels, Brown-headed
algorithms.bodyText: arrots ( Poicephalus cryptoxanthus ) and Blue-fronted Parrots. There are innumerable others which have tried, some getting no irther than building a nest, others laying, and others even producing

1 82 E. H. HAWKE-BREEDING SUCCESSES IN LOURENgO MARQUES young which for some reason or another have not made the grade I am one of that group which does not believe in disturbing any bin- that is about its business of raising a family, so I cannot provid much information regarding the number of eggs laid, incubatio periods, etc. Food is of the widest possible variety ; all kinds of seec fruit, bread soaked in milk, minced meat, insectivorous foods, liv food (grasshoppers, mealworms, gentles, white ants), greenfood, s there is something for all tastes, and it is surprising what some of then will eat. To me a Sunbird with a juicy piece of minced meat wa something unexpected. Those which share the Sunbird aviary als- enjoy the nectar mixture and fruit flies, and the bird that does not tak some nectar certainly is the exception. I do a certain amount of trapping myself but, having a business t attend to, the opportunities are few and far between. The natives however, bring in specimens from time to time, and it is really 01 them that I rely for replenishing and adding to my collection. Fat also lends a hand, as one may judge from the following two incident which may prove of interest. I had been trying for some time to secure a Black-collared Barbel but could never find a native collector with sufficient intelligence t find one of the hollow logs in which these Barbets normally roosl One day, however, I was doing some writing in my study when ou cook-boy approached with a bird clutched in his hand--a CollareJ Barbet, of course ! As he had been walking through our back yard the bird had fallen at his feet, having apparently stunned itself b striking an overhead telephone wire. This in the middle of a fair! large town. The second incident concerns a Narina Trogon (.Apaloderma narina) I was telephoned one afternoon by my wife who, though she bears wit! my affliction, is not too well versed in bird identification, to say ; Coucal was flying around our garden and the gardener thought h could catch it--should she permit the attempt. Not wishing to dam] her enthusiasm, I agreed, and when I returned home about 5 p.m I facetiously demanded to see the bird, only to be told that it hac disappeared. My wife, however, insisted on my going out to se exactly where the Coucal had been spotted and lo, there was n< Coucal, but a Narina Trogon. All forces were summoned, but th bird made off and I said good-bye to my hopes of owning one c those beautiful jewels. Next day I was busy in my office situated in the centre of a ver busy port area, when a friend walked in with a bird in his hand--yes the Trogon. He had been walking along the street to see me 01 business when this bird flew into his stomach and stunned itseli Admittedly the target was of no mean size, but what luck. Both bird lived in my aviaries for a number of years.
E. N. T. VANE-REARING THE YELLOW-CHEEKED AMAZON

(.Amazona autumnalis autumnalis ) By E. N. T. Vane (Great Missenden, England) The Yellow- or Primrose-cheeked Amazon is found fairly well iistributed in south-east Mexico and the northern areas of Central \merica, but only occasionally are odd specimens available in this :ountry. According to Peters' Check List it is only regarded as a sub-species to Salvin's, Lesson's or Lilacine and the Diademed \mazons, but it is without doubt by far the most handsome of the four. The body colour is a bright green, lighter on the under parts, rhe frontal band is a bright cerise, the crown a delicate pale lilac i)lue, the edge of each feather being darker. This colour merges into ;he green of the nape and mantle and again these feathers are imarginated with a blackish shade. The cheeks are chrome-yellow extending from the bill below the eye to the ear-coverts, this area peing flecked with cerise in some cases. On the bend of the wing s a patch of pale yellowish-green. The primaries are bluish and there s an orange-red speculum. The tail is green, lighter on the underside md yellowish towards the tip. The bill is yellowish horn with blackish ireas on the upper mandible. The eye is brilliant gold which can /ary considerably, sometimes when excited the pupil becomes very imall and the iris literally blazes, at other times the colour appears :o separate into two rings of red and yellow. The eye is surrounded py a narrow, white skin orbital area, and in some birds the eyes appear :o have distinct lashes. The feet are grey, with black claws. The sexes ire alike, though cocks are larger in the head and bill. Immature pirds resemble the parents in all details, except that the eye is dark prown and the bill darker towards the point of the upper mandible. Some specimens have traces of yellow on the throat. Length is about [4 to 15 inches. The pair of birds in my possession started laying when they were ibout three years old. They have twice succeeded in hatching young previously, and have had young dead in shell every other season ; :he eggs have always been fertile. The cock is most aggressive in the breeding season, indeed he is always seeking the opportunity to ittack someone or something and frequently vents his spite on his poor hen, who is a charmingly friendly bird by comparison. His avourite amusement is to knock her off the perch and watch her :limb back. She accepts this as normal good manners, and always akes her time to come back within his reach. She regards any outside nterference in this procedure as unwarranted between husband and vife, and is always ready to join him in a cursing match. This trait s probably the cause of their repeated failures to rear their young, as - ,1 \0x25A0 1 r.,' \; . v 1 'ic x, <3. *[, 'I 1"

algorithms.bodyText: 184 E. N. T. VANE-REARING THE YELLOW-CHEEKED AMAZON every year just as the hen should be incubating, it is time for th adjoining land to be ploughed or sown, and this is the signal for th cock to start his nonsense. They are both good talkers, and hav taught several of the other birds to talk as well. It is always amusin to hear the cock encouraging the hen in the depths of the nest boJ and to hear her muffled replies coming back. But every time he star swearing at the farm hands over the hedge, or any other intrude such as a cat, fox, or other visitor, the hen immediately joins him an comes off her eggs. Unfortunately, this amuses visitors, who ai of course, entirely unauthorized, and they linger and talk to th parrots and are frequently indignant when asked to clear off. Last year our Grey Parrot laid two clutches of eggs on the floe of her cage--one of the usual 18-inch square type--and incubate them assiduously. Naturally these were abortive as she had no matt but we decided to take advantage of her exemplary behaviour prq vided she laid at the same time as the Amazons. " Polly " woul not tolerate any form of nesting material for her eggs ; woode nest-pans and shallow boxes of peat, sand, and rotten chips wer, tried, but she laboriously removed the lot or pushed them asidd Again she laid this Spring, rather earlier than usual, but it coincide with the Amazons nesting in their flight (which is only about 18 fe( long with a nest-box outside ; they seem to prefer to climb thoug both are excellent fliers when so inclined), so we put our intention t exchange the eggs into operation ; there was little to lose, anyhow, z\ sure enough they started to plough the field three days after incubatio should have started. Collecting the Grey's eggs was a simple matter, she never mine anything I do to her, and when the eggs were removed she just gc up on the perch and had a good feed. She really was not perturbec: and seemed to be quite confident that I would return the eggs ur harmed in due course. Getting the Amazon's eggs was quite anothe matter altogether. The box was outside the flight, covered externall with an asbestos sheet in case the birds whittled their way right througl a task well within their powers, as they strip a three-inch perch in day and soon finish it altogether ; but strangely enough they hav had this same nest-box for seven seasons and have scarcely damage it beyond enlarging the entrance hole. After several attempts t manoeuvre the birds away from their box, we finally succeeded i stuffing a sack in the hole from the top of the box and removed th eggs with a long-handled ladle, replacing them with the infertil Grey's eggs. There were only two Amazon eggs, their usual elute being three. These were duly given to " Polly " on the thickly sandei floor of her cage in the living room on 27th May, when she promptl started incubating closely. Meanwhile the Amazons carried on a in previous years. The hen duly retired to the box, but the cock wa

E. N. T. VANE-REARING THE YELLOW-CHEEKED AMAZON 1 85 o aggressive and demonstrative that she was constantly coming off o see what all the bother was about. On 16th June, she was off for pfite a lengthy period, and after the usual ceremony of the cock mocking her off the perch, I decided to have another look. She had aid a third egg which was again removed. I had taken the pre- :aution of marking the eggs, which were almost identical in size md appearance. The Grey's were possibly a little more rounded, 3ut it would have been most difficult to distinguish them with any legree of certainty. This occurred during a very hot spell of weather when the Amazon was sitting very lightly, in fact almost appeared to lesert for a few days, although she brooded every night. It is possible hat these birds, coming from a very hot climate, might well rely on ;he heat of their surroundings to keep their nest warm for quite engthy periods during daylight hours, and this may account for their msatisfactory results in this country in other years. " Polly " sat very closely in the corner of the room we used daily, ffie was perfectly friendly and normal, and used to come off and eed regularly every morning when her bowls of food and water were 'enewed. She still liked to have her poll scratched, and once this was done, she immediately settled down to her task once more, and Yas left undisturbed for the rest of the day. This was exactly as she aehaved on other occasions. Mr. Arthur Lamb has recorded that when he bred an Amazon the ncubation period was twenty-one days, so we calculated that these iggs were due to hatch any time after 19th June. About this time ' Polly " started to soak her breast and thigh feathers each morning, md since she did not resent my help, the eggs were floated in a bowl ff warm water for a few minutes. One sank and the other two floated. [ have not found this a reliable method of determining whether the igg will hatch or not, but mention the fact for what it is worth. The Glrey immediately returned to her eggs when they were replaced. 3n the 22nd the eggs were again submitted to this treatment, and an this occasion there was a most definite movement in one of the loating eggs and I could hear a definite tap from the interior. On Sunday the 23rd, one egg had a clearly visible chip, and I could hear the young bird squeaking inside the shell. Shortly before midday, whilst I was out, the first little Yellow-cheek broke through. It was assisted by the foster-mother who very carefully cut the top out in a small circle, so that the young one wriggled through a hole leaving the shell in two clean pieces. Of the other two eggs, one was clear and one addled in the early stages. It is therefore assumed that the latter was the egg removed on 16th June, which had been spoilt by the unreliable sitting habit of the Amazon hen, and that the ertile egg was removed on 29th May, together with the infertile ane. So the incubation period was twenty-five to twenty-six days.

I 86 E. N. T. VANE-REARING THE YELLOW-CHEEKED AMAZON Stage I. First Feed. --The young bird is lifted bodily by the head. The point o the bill is forced between the young bird's mandibles at the back, and liquid is regurgitated and trickled down the tongue from the other side into the mouth. Stage II. Second Feed. --Parent takes tip of young's bill and starts jerking head with pumping action.

E. N. T. VANE REARING THE YELLOW-CHEEKED AMAZON 1 87 The African Grey was entirely calm and unperturbed with her xomplishment, she behaved like an experienced mother, never in le least worried but obviously very pleased with the result of her itience. She brooded the chick very closely, making no attempt 1 feed it for the first twenty-four hours, although she repeatedly eaned it. She moved it about by lifting it bodily by the head. She as supplied with the usual seeds, bread and milk with Abidec added, so soaked brown bread, with sprouted seeds and greenfood, which ie enjoyed and consumed in increasing quantity as the youngster 'ogressed. We now had a unique opportunity to observe exactly how a parrot ts about rearing its young, as the whole of the operation was carried it oblivious to our close interest and observation. The parent rd was completely absorbed in her task, and did not resent our 'esence in the least. The first feed was given on the second day. he young bird was first lifted bodily by the head, and the point of e parent's upper mandible was then gently inserted into the small tp of the youngster's mandibles right at the rear as shown in sketch i. le then trickled liquid down her tongue into the opposite side of the iby's mandibles. Once the young bird started feeding thus, this ocedure was no longer necessary and as soon as the mother clucked, e young one instinctively raised its head and gaped ready to accept i food. Taking the tips of the mandibles in her beak the mother en applied the usual pumping action of regurgitation and one uld actually watch the young one's crop fill out (see sketch 2). t this stage feeding was carried out with unfailing punctuality every t> hours. The consistency of the crop milk was about the same as at of ordinary milk. For practically the whole of the first two weeks e Grey brooded continuously, but thereafter left the nest for a lile for longer and longer periods. Feeding intervals were slowly creased to three hours, until six weeks had passed, when the meals n-e increased in frequency, but decreased in bulk. During this time, 0, the consistency of the food was also thickened. By this time the ung bird was becoming very intelligent and knew full well that every ne mother had something to eat, it would get a taste, and it was not .ckward in asking for its share. At about ten days, the eyes began to open and quills began to *pear. At this stage we were a little apprehensive that the difference colour might upset the mother. We need not have concerned rselves, however, as " Polly " was a most attentive and competent rent. The floor of the cage became littered with seed husks, but no tempt was made to clean it out for the first month in case she rented it. I was in fact away at the time, and no one else dared put hand inside the cage, this applied whether she had a youngster or t. At a month old, the squab resembled nothing more than a dirty

looking pin-cushion, and was extremely awkward-looking and ugh but " Polly " thought it was the loveliest thing that ever happenec and she spent hours cleaning it. The young one grew rapidly, and as the feathers opened out th young bird was deliberately taught to preen itself and was always i spotless condition. The plumage was complete at seven weeks, exact! similar to the adult bird's, except that the flight and tail feathers wer not fully developed. The young bird was just over eight weeks ol when it first succeeded in climbing on to the central perch--an ag at which it would normally have reached the stage of peeping oi of the nest hole. Its bill was blackish on the upper mandible, yellowis; at the edges and towards the point. The eye was dark and the fet grey. On its breast it has a few yellowish feathers. The fact that i plumage is similar to the adult was interesting, as according to som accounts, many Amazons are reputed to be all green when immatui and to assume full colour when a year or more has passed.

Year after year numerous members inform us either that they hav had a good breeding season or that they are satisfied with their result; I am afraid we are never completely satisfied--but we are ourselvc mainly to blame that our results fail to come up to our expectation because we keep far too many birds. We seem to have a faculty fc accumulating them ! During the winter all the pheasant pens and pigeon flights wei entirely rebuilt, the passage at the back of the main aviaries w i reconstructed and divided into six compartments, and a Caique hous with flight was built. It now only remains to overhaul completely th main aviaries, but that is a project we do not view with equanimity Last winter was, of course, comparatively mild, and our loss( directly attributable to the cold were remarkably few. We die however, lose our Egyptian Plovers, a Natal Robin, a Black-heade Sibia, and a Golden-breasted Bunting--all these in the wilderne: aviary. The occupants of the main range of parrakeet aviaries are Greer
algorithms.reference: winged Kings, Grimson-wings, Queen Alexandra's, Pennant's, Bauer' Cockatiels, Tovis, All-Green, Golden-winged, Lineolated ; Patagoniai Weddell's, Cactus, Black-headed and Yellow-cheeked Conures Noble Macaws ; Fischer's, Masked, Peach-faced and Abyssinia Lovebirds ; and Lesser Hill Mynahs and Chinese Collared Laughin Thrushes.
algorithms.table: KAY BONNER-DARENTH-HULME, 1 957
algorithms.bodyText: Few of the parrakeets made any great success of such attempts as :hey made to breed. The Pennants produced their usual brood, but whereas in the previous four years the young have left the nest in full, idult plumage, the four young this year were somewhat undersized, mottled dark green and red. All the Lovebirds increased their kind, out none of our pairs may be described as prolific. The Noble Macaws laid three eggs, but scattered them at an early stage of incubation. The colony of Lineolated Parrakeets just holds its own, a brood of three ate in September making up for earlier losses. The Red-faced Lovebird colony, numbering thirty-four, is a con- tinual source of interest. Last year's success when one young one was "eared has not been repeated, but it is not yet too Tate. A few new birds have been added to the wilderness aviary : Hilde- Drandt's Starlings, Chinese Hawfinches, Pekin Robins, and Red- :ollared and Yellow-backed Whydahs. Here the Common Mynahs reared broods of two and one ; the former very rickety, the latter a perfect bird. Purple-headed Glossy Starlings had several broods, but )nly succeeded in rearing one young one which was later scalped. Many Zebra and other small finches leave the nests, but the majority piite unaccountably disappear--presumably falling victims to some, is yet, undetected predator. The numerous pheasants, quails, bantams, pigeons and doves, both iomestic and foreign, continue to thrive and, in the main, increase. Our one real success, the breeding of the Green Imperial Fruit Pigeon, made up for any disappointments. The young one hatched on list September (see page 148) left the nest on the 22nd, and is as fine 1 bird as the first reared. We now have fourteen of these somewhat /oracious pigeons, seven Green Imperial, and seven Pied Imperial. The latter laid fourteen or fifteen eggs, but failed to hatch any. The most important recent arrivals are four Black Bronze-winged )r White-capped Ground Pigeons (Henicophaps albifrons schlegeli) Drought from the Aru Islands by W. J. C. Frost. At present they are /ery travel-stained, but eventually they should prove to be very landsome birds. The bird-rooms at present house seven White-bellied and four 31 ack-headed Caiques, five Senegal Parrots, one Mayer's Parrot, one Ahite-winged and three Canary-winged Parrakeets, three Black- :heeked Lovebirds, and one Greater Hill Mynah. Amongst our house Darrots we suffered the loss of our favourite Grey " Cocotte ", a venerable and very talented " lady " well known to many members )f the Society.
algorithms.figure: I90 A. GHIGI -A NEW MUTATION OF THE GOLDEN PHEASANT A NEW MUTATION OF THE GOLDEN PHEASANT (Chrysolophus pictus luteus) By Alessandro Ghigi (Bologna, Italy)
algorithms.bodyText: Adult Male. --Crest golden yellow slightly lighter than in the typical form ; rest of face, chin, throat and sides of neck, light yellow ; cape orange with the two steel blue bars as in the Golden Pheasant ; mantle dark green, with the lower portion of each feather yellowish ; lowei back and rump golden citron yellow ; central tail feathers pale brown dotted with light yellowish ; other tail feathers irregularly barred with pale brown and yellowish ; upper tail coverts same colour as central tail feathers in the lower web, with the upper wet yellow ; scapulars yellowish tipped with brown ; tertiaries and theii coverts dark brown ; secondaries and their coverts barred with more or less dark brown ; primaries light straw yellow ; all body feathers yellow, lighter in the middle of abdomen and on the lowei thigh ; tail-coverts yellow. Iris, wattles, and bare skin around orbits yellow ; beak and legs yellow horn. In substance, the more remarkable differences between this mutanl and the typical form are the total substitution of a yellow colour foi the scarlet, a dark brown for the blue of the wings, a citron yellow foi the rich yellow of the back, a pale brown for the black of the tail and wing-feathers, and the straw yellow primaries. Crest and cape are the same as is the visible portion of the green mantle. Young male. --General surface colour straw-yellow, very slightly barred with pale brown in all sections. On the sides of head yellow orange shades are noted. Wing and tail feathers have the same pattern as the typical form, but are extremely light-coloured with alternative bars or lines of brown and straw yellow. Adult female. --Same pattern as in the typical form, but the general surface colour instead of being buff barred and mottled, more or less plentifully with black, appears straw yellow, barred and mottled with brown, more or less pale according to the specimens and to the sections of the body considered. Primaries and secondaries, pale brown barred crosswise with straw yellow. Chick. --Creamy white at birth ; as soon as the epitrichium of the filoplumes has split the mottling appears the same as in the normal chick, but in much lighter shades. Origin. --The mutant male, first of the race, was brought to me: already adult, by Mr. Alexander Hampe from Coburg, in 1952. Having had an inkling of the matter through an advertisement issued in an avicultural journal, he thought I would be interested, and brought it to me. I was not able to obtain information about the place of origin, but it seems to have been in Bavaria.
algorithms.table: Avic. Mag. 1957. Adult Cock Mutant Golden Pheasant \0x25A0opyright] [A. Ghigi Primary Wing-feathers-- { above ) Mutant Female, { below ) Normal Female. To face p. 190
algorithms.bodyText: A. GHIGI-A NEW MUTATION OF THE GOLDEN PHEASANT 1 9 1 Breeding .--In the spring, 1953, a young normal golden female nated with the mutant did not lay eggs ; in 1954 an offspring of the isual colour resulted, whence it was shown that the mutant sire was ecessive. Two heterozygous females of this generation were mated vith their sire ; 1 entrusted Professor Taibel, Director of the Experi- nental Poultry Station of Rovigo, with one heterozygous male and wo heterozygous females. In 1955 my heterozygous hens produced normal heterozygotes and ecessive mutant homozygotes in the same proportions ; Professor raibel obtained in Rovigo 75 per cent normal dominants and 25 per :ent homozygous recessives. In the spring of the following year, 1956, it was confirmed that the nutants are homozygous, as both my young mutant specimens and hose from Rovigo (Taibel) exclusively produced mutants. My breeding was not very successful in 1956. The old cock, maybe jecause of the terrible cold suffered during the winter, did not fer- ilize the eggs of the first brood, but all the eggs laid by the hens nated with the young male were fertilized. Furthermore, various iccidents caused the death of some chicks during the rearing season. \nyway, excluding the first of the race, we now possess two adult nales and three adult females, three year-old males and six year-old emales. Altogether we have, the first of the race excepted, five adult nales and nine adult females. I have sent one adult male and two /oung females to the Zoological Garden of Rome ; furthermore, ast spring, I shipped a pen formed by one male and two females, ill heterozygous of the usual colour, to the Zoological Garden of Copenhagen, from where I have not yet had news concerning an eventual mutant offspring. Some further observations may be added : (1) The adult male, that lives now in the Zoological Garden of Rome is not perfectly similar to the sire ; some feathers of the throat show a brown edging, so that the bird appears to have a small collar in the throat. (2) The plumage colour is not of the same richness in all the female specimens ; some have darker bars compared with others. One must consider that the first mutant cock, arising from normal forms, may carry some multiple factor, to which a further variability is due. The above facts will be the subject of careful control in the next, 1 957? breeding season. Note .--In this breeding season (1957) I have reared about fifty mutant chicks.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 192 KARL PLATH-NEWS FROM THE BROOKFIELD ZOO NEWS FROM THE BROOKFIELD ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By Karl Plath, Curator of Birds (Brookfield, Ill., U.S.A.) " What's new at Brookfield this year ? " This question can be heard every year, for each year a new attraction is added for the benefit of the public. Last year an Okapi, before that the Otter Grotto, modernistic but attractive, before that the enormously popular Children's Zoo, a flock of the delightful, tiny Fairy Penguins (about 1 o inches high), a generous gift from one of our benefactors, Sir Edward Hallstrom, of Sydney, Australia, then from the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo came Emperor and Adelie Penguins. So now we have the extremes in size of these fascinating birds, for the lovable little Fairy Penguins scarcely weigh 2 pounds, while the largest of our three Emperors (about 4 feet high) weighed 80 pounds on arrival, and feels like a sack of sand when one bumps against it. Comparing the Emperor with the smaller King Penguin shows that the former has much more bulk, while the slimmer King which is about 10 inches shorter weighs on an average of 35 pounds. The Emperors, Kings, Adelies, and Humboldts occupy a large, glass-fronted cage about 30 feet across and 10 feet deep, with a glass-fronted pool almost as large, where they disport themselves with abandon. This enclosure is kept at a temperature between 50* and 6o*, usually 54 0 (fahrenheit), with germicidal lamps for germ-proof atmosphere and filters for pure air. The Fairy Penguins are kept in winter in one of the wall-cages (about 15 feet long), and in summer are active in one of the larger pools. But this article is to tell members of our latest remodelling--that of the Perching Bird House which attracted considerable attention about ten years ago in the making of a series of " picture-cages ", twenty of them along the east and west wings of the building. These are metal- framed, glass-fronted cages and are used for individual specimens best kept apart, such as the toucans, hornbills, several birds of paradise (also gifts from Sir Edward), and others. Now the effect is a long gallery of animated pictures, the subjects living birds behind their glass fronts. The lights are in the cages, and the passage dark. A large double door is at each end, but the main entrance is at the centre of this long gallery. When the visitor enters here he sees at first, or is aware of, large glass cages on each side of the door with numerous colourful small birds but he is mainly attracted to the huge " Freedom Room " which confronts him. This has no wire, no glass, and a portion of the picture gallery floor of beautiful terrazza extends into this open aviary. This has a railing to prevent the visitor from stepping down into it. In former years this large room had thirty-three wire-fronted cages all around it and a medium sized flying-cage in the centre. The alteration was started early in 1956, and opened to the public
algorithms.figure: Avic. Mag. 1957 Copyright ] The East End of the " Freedom Room " in the House at the Brookfield Zoo. [Ralph Graham Perching Bird To facep . 192
algorithms.sectionHeader: I KARL PLATH NEWS FROM THE BROOKFIELD ZOO 193
algorithms.bodyText: Christmas Day, 1956. The construction is of stainless steel and ite-glass, and the effect is very elegant. This main room has been transformed into a garden of exotic plants d flowers. There are three trees with bare branches for perching d a tall hollow tree in one corner partly hidden by a large date lm. There is more than one ground level--a little pool in a corner the top trickles into a larger one below it, and that again flows to a large pool which overflows by means of a gurgling waterfall to the largest pool immediately in the foreground beneath the rail, mbrella plants, banana plants, anthuriums, various aquatic plants, d many kinds of flowering plants border these pools and add to the )pical effect. To keep the interest below there are several striking aquatic birds-- arlet Ibis, Jacanas, Stilts, Crocodile Birds, a pair each of Mandarin acks, Formosan Teal, and several others. These birds are content stay in the water or on the ground, with the exception of a tame d fearless Sun-Bittern which often perches on the rail and sometimes (erates a little petting. In the trees and flying all about are other autiful birds--gorgeous rollers, motmots, Quetzal, barbets, touracos, d a brilliantly red Cock-of-the-Rock which often flies into the llery. Several other birds do this, Giant Whydahs, Long-tailed arlings, tanagers, Vermilion Cardinals, and some others, but all seem ntent to fly back and enjoy this brilliantly lighted bird paradise. The eat skylight 30 feet above protects the birds from flying up against it r being covered with plastic waffle-like panels. There are four double 0 watt lamps in the wall above, not too noticeable, and several ore lamps set below the floor under the railing beneath the floor. 1 of this light in the big cage makes the gallery comparatively dark, that most of the birds are happy to stay in the open-front aviary, lis improvement has worked wonders with the public, who are lighted and amazed when a brilliantly plumed Quetzal or touraco as their heads as it swoops by. Seemingly the birds have never been ore enjoyed. Of course we had to consider the nature and habits of the birds at were to be at large, and they had to be compatible. We knew at the jays and other large omnivorous birds would not be desirable, >r would most of the seed-eating finches which would also nibble the plant life ; so for these classes of birds there are other large mmunity glass cages, to accommodate various jays, oropendolas, ee-pies, Australian butcher birds, and two smaller cages housing e larger orioles, tanagers, and grosbeaks. For humming birds, mbirds, and callistes we have twelve comparatively small cages, as ost of these species do best kept separately. Our most interesting imming bird to date is the very tiny Vervain from Jamaica. Gener- ly speaking, it is our opinion that sunbirds do better ; they are
algorithms.sectionHeader: KARL PLATH-NEWS FROM THE BROOKFIELD ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: equally beautiful though, of course, do not have the rapid wing-bc of the hummer. Our Parrot House, while one of the Zoo's older buildings, still hou; a good collection. One outstanding member is a beautiful Guildin; Amazon (from the Bronx Zoo), and in all we have forty-six spec. (240 individuals) in this building. We are fortunate in being able keep all of these parrots outdoors from May to October, and have h good luck in breeding many of the larger Australian psittacines well as others ; outstanding being Grand Eclectus, Grays, and Rose? Cockatoos--unusual for this latitude. Later on we hope to do an article on the varied species in t beautiful Aquatic House ; we did do something on this years ag but many rarer specimens have been added. A list of the birds living in the " Freedom Room " at the Chica Zoological Park, Brookfield, Ill. of scientific order.
