algorithms.bodyText: S. T. JOHNSTONE-NOTES FROM THE WILDFOWL TRUST
algorithms.figure: Silver-eared Mesia Brazilian Scarlet Tanager Orange-rumped Tanager Giant Whydah Golden-backed Woodpecker Yellow-backed Cacique Red-legged Rail (Black Rail) Crocodile Bird American Jacana North American Stilt South American Stilt Golden Plover Scarlet Ibis Mandarin Duck Formosan Teal Red Cock of the Rock Mesia argentauris Ramphocelus bresileus Ramphocelus flammigerus Diatropura progne Brachypternus benghalensis Cacicus cela Limnocorax flavirostra Pluvianus aegyptius Jacana spinosa Himantopus himantopus mexicanus Himantopus himantopus melanurus Pluvialis apricaria Guara rubra Aix galericulata Anas formosa Rupicola sanguinolenta
algorithms.bodyText: There are from one to five of each of the above birds in this Freedom Room We did try a magnificent Racket-tailed Drongo, ut the first thing he did was to snap up two tiny Painted Quail, and e was removed pronto. We would like to mention here what I think ; the longevity record of a Spiny-cheeked Honey-eater which lived *om May, 1934, until December, 1956. With such a record, I would ot trust his safety with other birds, nor would I do so with a Hard- /icke's Green Bulbul received in October, 1936, and still in perfect lumage as was the Honey-eater.

By S. T. Johnstone (Slimbridge, Glos., England) In the ten years that we have had a collection at Slimbridge, 07 forms of wildfowl have nested, and of these 100 kinds have een reared. Whilst a number of species have been reared for the first ime in Europe, perhaps our greatest contribution to aviculture has een the re-establishment of the Hawaiian Goose ( Branta sandvicensis) om the three birds presented to us by Mr. Shipman in 1949. Fifty- ve birds have been reared, representing an estimated third of the world's population. Twelve have been reared by Mr. Terry Jones at .eckford, in whose care we placed a pair of birds some three years ago. iearing in mind the possible loss of the Slimbridge flock from epidemic auses we have established pairs at our Peakirk branch, at Cleres, nd with Mr. Schuyl at Rotterdam ; a pair has been returned to unerica under the care of Dr. Dillon Ripley. The Hawaiian Goose is robably the world's second rarest bird, and consequently the Trust ; very proud of its effort in the attempt to save this beautiful goose 'om extinction.

Ig6 S. T. JOHNSTONE NOTES FROM THE WILDFOWL TRUST 1957 has been far and away our most successful breeding season No doubt the improved breeding results were aided by the gloriouf weather of May, June, and early July, so that by the time the bad weather of August arrived the majority of the young birds were full) feathered and past danger. But we must record a new method of feeding the young birds. Alj were reared entirely on dry Turkey Starter crumbs, and certainly il would seem that this had a very beneficial effect, not only on the numbers reared, but also on the rate of growth. Over 750 birds have been reared, representing 75 per cent of those hatched. The figures are as follows :--
algorithms.figure: Cygnets and Kinds Kinds Goslings Ducklings breeding. reared. reared. reared. 9 1 72
algorithms.bodyText: Failure was recorded with the Bewick's Swan ( Cygnus columbiams bewickii), the first clutch of five eggs being spoilt when the sitting pen was disturbed by the many visitors who came to the New Grounds this summer. The second clutch of eggs were unfortunately infertile. A further disappointment was the loss of nine of the fourteen Ne-ne that hatched, owing to a heavy burden of tapeworm. On the other hand, the Magpie Geese ( Anseranas semipalmata) have been extremely successful : six birds have been reared by foster mothers and a further five by the parent birds. The Australian Grey Teal ( Anas gibberifrons mathewsi) has been reared for the first time, and two drakes and a duck have been added to the collection. The Ringed Teal ( Anas leucophrys ) did very well, and we have added thirty birds to the original stock. From our own point of view the most interesting species that we were successful with was the Smew ( Mergus albellus). We have had a wild-caught female and three males at Slimbridge for the past six years, and although in recent years the female showed signs of getting " heavy" it was not until 1957 that she nested. In a small barrel some 2 feet from the ground the first egg was found on 12th June, closely resembling that of Carolina [Aix sponsa ) in size, colour, and texture. Altogether five eggs were laid. A large amount of down was pulled after the third egg. The parent bird was allowed to sit on the eggs for the first ten days, and they were then removed and incubated under a bantam in the normal way. The incubation period lasted twenty-six days, and all five eggs hatched, the ducklings being extremely like young Golden-eye (. Bucephala clangula clangula), the downy pattern being identical. Two ducklings soon fell behind and died, but the remaining birds thrived. Their early diet was fresh- water shrimp with trout fry, the fry being increased in size as the birds grew. Turkey Starter crumbs were also given, and when the

)irds were feathered the trout were replaced by sections of live eel-- he diet that is given to the rest of the Sawbills in the collection. U1 three birds are now well established. At Peakirk, some nine miles north of Peterborough, we have laid >ut eleven acres of Waterfowl Gardens, and established a collection )f seventy-five species of swans, ducks, and geese. Here a promising tart has been made with breeding waterfowl, and 146 birds of fifteen pecies have been reared.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 1957 BREEDING RESULTS IN THE HALLSTROM COLLECTION
algorithms.bodyText: By Sir Edward Hallstrom (Sydney, N.S.W., Australia) Perhaps the most interesting experience I have had this year has jeen with the Golden-shouldered Parrakeet. The cross between the jolden-shouldered and the Hooded has proved to be fertile, and some oungsters from this cross are now fully matured. I have tried to ross the Golden-shouldered and the Many-coloured Parrakeet ; found that the older Golden-shouldered male would have nothing o do with the Many-coloured females. It then became necessary for ne to rear youngsters of both birds together and now, after several r ears of waiting, I have three pairs that I feel quite sure will take up Lousekeeping in a very short time, as the males are already driving he females. My stock of Golden-shouldered Parrakeets has increased o fifteen pairs plus a few extra, odd males. Young Golden-shouldereds >arely a year old have gone to nest, and have reared youngsters, fhe cross between the Hooded and the Many-coloureds apparently are nfertile. I have had at least a dozen pairs go to nest, without pro- lucing a single chick. Some of the interesting birds I bred last year were some Red and Hue Macaws, Red and Yellow Macaws, Blue and Yellow Macaws, t nd more Glossy Black Cockatoos. One Banksian Cockatoo was ompletely reared by hand from the day it was hatched. Its mother 00k no interest in the baby ; we undertook the job for her. There were four Red-bellied Gonures, four Cactus Conure crosses, is before, a great many African Lovebirds--Fischer's, Peach-faced, Tasked, and Nyasa. Five African Grey Parrots, with three more >abies in the nest at the moment, and three baby Cloncurry Parrots. ? or years I have wanted to breed the Cloncurry, but never seemed to be ible to get a female. At last I have three females, and to-day one pair ire sitting, a pair only a year old have gone to nest, and another nice )air have mated and are very interested in the nest-box.

Several years ago I sent out a very carefully planned expeditioi and procured some Blue-cheeked Rosellas ; two pairs, one of whicl are only twelve months old, are now sitting on eggs. I had never seei Blue-cheeked Rosellas before. They are not even mentioned ii Cayley's book, What Bird is That ?, but they were recorded by Gould 1 hope that within a week or two I will have established the firs! breeding record. A few days ago, on making a check through my nest-boxes, I fount; many young Eclectus Parrots, a number of eggs, and a great man' of the commoner Australian parrots. I have also two pairs of Yellow winged Conures. There are at the moment five pairs of Macaws sitting on eggs. I have another interesting youngster in the nest, about twelve day old at the moment--a Ribbon-tailed Bird of Paradise (Taenia paradise , mayeri ). This, of course, is the first to be bred in captivity, and I an glad that the credit goes to me. They are in an aviary with quiti heavy undergrowth. The female chose a very thick privet bush ii which to build. She was supplied with ample nesting material, anc built a nest quite 9 inches across, cup-shaped, the middle of the nes is no more than 2 inches deeper than the rim. It took quite a long time to understand the mating habits of these birds by actual observation. Mating usually takes place after ai attractive display by the male, and in the case of my birds, of whicl there are two more pairs sitting at the moment, was finally complete! on the ground whilst the birds were locked together by the feet ii such a manner that caused me to misunderstand the mating fo fighting, which perhaps delayed my success with this particular species After mating, the male takes no further interest in the female, th< nest or the youngster. Special food, a mixture of fruit and yolk 0 e ggj was supplied, with a small handful of mealworms. The mal( apparently has respected this food and left it entirely alone, eatim only the standard Bird of Paradise food that is provided in th< ordinary way. The aviary is about 30 feet long, 9 feet wide, and 7 feet high. Th< whole of the floor is concreted ; along either side of the aviary i. planted privet, and other shrubby plants, in beds 12 feet long. Thest were built up from the concrete some 18 inches, leaving plenty 0 soil for the privet. The rest of the aviary was covered with leaf whicl soon became mould ; the mould is allowed to build up to betweer 2 and 3 inches ; this becomes a wormery, as literally thousands 0 earthworms breed in this litter. It is necessary, of course, to keep i moist every day, for the worms to thrive. The female turns th( leaf over, and she is to be seen quite regularly pulling worms out o the leaf mould which she completely swallows and later regurgitate: as food for the baby. Around the roots of the privet I throw large

K. W. DALTON-BREEDING TIMNEH X AFRICAN GREY PARROTS 1 99 lumbers of termites daily, and also supply large white grubs, giving he parent a wide range of food from which to choose. The youngster when hatched was a shiny black, quite ugly. It s now twelve days old, and pin-feathers are beginning to become tpparent. When I found that this creature had been hatched, I got n touch with the Australian Museum, and in a few days, when it is afe to do so, Dr. Keast is being sent out to observe the baby, so hat the record of this breeding can be verified. The position in which the bird has the nest, in dense foliage, pre- cludes photographs from being taken for the time being. I would hate o disturb or frighten the mother and perhaps prevent the very nice ^xtra feather in my avicultural cap.
algorithms.equation: 1 I ^ BREEDING OF TIMNEH x AFRICAN
algorithms.bodyText: By K. W. Dalton (Hallow, Worcs, England) An African Grey Parrot hen and a Timneh cock which I purchased m the spring of 1956 laid four eggs on the floor of the shelter. They sat for about four weeks, but the eggs were not fertile. This year I stood a hollow log on the floor of the shelter and they soon went to nest, four eggs were laid and both birds stayed in the nest all the time except for feeding. About the 27th June young were first heard, three of the eggs hatched and for the first two weeks, due to the very hot weather, neither of the parents brooded in the day time, but both did at night. Two of the young had black beaks the other a white one. The next three weeks were very wet and both birds brooded night and day, the cock Timneh coming off now and again to get food which consisted of apple, hemp, and monkey nuts, and though sunflower seed was offered little was taken, but very large quantities of water were drunk. During the sixth week the young one with the white beak died. The following week the parents only brooded at night and the young started to get feathers on head and wings. Three weeks later, when the young were half-grown, another one died and I can only put this down to suffocation at night as both parents brooded at night. Food taken was as before but now more sunflower seed was eaten, the parents were still brooding at night and this continued until the surviving young one left the nest-box when 13 weeks old. It has a reddish brown tail like the Timneh cock.
200 D. M. WEST-BREEDING OF THE QUEEN OF BAVARIA'S CONURE
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING OF THE QUEEN OF BAVARIA'S CONURE
algorithms.table: (.Aratinga guarouba) By David M. West (Montebello, California, U.S.A.) This year I have had young Bourke's, Elegants, Turquoisines Barraband's, Pileated, Red-rumped, Crimson-wings, blue Ring-
algorithms.bodyText: necks, Stanley, Rosellas, hybrid Brown's X Yellow Rosella, anc Queen of Bavaria's Conure. Princess, lutino Ring-necks, yellow Red- rumps did not breed. The nesting of the Bavarias is the most amazing result for the paii are not perfect specimens. The male is a pinioned bird, and th( female has a flight impediment, and though she flies it is with some difficulty. Accordingly it is all the more surprising that on ist Jul> I found the female on three eggs. As the pair go in and out of theii nest and use it for a play-pen most of the time, I had not realizec that they were nesting. She had not been noticed spending any special amount of time in the nest. It was my impression, on ist July, that the three eggs were fresh. On 4th July it was 104 degrees in the garden, despite large, shady trees. Noting the female was off, and had been off almost continually during the day, I took a quick look-see. The initial impression was dismay, for broken egg-shells were in evidence. Then, as my eyes grew accustomed to the darkness in the interior of the box, two small bits of fluff and one egg could be seen. It had been my original impression that the broken egg-shells had indicated that they had used the eggs as toys, but what elation to find they had actually done the right thing and incubated them ! Despite an almost 100 per cent conviction on my part that the parents would refuse to feed, or murder the chicks, or the box would fall to the ground, or the weather would cook the chicks, the birds have continued to thrive. Since then the third egg has hatched, and the chick has grown apace, so that there is very little difference between the three in size. The weather has been the greatest worry. The summer has been the hottest in several summers, and since ist July there has not been a day with a temperature of less than 80 degrees, and several days with the temperature over the century mark. Still, the parents and chicks are doing well, so one should not worry, especially since it must be very warm in their native habitat. Both parents apparently feed the young and have from the first. The male spends the night in the nest, which is about 18 inches by 18 inches by 3 feet high. The box is hung under a shelter. The young are quite noisy and, while the parents are feeding, their calls can quite easily be heard at a distance of 50 feet.

D. M. WEST-BREEDING OF THE QUEEN OF BAVARIA'S CONURE 201 The female is the more aggressive bird, but does not appear to be oo upset when an inspection of the box is made. As the box is at eye 5V el, I do not have to touch the nest, but can look directly in and see he young. Inspections have been made each week, and on very hot lays when the temperature has been in the 90's or ioo's, an inspection 5 made daily for fear that one of the young might have died and the mell would cause the parents to quit the nest. Food : The parents are surprisingly unimaginative. They are very ond of fresh corn on the cob, and will eat at least three large ears of his a day. Formerly they were very fond of orange and apple, but at jresent they do not eat much of them. Grapes are flung to the ground n disgust, and ditto pine nuts. The only seed they eat in quantity s sunflower and a little oats. Canary and millet are almost totally gnored. Greens are not much appreciated. It is obvious that the nost important article in their diet while rearing young is the flesh :orn. It is surprising to me how often they go to the water bowl to Irink. Apparently they are a species that requires an inordinate imount of water while rearing young. At the age of some thirty-five days the young were just beginning to ihow pin-feathers in the wing and tail. Now, at the age of six weeks :hey are almost fully covered with feathers, and quite large in size. Still, it would be my guess that they will be at least another three weeks in the nest. While they were without feathers their body colour reminded one of the body colour of young lutino or albino parrakeets quite pinkish. This is not a first breeding for the U.S., but must be the second recorded breeding. Previously in California the Sun Conure went under the name of cc Golden " Conure, and for this reason seveial people have, erroneously, been given credit for breeding the Queen of Bavaria's Conure. Some gentleman in Louisiana has bred the Queen of Bavaria's Conure and has reared three, although I believe he helped the parents and hand-fed the youngsters from time to time, although this fact certainly should not detract from his accomplishment. It is my understanding that the adult pair and one of their youngsters have been purchased by Mr. Rudkin, Junr., and are in his collection at Fillmore. I believe that the youngsters will emerge from the nest with their plumage streaked with green. Mr. H. Zelenko, of New York City, has told the writer that a Bavaria in his possession laid eggs while still in immature (streaked green) plumage. Does this indicate they mature early, for somewhere it seems to me I've read that mature plumage is assumed at the end of the first year ? This has been the case with the young bird reared in Louisiana, for it was in full adult (clear yellow) plumage by the end of fifteen or sixteen months.

202 D. M. WEST-BREEDING OF THE QUEEN OF BAVARIA'S CONURE Postscript: At the end of the tenth week the youngsters left the nest. The youngest of the three birds left the nest too early, and daily would end up on the ground. This necessitated my replacing him in the nest every evening, and the following day the process would be repeated. This discouraging situation finally resulted in the removal of this bird from the aviary, and hand-feeding " him I believe this bird to be a male, as it is very brightly coloured. The remaining two youngsters were replaced each night in the nest-box for the first week after they came out. After the first week, however, they have been able to find their way back to the nest each night by themselves, and at the present time the parents and the two youngsters all sleep in the box together and without any fighting. The young began to eat by themselves about the third day after leaving the nest. The parents take very good care of them, and constantly hover about the youngsters, even at this late date. (23rd October, 1957.) The youngsters are quite reluctant fliers, and prefer to crawl about rather than fly, though when forced into it they fly very well. The parents are now back again mating regularly, and appear somewhat interested in the nest-box. However, the colder weather is coming upon us, and I doubt that their present interest will be long-lived. It should be added that the two youngsters living with their parents have the same terrible galaxy of cries and yells that their parents have. The four birds greet each new dawn with a full assortment of terrible shrieks and cries . . . about the only drawback to this wonderfully coloured bird.
algorithms.construct: J. J. YEALLAND-LONDON ZOO NOTES 203
algorithms.bodyText: B y J- J- Yealland The fourth of the B.B.C. Television Service's " Zoo Quest " expedi- ons set out in June, this time for the Central Highlands of New luinea where David Attenborough and Charles Lagus stayed at Jondugl as guests of Sir Edward Hallstrom, filming the animal fe of the Wahgi and Jimi Valleys and later visiting the Bismarck /fountains. Sir Edward's fauna station at Nondugl is, as members now, in the care of Mr. F. Shaw Mayer, who, it will be remembered, irought a number of rare and beautiful Papuan birds to London iefore the war. The collection brought to the Zoo by David Atten- *orough in October called to mind those far-off days, for it contained hirteen Birds of Paradise, the largest number to be exhibited here ince about 1940. These came from the large aviaries at Nondugl as , present from Sir Edward, the complete list (those new to the Collec- ion marked with an asterisk) of his gift being : --
algorithms.table: * 1 Sickle-billed Bird of Paradise ( Epimachus meyeri bloodi ) ; * 2 hincess Stephanie's (Astrapia stephaniae ducalis ) ; * 1 Salvadori's Paradisaea apoda salvadorii) ; *1 Finsch's (P. minor Jinschi) ; *2 Blue >r Prince Rudolph's (P. rudolphi margaritae) ; * 1 King (Cicinnurus egius similis ) ; *2 Golden-winged Magnificent (Diphyllodes magnificus hrysopterus ) ; * 1 Hallstrom's (Pteridophora alberti hallstromi) ; * 1 Black ind Gold (Cnemophilus macgregori sanguineus) ; 1 Lesser Superb Lophorhina superba minor ) ; * 1 Stone's Cat-Bird (Ailuroedus buccoides tonii ) ; *2 Yellow-breasted Bower-Birds (Chlamydera lauterbachi) ; '4 Blue-faced Lorikeets (Trichoglossus haematod intermedius) ; 1 Red- ided Eclectus Parrot ( Lorius roratus pectoralis ). Those collected by Attenborough and Lagus, and presented by the hB.C. Television Service :-- *2 Fig Parrots ( Opopsitta diophthalma coccineifrons ) ; *1 Plicated iornbill ( Rhyticeros plicatus jungei ).
algorithms.bodyText: It will be noticed that the common names used for some of these )irds are adaptations of the specific or sub-specific name, as the case nay be. The reason for this is that these particular races appear to lave no separate common name. Some of the Birds of Paradise are still in the immature plumage. The Superb is the one described by Iredale as L. superba addenda ; [ am not sure if this is an accepted name, but if so, the sub-specific lame minor given above can be corrected later. A great deal should be written about this magnificent collection, md it is hoped, if all goes well, to publish more detailed notes with photographs, though, as we all know, only coloured plates can do ustice to Birds of Paradise. Since the birds were not permitted to enter Australia, David

J. J. YEALLAND-LONDON ZOO NOTES Attenborough had to take the collection (which, of course, alsc included some mammals and reptiles) to Rabaul, by sea to Hong Kong where he stayed with Dr. Searle, and thence by air to London On the same plane came a pair of Chinese Starlings presented b\ Dr. Searle and a Javan Brahminy Kite and a Siberian Ground Thrush given by Mr. G. H. Newmark. A Tengmalm's Owl that flew on board one of the ships taking pari in the N.A.T.O. exercises off the Lofoten Islands has been presented : also a Duck Hawk or North American Peregrine (.Falco peregrinm anatum) which flew on to a grain ship off Baffin Island. The Duck Hawk is the first to be received here. A Red-fronted Woodpecker was sent as a present from Mrs. D. Seggar, who has previously giver various birds collected in British Guiana, and a Bronzy Sunbird has been received in exchange. Cormorants that nested on the imitation cliff in the Southern Aviary and reared two young earlier in the year have now re-made their nests in the trees, using the old materials. Editor's Note .--With regard to the " common names " given to the Birds of Paradise in the above Notes, it is difficult to understand why it is considered necessary to do this. It should be emphasized that these so-called " common names " applied to rare exotic species, which are most unlikely ever to become common birds, have no real significance. For many years the Zoological Society of London, as in the present instance, seems to have invented " common names " by translating the specific or sub-specific name into the nearest English equivalent. This practice has never been followed in horticulture where the internationally accepted Latin name is retained for all rare species, and there would seem to be no real reason for departing from this generally accepted procedure. In addition the translation of such " common names " into other languages is liable to lead to confusion which could never arise if the correct nomenclature had been maintained.
algorithms.figure: I COUNCIL MEETING 205 COUNCIL MEETING If A Council Meeting was held on nth November, 1957, in the Council Room, Zoological Society of London. * * * Officers for 1958
algorithms.bodyText: There were the following retirements and appointments :-- Council : Mr. Gerald lies resigned on taking up residence in Canada, and Mr. Sydney Porter and Mr. R. C. J. Sawyer retired by station. Dr. E. Hindle, Dr. F. B. Lake, and Mr. K. A. Norris were elected to fill the vacancies.
Mr. Allen Silver was elected a Vice-President of the Society. Mr. W. J. C. Frost was elected an Hon. Life Member.

The Society's Medal was awarded to :-- Mr. E. J. Boosey, for breeding the Senegal Parrot (Poicephalus senegalus). Mr. E. J. Boosey, for breeding the Greater Hill Mynah (Eulabes religiosa). Mr. A. A. Prestwich, for breeding the Green Imperial Fruit Pigeon (.Ducula aenea ). Arthur A. Prestwich, Hon. Secretary. Exchange and Mart Scheme Members often have odd birds for which they are unable to obtain a mate. In order to facilitate the exchange of such birds the Council have decided to inaugurate this scheme. Any member who wishes to take advantage of the scheme should send to Mr. C. M. Payne a postal order for 5i., and particulars of the bird required or for disposal. If Mr. Payne has a record of such a bird from another member he will advise both members, who will then be in a position to communicate with each other. It is not the intention that the Society should take any part in the negotiations. The payment of 5L will entitle the member to the benefits of the scheme until the 31st December, 1958. Mr. Payne's address is : The Malt House, Barford, Warwickshire.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BRITISH AVICULTURISTS ? CLUB BRITISH AVICULTURISTS 5 CLUB
algorithms.bodyText: The fifty-ninth meeting of the Club was held at the Rembrandi Hotel, Thurloe Place, South Kensington, S.W. 7, on Monday, nth November, 1957, following a dinner at 7 p.m.
algorithms.reference: Chairman : Dr. E. Hindle. Members of the Club : Miss P. Barclay-Smith, Miss J. Barnes. P. C. Bath, Hylton Blythe, A. W. Bolton, Miss K. Bonner, K. F. Clarke, Major C. N. Clayden, W. D. Cummings, Mrs. R. E. Darnton, Sir Godfrey Davis, M. F. Draper, B. H. Dulanty, Sqd.-Ldr. C. Everitt' Mrs. C. Everitt, Miss R. M. Ezra, Miss E. G. Ganner, J. C. Garratt, Dr. E. F. Gleadow, F. Grant, Miss M. Hagan, H. J. Harman, R. E. Heath, L. W. Hill, Miss S. I. Hobday, F. E. B. Johnson, Miss S. R. Joseph, Miss E. M. Knobel, Miss M. H. Knobel-Harman, Dr. F. B. Lake, A. J. Lambert, A. L. Leighton, P. H. Maxwell, F. Mosford, G. S. Mottershead, S. Murray, Sir Crawford McCullagh, Bart., K. A. Norris, W. R. Partridge, C. M. Payne, A. A. Prestwich, J. H. Reay, D. M. Reid-Henry, S. Sanderson, R. C. J. Sawyer, J. L. Sears, D. Seth-Smith, A. G. Soanes, T. Spence, E. O. Squire, N. R. Steel, P. Sutton, J. A. Swan, Mrs. J. A. Swan, J. Thorpe, E. N. T. Vane, Mrs. G. Wheatley, H. Wilmot, W. A. Wingate, J. J. Yealland, D. Young.
algorithms.bodyText: Members of the Club, 62 ; guests, 54 ; total, 116. Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Darnton were unable to show " Birds, Beasts, and Butterflies of Equatorial Africa " as notified to members, because this film has not yet been completed. Instead, they showed " Tobago and nesting Flamingos in the Caribbean ". Mrs. Darnton has provided the following summary :-- " We spent last winter in Trinidad, Tobago, and Bonaire, and our film opens with various scenes taken round the lovely coast of Tobago and of the even more lovely hills and valleys of the island itself. When we were there, these valleys and hillsides were aflame with the spectacular flowers of the Erythrinas grown for shading the cocoa, and from many of these trees hung the long, pendulous nests of the Crested Hang-nest (Ostinops decumanus ) whose activities we filmed. " We also found a Hairy Hermit Humming Bird (Glaucis hirsuta insularum) attaching her nest with cobwebs to the tip of a hanging palm frond--a difficult subject for the camera, as the nest was only lit for ten minutes or so in the early morning. Unfortunately this lack of good lighting formed a problem throughout Trinidad and Tobago, as many of the most beautiful birds of these islands, such as the Red- capped Manakins, the Mot-mots, the Jacamars, and the Trogans, are birds of the shadows, and so are impossible to photograph satis- factorily. " However, when we went to Bonaire this problem did not arise,

)r instead of dense, tropical vegetation and tall forests, we found omparatively desert-like conditions--only trees and plants resistant a a very low rainfall being able to survive. Here in this tiny island re were fortunate in finding a colony of the Rosy Flamingo ( Phoeni - ipterus ruber) actually nesting. This was extremely lucky for normally biey do not nest until May, and we were there in early March. In act we found several thousands of young birds of various ages already unning about in great, grey flocks, while some of the adults were still itting on eggs. This species of flamingo is undoubtedly the most leautiful, and is said to be also the rarest. We were so entranced by heir beauty that we used to get up at 5 a.m. every morning so as to >e at their feeding grounds just after dawn. To live almost among hese lovely birds as we did for a fortnight, we felt was indeed a Privilege we shall never forget." The Chairman said he had seen numerous films of flamingos, ut never one to equal the present. Judging by the applause, this pinion was obviously shared by the large audience. These are eally worthwhile films, and Mr. and Mrs. Darnton are to be heartily ongratulated on the results of their recent visit to the West Indies.

The annual subscription (5^.) will be due very shortly. Will riembers please note that, with a view to saving the unnecessary xpense of postages, receipts will not be sent unless specially requested. The next meeting of the Club is on Monday, 13th January, 1958. Arthur A. Prestwich, Hon. Secretary.
Colonel H. B. Finch has bred a hybrid of hitherto unrecorded >arentage, Nutmeg or Spice Finch X Magpie Mannikin.

The Whooping Crane is very close to extinction : only twenty-three re known to remain in the wild, with three in captivity. Both in 955 and 1956 the pair in the Audubon Park Zoo, New Orleans, aid eggs and hatched young, but they soon died. This year the pair Las again hatched young--this time it is to be hoped with better uccess.
algorithms.reference: S. A. Croucher, Head Keeper, Parrot House, Zoological Gardens, legent's Park, retired on 15th October, after forty years in the service >f the Zoological Society of London. Many members are greatly
algorithms.bodyText: indebted to " Sid ", as he is familarly known, for help and advic< during many years, and all will wish him well in his retirement Croucher has been succeeded by Fred Shambrook.

Comte Leon Lippens reports a hitherto unrecorded cross, Rim Ouzel (Turdus torquatus ) x Mistle Thrush (T. viscivorus). In an avian at the bird reserve " Le Zwin ", at Knokke-Le Zoute, Belgium, z Ring Ouzel paired with a Mistle Thrush. They had four eggs two young were hatched, one of which thrives and is now over threi months' old. It is described as looking rather like a very dark Mistk Thrush.

Dr. Sten Bergman writes from Sorong, Dutch New Guinea " I have excavated earth mounds of the Megapodes, where they la\ their eggs. I have succeeded in hatching two eggs in a cupboard heated by a lamp burning day and night. I have thus had ar opportunity of observing the very interesting and curious hatching The chick kicks itself out of the egg and is able to fly as soon as it i: dry. At present I have two chicks nearly two weeks old."

A. Decoux, Aixe-sur-Vienne, France, reports : " I think the present breeding season is the worst I ever saw. The young parrakeet* and finches died in the nests in May. The weather was wet and cold we had very severe frosts in April and May. I have successfully bred the following doves and pigeons : Wong# Wonga, Common and Crested Bronze-winged, Peruvian, Talpacoti Diamond, Peaceful, Senegal, Bleeding-heart, and several others 1 Cuban Finches, Green Cardinals, Red-crested Finches, a few Aus- tralian Grassfinches ; many young died after leaving the nest or account of the cold and rainy summer."

K. A. Norris sends further news of his birds : " The young Blue Robins are almost through their first moult. There are five splendid young cocks, bringing the stock of this species up to pairs ! The young Red-winged Blackbirds are also doing very well and one young cock is already learning to display its scarlet shoulder tufts. Zosterops had a magnificient little nest, entirely of plant fibres, but. unfortunately, the two eggs appear to be infertile. The swarms oi fruit and other flies which we " created " in anticipation of the arrival of young Zosterops have greatly delighted the Tree Frogs, and their response might lead one to think that I have the B.B.C. Male Voice Choir in the birdroom."

On the last day of August, W. J. C. Frost arrived back in England P. & O. cargo-liner Shillong --on the following, outward voyage, is ship sank after a collision in the Red Sea--with the results of his ty-third collecting expedition. Amongst the birds brought home were Greater and King Birds of
algorithms.table: aradise ; Great Indian, Wreathed, Plicated, and Malayan Pied ornbills ; White-fronted Bronze-winged, Nicobar, Partridge, and leeding-heart Pigeons ; Bronze-tailed Peacock and Bornean Crested ireback Pheasants ; Blue-tailed and Blue-winged Pittas ; Fairy tuebirds ; Rothschild's and Black-necked Grackles ; Fire-tufted arbets ; Rose Finches ; Mitchell's Lorikeets, etc. Wilfred Frost, dw aged 82, left in the middle of November on yet another ipedition to Borneo. * * * Breeding reports : Dr. S. B. Kendall, Citron-crested Cockatoos
algorithms.bodyText: ared two exceedingly good young ; Greater Sulphur-crested cubated a single egg for about 28 days, after which it disappeared. Gaither Langberg, Copenhagen, 2 Grey Parrots, 11 Splendids, and lutino Nyasa Lovebirds. H. Murray, 2 Barraband's Parrakeets, ale and female, bred from recently imported birds ; 19 Cockatiels, Bourke's, 1 Guiana Parrotlet, 6 Green Cardinals, and a number of yasa Lovebirds. W. H. Rose, Blue-fronted Amazon, 1 young one ist over three weeks old ; Yellow-backed Lories hatched 1 young le which lived about seven days ; they failed to hatch the single egg l their second nest. Dr. K. G. Rothwell, 4 Elegants, 7 Bourke's, Golden-Mantled Rosellas, 4 Stanleys, Diamond Doves, and Chinese ainted Quail.

Leo A. Ara, Calcutta, records the following breedings : " Indian ing-necked Parrakeets, March, 1954, one ; April, 1957, one. From second pair, the male being a yellowish bird (not a lutino) and the male normal, April, 1957, two--both green in colour. The yellowish ale's colour does not remain constant as it has in turn been yellow, ale green, and yellow-green. Quaker Parrakeets, July, 1955, two ; 'ctober, 1955, one ; August, 1956, two ; January, 1957, one. I now ave a dozen. Golden-headed Conures, November, 1956, three ; ebruary, 1957, three. At present they have young in the nest, do not know how many but I have seen a young one, not fully athered, at the entrance to the nest. They are really lovely birds ad all live together in the same aviary."

C. af Enehjelm, Director, Helsingfors Zoo, writes : "I have not ad a very successful breeding season, mainly due to a long absence, have, however, bred 5 Three-coloured Parrot Finches, 20 Long- iled Grassfinches, 7 Bicheno's Finches, and some others. I have bred
algorithms.sectionHeader: REVIEWS 6 Green-rumped Parrotlets. These are the first for some time--I ha
algorithms.bodyText: so many I have not allowed them to breed for the past two or thre years. Last year's disappointment with the Red-headed Buntings (i icterica) was repeated. Three young ones were hatched but they wer fed for only a couple of days. The Indian Zosterops commence incubating three eggs, but these disappeared. The same thin happened with four nests of Peters' Spotted Waxbills. Amongst m new arrivals are three pairs of Dufresne's Waxbills from Keston, als pairs of Melba and Crimson Finches. I now have two yellow and on " white " Masked Lovebirds--the last is very ugly."

When the Society was founded in 1894 the annual subscription wa fixed at 5^. Four years later, in 1898, it was raised to ys. 6 d., and i 1900 to ioj. And so it remained until 1918 when it was increased to f\ It has now stood at this figure for 40 years ! The Avicultural Society is the only society of similar standing tha has not increased its subscription during the recent, semi-inflationar years. But if the very high standard of the Magazine is to be mair tained without an increase in the annual subscription the Society income must be increased. This may best be done by the member themselves. They must make every possible effort to propose ne^ members. No amount of energy on the part of the Officers can mak up for apathy in this respect. And please remember that donations t the Coloured Plate Fund are always very welcome ! A. A. P.

ORNAMENTAL WATERFOWL. By Lieut.-Col. A. A. Johnso and W. H. Payn. H. F. and G. Witherby, Ltd., London, 1957 Price 21s. net. Though wildfowl are very popular and a large number of book have been published, especially in recent years, on this group of birds there have been comparatively few on keeping them in captivity Rose Hubbard was the first to produce such a book, entitled Ornamentc Waterfowl , which was published in 1888, with a second edition ii 1907. After an interval of a quarter of a century A. F. Moody's boo, on Waterfowl and Game Birds in Captivity appeared in 1932, and this wa followed in 1933 by J. C. Laidley's comprehensive work on The Car and Propagation of Ornamental Waterfowl. Unfortunately all these book have been out of print for some time and are most difficult to obtain so that those who wish to start a collection of waterfowl have been a a great disadvantage. The appearance of the book under review i therefore particularly welcome and the authors have dealt with thei

ibject in a straightforward and simple manner which will be of articular use to those wishing to make a beginning in this scinating branch of aviculture. The first chapter is on starting a Election and contains a list of some of the more attractive and less cpensive ducks which are particularly suitable for beginners. The cond deals with fencing, planting, and pond construction, and the Dok continues with chapters on general management of the collection, ssts and eggs, hatching and rearing, plumage and moults, and ail- ients and diseases. Then follow descriptions of some native and exotic ucks and the geese and swans. The necessity of making sure, by actual observation, that the ucklings are eating is pointed out, but the authors do not give in- .rmation, as does Mr. Laidley, on methods of ensuring that the young irds do take food. Emphasis is laid on the importance of winning the complete con- dence of ducks and geese from the start and the great value of always dking to the birds when feeding or walking among them. That the athors carry out what they preach is shown by the instance quoted ' a wild White-fronted Goose belonging to one of them which ate read from the hand within six weeks of being captured, and which ow likes to travel about sitting in the front seat of a motor-car. The fact that each time there has been a special Waterfowl number if the Magazine the issue has sold out is evidence of the great interest lere is in this group of birds and this latest book should therefore be i great demand. As the authors state : " There is, in fact, no reason : all that anyone who is interested in waterfowl should not keep at ast a pair or two even if they have only the smallest of gardens or othing more than a backyard." P. B-S.
algorithms.sectionHeader: RCTIC BIRDS OF CANADA. By L. L. Snyder. University Press,
algorithms.bodyText: Toronto ; Oxford University Press, London, 1957. Price 38^. net. Though as the author, who is Curator of the Department of rnithology in the Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, states in the troduction, the scope of this book is approximately indicated by its tie, it has been necessary to establish a rather precise boundary ong the southern perimeter to serve as a threshold in determining hat forms to include or exclude. Accordingly the boundary has ien established as a line running along the treeless coasts of Yukon rritory and Mackenzie District east to Bathurst inlet and thence uth-eastward to Eskimo Point on Hudson Bay, across that Bay to artland Promontory on the east coast ; thence eastward to Ungava ay and along its treeless coast to Cape Chidley. All species known to :cur, or which have occurred north of this line are included.

In describing the nature of Arctic birds the author points out tha it is not correct to assume that they are exceptionally hardy. He state that among the more relentless factors enforcing adjustment amoni Arctic birds is time, especially for migrants, and there is an urgenc 1 in courtship, laying, incubation, and growth of young. He als< points out that the Arctic is stern and insistent, discouraging th< development of frills and non-essentials such as crests, wattles, spangles and complicated rituals, and Arctic birds are plain and unembellished In describing the nature of Arctic bird populations he states tha the best established generality is that they are notoriously unstabL as to numbers and much of the instability is attributable to weather The Arctic has been virtually unavailable to birds of arboreal habi and nearly half belong to one Order the Charadriiformes. Attention is drawn to the fact that the knowledge of Arctic bird is very meagre and a number of points requiring detailed study an outlined. A key to the Orders of Canadian Arctic birds is given followed by a section on habitat as an aid to identification. The mail part of the book is devoted to accounts of seventy-two species of tei different Orders, which include status, habitat, and characteristics with map. Additional names have been selected from the literatun to include those which may be in use locally in the North, and Eskimt names for particular regions are given. In many cases there an excellent pen and ink drawings by T. M. Shortt.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BIRDS OF BRITAIN CALENDAR FOR 1958. Country Life, Ltd.
algorithms.bodyText: London. Price 6^. This calendar with a photograph of a different species for eacl month of the year by Eric Hosking is well up to the high standard 0 its predecessors. A short description of each bird is also given. P. B-S. sj: jJs sic
algorithms.subsectionHeader: Breeding and Rearing Successes at Barford, Warwickshire, 1957.
algorithms.bodyText: The following birds have been bred this year : Derbyans, 3 youngsters full; reared ; Princess of Wales, 4 youngsters fully reared ; Barrabands, 3 youngster fully reared ; Cockatiels, 7 youngsters fully reared ; Peach-faced Lovebirds, ' youngsters fully reared ; Elegant Parrakeets, 1 youngster fully reared. Fischer' Lovebirds, a quantity, not less than 25 fully reared ; so-called yellow Masked Love birds, 2 youngsters fully reared ; split-lutino Indian Ring-necked cock paired to < normal hen--had 2 youngsters, both green ; Chinese Painted Quail, 2 youngster fully reared. In addition to these I have reared a number of Pheasants and Peafowl. Rocl Pebblers had 4 youngsters which were lost after they left the nest ; Yellow-backec Lories, Many-coloured Parrakeets, Leadbeater's Cockatoos, Splendid Parrakeets and Bourke's Parrakeets had eggs which proved infertile. Towhees, 3 youngsters which they subsequently lost in the cold weather.

I think this may be the first time that yellow Masked Lovebirds have been bred l this country. There is perhaps some doubt as to whether they are in fact pure tasked Lovebirds. John Yealland, when he saw mine, expressed the view that ley had Peach-faced Lovebird blood in them. However, contrary to the expressed pinions of more knowledgeable aviculturists, I still think that they are a delightful lutation, and I see no reason why in time by careful selection they should not be red completely yellow with the very attractive bronze face. I have seen a con- derable number of this mutation, and they vary in the intensity and clarity of ie colour considerably. The pair which I have bred this year are very attractive. A newly-imported pair of Turquoisines are at the moment sitting on five eggs. C. M. Payne.

My pair of Pileated Jays fortunately went to nest in mid-July, 1956, in a small nary 12 feet by 4 feet, the shelter being 4 feet by 4 feet. As they seemed to be playing around with nesting material and stripping the irious growing plants and creepers in their aviary, I put an old Magpie nest in the lelter, never thinking that they would breed, but with the object of giving the plants chance by diverting their attention. Great was my surprise two days after placing ie nest to find an egg, not unlike that of our Magpie, in it. Two more eggs followed in ie course of the next four days. The hen seemed to do all the sitting. In fact I never w her off the nest, and the cock fed her. On the sixteenth day one youngster was itched. When I looked about four days later the three eggs had hatched. Both rds appear model parents, but the cock did all the feeding. On collecting meal- orms or maggots he would first feed the hen. She would then raise herself and the >ck would feed one of the youngsters ; he would repeat this until all were fed. icidentally, I was not standing in the aviary shelter while this was taking place ; teir aviary was one of a range, and I could observe this from a small passage dividing ieir shelter from the next. As at this time we were very busy on the land, I had not the time to collect beetles, \0x25A0asshoppers, etc., of which they are very fond, so they had to make do on soft food id fruit, with mealworms and maggots as the only live food. I think perhaps this is ie cause of the failure to rear them. On the seventh day I found one of the babies icked away in a bush in the flight. A couple of days later the second one was placed the same spot. The last one was still alive and apparently lusty on the sixteenth ly, but as I could hear no feeding noises on the eighteenth, I flushed the hen. This, ie last hope, was dead, although there was food in its crop. Never having seen a )ung Jay before, I couldn't really say, but my impression was that it was on the inny side. The pair are nesting again now, so perhaps they will have better luck lis time. They certainly deserve it, as both proved such good parents. As I have id before, the only conclusion I can come to is that perhaps the cause of failure was mething lacking in their diet. However, we will see what happens this time. P. G. Paris. reeding Results at San Marino, 1957 Members may be interested to hear how some of my birds did this year. This ason, after an unsuccessful attempt last year, I was able to rear one Black-chinned uhina. Two young were hatched but one died. The survivor has been removed om the " glasshouse aviary " to avoid the possibility of its being killed by the irents. An interesting attempt was made by a Mountain Tanager male and a ed-eared Tanager female. They built a nest in a spruce tree but as far as I know ) eggs were laid. As I am now out of the navy and will be back in Los Angeles ixt year I am planning to remove these two Tanagers and give them a planted nary to themselves. A hybrid from them should be a truly magnificient bird, also reared five young Grey-headed X Brahminy Mynahs. I would like to state at the Grey-headed X Pagoda Mynahs referred to in my article (page 47) were, fact, the present cross. Brahminy Mynahs are often advertised as Pagoda Mynahs, mce the confusion, but they are not the same. J. R. VAN OOSTEN. l6*
algorithms.sectionHeader: CORRESPONDENCE \ CORRESPONDENCE THE DRINKING HABITS OF DUCULA SPECIES
algorithms.bodyText: I have seen the Green drink in the wild state, and had both Pied and Green drink in captivity. I have not seen them drink whilst standing on the ground with open feet. Like all the fruit pigeons they do not care for walking. The ones I had in captivity drank ofl perches, the water being placed within reach. Birds in aviaries had overhanging branches. They sidled down the branch until they could reach the water. The common Bengal Green I have seen settling in huge numbers on the lower branches of a peepul tree ( Ficus religiosa ) until the branch touched water. Other fruit pigeons more normally settle on dead branches sticking out of the water. The Green Imperial are, of course, tree-top dwellers and very rarely come down to the ground. I should think they would get plenty of water, high up, which had been caught in broken branches. If my memory does not fail me these pigeons drank at dawn and dusk. I succeeded in breeding the Green while in Calcutta. Stuart Baker mentions that some natives believe the Green Pigeon only comes down to drink where no perches are available, if it has a branch clasped in its feet. I have been told this by villagers in Bengal.
algorithms.table: Herbert Fooks. Grizedale Lodge, Hawkshead, Nr. Ambleside, Westmorland.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING OF CRIMSON FINCHES (. NEOCHMIA PHAETON)
algorithms.bodyText: This summer we were fortunate in breeding three young Crimson (Blood) Finches {Neochmia phaeton). The parents nested in a covered flight, producing five eggs, the first about the 19th July. The young were hatched on 5th August, and three left the nest on the 25th and 26th August. A fourth was found dead at a very early age, and one egg was broken. We separated the young from their parents on the 12 th September, as the first egg of a second round was laid on that day, and the young were being prevented from returning to the nest, which was usual until then. The three young are very fit indeed at time of writing (25th September), are medium brown in colour, slight crimson diffusion over back and wings, crimson tail, underside brown, flight-feathers dark brown, belly and thighs light brown, beak black. The birds were very insectivorous, being fed gentles, once or twice ant eggs, and some mealworms, with plenty of chickweed and home-made sponge cake. Ideal parents, with the cock doing most of the incubation and much of the feeding. L. Scamell.

Newdigate, Surrey. A DIRECTORY OF BIRD RINGING A world-wide directory of bird ringing is proposed to be published by The Ring, an international ornithological bulletin devoted entirely to bird ringing and bird migration studies. The avicultural rings will be included in this directory besides the rings of ornithological schemes, carrier pigeon associations, etc. I should be most grateful if readers of the Avicultural Magazine could assist us by sending information and addresses--home and abroad--of all possible, even the smallest institutions, organizations, clubs, businesses, and individuals issuing their own rings for cage-birds. Samples of rings are essential, and would be greatly appreciated. All communications and information should be sent to The Ring, 1 Altyre Road.
algorithms.reference: Croydon, Surrey, England. Dr. W. Rydzewski, Editor.

algorithms.bodyText: The charge for Members' advertisements is one penny per word. Payment must accompany the advertisement , which must be sent on or before the 15th of the month to A. A. Prestwich, 61 Chase Road, Oakwood, N. 14. All members of the Society are entitled to use this column , but the Council reserves the right to refuse any advertisements they consider unsuitable.

Pair Black Swans.--P. C. Bath, Park Farm, Roxton, Bedfordshire. Birds of all descriptions from all over the world. Will trappers, exporters, etc. please contact.--J. W. Taylor, Arundel Aviaries and Fisheries, 211-213 Arunde Street, Landport, Portsmouth, Hants, England.
algorithms.figure: FOR SALE Carolinas, ducks or drakes, beautiful specimens, 50*. each.--Mrs. E. Wicks, Silver Springs, Beaufort Road, St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Two excellent aviaries, under a year old ; one double, 19 feet long, built by Stonors, the other a carpenter-built sectional.--Full particulars from Mrs. Grace Wheatley, 57 Cadogan Place, London, S.W. 1. WATERFOWL RINGS Members are reminded that the Society's special blue rings are always available. All Waterfowl in collections, both public and private, should carry them. Revised prices Price per dozen , post free. Size. 2-3 Teal 3 Wigeon . 4 Mallard, Pintail, etc. 4-5 Smaller geese 5 Greylag . s. d. 4 o 4 9 5 6 6 3 7 o Requests for rings should be addressed to the Hon. Secretary, Avicultural Society, c/o Zoological Society of London, Regent's Park, London, N.W. 1, from whom all particulars can be obtained. STEPHEN AUSTIN AND SONS, LTD., PRINTERS, HERTFORD.

algorithms.bodyText: Rules of the Avicultural Society Last amended, gth November, iggg.
algorithms.listItem: 1. --The name of the Society shall be The Avicultural Society, and its object shall be the study of British and foreign birds in freedom and in captivity. Poultry, Pigeons, and Canaries shall be outside the scope of the Society. The year of the Society, with that of each volume of the Society's Magazine, which shall be known as the Avicultural Magazine, shall commence with the month of January and end on the 31st December following. 2. --The Avicultural Society shall consist of Ordinary, Life, Honorary Life Members, and Honorary Fellows, and the last shall be restricted in number to ten, and be elected by the Council. 3. --The Officers of the Society shall be elected, annually if necessary, by Members of the Council in the manner hereinafter provided, and shall consist of a President, one or more Vice-Presidents, a Secretary-Treasurer, an Assistant
algorithms.bodyText: Secretary, an Editor, and a Council of fifteen Members. The President, Vice- Presidents, Secretary-Treasurer, Assistant Secretary, and Editor shall be ex officio Members of the Council. 4---New Members shall be proposed in writing, and the name and address of every person thus proposed, with the name of the Member proposing him shall be published in the next issue of the Magazine. Unless the candidate shall within two weeks after the publication of his name in the Magazine, be objected to by at least two Members, he shall be deemed to be duly elected. If five Members shall lodge with the Secretary objections to any candidate he shall not be elected, but the signatures to the signed objections must be verified by the Scrutineer. If two or more Members shall object to any candidate the name of such candidate shall be brought before the Council at their next meeting, and the Council shall have power to elect or to disqualify him from election. 5*--Each Member shall pay an annual subscription of#i, to be due and payable in advance on the 1st of January in each year ; and, on payment of the subscription shall be entitled to receive all the numbers of the Society's Magazine for the current year. Life Member's fee, #15. 6.--Members intending to resign their membership at the end of the current year of the Society are expected to give notice to the Secretary before the 1 st of December, so that their names may not be included in the " List of Members ", which shall be published annually in the January number of the Magazine.

7*--The Magazine of the Society shall be issued on or about the first day of every month, and forwarded, post free, to all the Members who shall have paid their subscriptions for the year ; but no Magazine shall be sent or delivered to any Member until the annual subscription shall have reached the hands of the Secretary-Treasurer. Members whose subscriptions shall not have been paid as above by the first day in November in any year shall cease to be Members of the Society, but may be readmitted, at the discretion of the Council, on payment of the annual subscription. 8.--The President, Secretary-Treasurer, Assistant Secretary, and Editor shall be elected for a term of five years, and, should a vacancy occur, it may be temporarily filled by the Executive Committee (see Rule io). At the expiration of the term of five years in every case it shall be competent for the Council to nominate the same officer, or another Member, for a further term of five years, unless a second candidate be proposed by not less than twenty-five Members of at least two years' standing, as set forth below. In the November number of the Magazine preceding the retirement from office of the President, Secretary-Treasurer, Assistant Secretary, and Editor, the Council shall publish the names of those members whom they have nominated to fill the vacancies thus created ; and these Members shall be deemed duly elected unless another candidate or candidates be proposed by not less than fifteen Members of at least two years' standing. Such proposal, duly seconded and containing the written consent of the nominee to serve, if elected, in the capacity for which he is proposed, must reach the Secretary on or before the 15th of November. g.--The Members of the Council shall retire by rotation, three at the end of each year of the Society (unless a vacancy or vacancies shall occur otherwise) and three other Members of the Society shall be recommended by the Council to take the place of those retiring. The names of the three Members recommended shall be printed in the November number of the Avicultural Magazine. Should the Council's selection be objected to by fifteen or more Members, these shall have power to put forward three other candidates, whose names, together with the signatures of not less than fifteen Members proposing them, must reach the Secretary by the 15th of November. The names of the six candidates will then be printed on a voting paper and sent to each Member with the December number of the Magazine, and the result of the voting published in the January issue. Should no alternative candidates be put forward, in the manner and by the date above specified, the three candidates recommended by the Council shall be deemed to have been duly elected. In the event of an equality of votes the President shall have a casting vote. If any Member of the Council does not attend a meeting for two years in succession the Council shall have power to elect another Member in his place. 10.--Immediately after the election of the Council that body shall proceed to elect three from its Members. These three, together with the Secretary- Treasurer, Assistant Secretary, and Editor, shall form a Committee known as the Executive Committee. The duties of the Executive Committee shall be as follows :-- (i) In the event of the resignation of any of the Officers during the Society's year, to fill temporarily the vacancy until the end of the year. In the case of the office being one which is held for more than one year (e.g. Secretary-Treasurer, Assistant Secretary, or Editor) the appointment shall be confirmed by the Council at its next meeting.

(ii) To act for the Council in the decision of any other matter that may arise in connection with the business of the Society. The decision of any matter by the Executive to be settled by a simple majority (three to form a quorum). In the event of a tie on any question, such question shall be forthwith submitted by letter to the Council for their decision. The Executive shall not have power

It shall not be lawful for the Treasurer to pay any account exceeding #10 unless such account be duly sanctioned by another Member of the Executive. It shall be lawful for the Secretary-Treasurer or Editor to pledge the Society's credit for a sum not exceeding #100. Should a Member wish any matter to be brought before the Council direct such matter should be sent to the Secretary with a letter stating that it is to be brought before the Council at their next meeting, otherwise communications will in the first place be brought before the Executive. A decision of a majority of the Council, or a majority of the Executive endorsed by the Council, shall be final and conclusive in all matters. 11. --The Editor shall have an absolute discretion as to what matter shall be published in the Magazine (subject to the control of the Executive Committee). The Secretary and Editor shall respectively refer all matters of doubt and difficulty to the Executive Committee. 12. --The Council (but not a committee of the Council) shall have power to alter and add to the Rules, from time to time, in any manner they may think fit. Five to form a quorum at any meeting of the Council. 13. --The Council shall have power to expel any Member from the Society at any time without assigning any reason.
(Instituted ist November, i8g6)

The Medal may be awarded at the discretion of the Council to any Member who shall succeed in breeding, in the United Kingdom, any species of bird which shall not, in the opinion of the Council, be known to have been previously bred in captivity in Great Britain or Northern Ireland. Any Member wishing to obtain the Medal must send a detailed account for publication in the Magazine within about eight weeks from the date of hatching of the young, and furnish such evidence of the facts as the Council may require. The Medal will be awarded only in cases where the young shall live to be old enough to feed themselves, and to be wholly independent of their parents. The question of awarding a Medal for the breeding of local races or sub-species of species that have already been bred shall be at the discretion of the Council. No Medal can be given for the breeding of hybrids. The account of the breeding must be reasonably full so as to afford instruction to our Members, and must appear in the Avicultural Magazine before it is published or notified elsewhere. It should describe the plumage of the young, and be of value as a permanent record of the nesting and general habits of the species. These points will have great weight when the question of awarding the Medal is under consideration. In every case the decision of the Council shall be final. The Medal will be forwarded to each Member as soon after it shall have been awarded as possible. The Medal is struck in bronze (but the Council reserve the right to issue it in silver in very special cases) and measures 2^ inches in diameter. It bears on the obverse a representation of two birds with a nest containing eggs, and the words " The Avicultural Society--founded 1894 ". On the reverse is the following inscription : " Awarded to [ name of recipient ] for rearing the young of [name of species ], a species not previously bred in captivity in the United Kingdom."
